Vermintide 2 is a great on rails horde mission type action game. 4 people equipped with medieval armaments slaying a tide... of vermin. Lots of fun to be had if you like Left 4 Dead style missions in this interesting setting.

Edit: New Review here, Old Review below: Much effort has been made since my previous review. The game has improved considerably and demonstrates many 'labors of love' so to speak. If you enjoy Left 4 Dead 2 style games, you may enjoy this.

Buggy, limited content, awful community that kicks people out of games at the end of the campaign for no reason (with nothing you can do about it), and collector's edition isn't worth purchasing. I loved vermintide 1, but vermintide 2 is in an awful state right now.

Let me be clear. If you have a dedicated 4 man team of people who can switch characters easily, this game will be fun, else the community will be anger inducing.

Then, to boot, I spent $45 on this game, and yet I'm expected to pay $10 more for late, buggy, half assed dlc?? I bought the Collector's Edition with the INTENT to have all DLC as it arose, because I loved VT1 SO MUCH that I didn't want to miss out on any dlc. But no. All I got from that extra $16 dollars was some cheap cosmetics and some DLC for VT1, which wasn't even explained in the pkg. I want to like this game, but FatShark is just phoning it in right now.
Still good and worth playing

[i]Warhammer Vermintide 2[/i] is a game I'm honestly surprised I ended up playing so much of considering I found the first game boring. For anyone who didn't play that game Vermintide is a hack-and-slash Left 4 Dead style of game, however it didn't have too much going for it. There weren't many levels to play, and the biggest issue in my eyes was that there really wasn't much reason to keep playing after you beat all the levels. Sure there are those who enjoy the challenge of beating the harder difficulties, but it's not for everyone, especially when the game is, frankly, pretty boring without friends. 

However, some of these issues are fixed in Vermintide 2. The improved item system adds a lot of replability as item rewards are less RNG dependent this time around, and you will always have item progression if you keep playing, completing quests, and earning yourself more item chests. This kept me in the game for awhile, far longer than I played the original, however it still got extremely boring after awhile, because at the end of the day you are playing the games few maps over and over again. There was 13 levels and almost any of them can be beaten in 20 minutes or less if you've experienced the level before. Therefore, even with harder difficulties as a challenge I ended up beating every level on the harder difficulties multiple times and it became way too much.

On the bright side, not everyone will have this issue. I have friends who love grinding the same levels to earn better gear. Another reason for grinding these levels is to rank-up your characters. Something that hurt my longevity with the game was that I really only found 1 character to be entertaining to play; however, there are 5 different characters, each with multiple class types, and 1 of them is sure to strike a chord with you. In fact, you may even enjoy multiple, and in that case you'll probably really love the game!

I had fun with the game when I first played through it, and even continued to enjoy just playing on the hardest difficulties while I leveled my shade to 35, but once I hit that point it was over for me. Playing the same maps over and over again can only work for a certain period of time, and if they really want players to keep playing past this point they should try to create a better daily quest/reward system, as well as better item rewards and specific challenges; after all, it's a PvE game so nobody cares if you can complete daily challenges to get strong loot.

The core gameplay here is pretty strong, it feels great mowing through giant packs of rats, and using your special ability feels dope. The enemy classes are pretty unique and some are real challenges that require a coordinated group effort to take down. Gameplay is certainly where this game shines the most; it's the systems around it and the lack of real incentives that are its weakest characteristics.

Lastly, I would highly recommend playing with friends if you're looking to pick this one up. Straight-up, this game will be boring by yourself, and even with 2 players you probably won't have the ideal experience. I'd recommend playing with a group of 3-4 and allow yourself to get a feel for each character before choosing which to primarily play, maybe even have your whole group take turns to keep it fresh.

To Fatshark, I would say great job. Yes I have some gripes, but I ended up playing the game for about 25 hours and that says a lot. My only suggestions would be to have more levels in future games, try to improve the item system, maybe even allow item trading, and give more of an incentive to keep playing the game following completion of the campaign; increasing item power and leveling heroes is certainly an incentive, but not one that will keep the casual player murdering rats any longer than they need to. This could even be done with a more interesting achievement list as the current one is full of tasks that are extremely easy or unbearably grindy with no in-between.

[b]Recommended[/b]

Not that the violence of the game should be appealing, the feel of the action of this game really stands out.

The sword swings all feel very realistic, especially the crits. It felt like someone in reality had just gained a burst of energy, and the swing in it shows that. It would be nice if momentum damage was incorporated, for example if I was dodging left and swinging from right to left, it would be nice for dmg increase of some %. Or say if I am jumping down from a cliff and head shotting a subject, and if aim is good then it should reflect in some ways.

Also, timed blocks or parry should incur a higher crit percentage, just for the return shot. This will make your game play ceiling level go even higher and with that, even as a collectable talent from Chaos Waste. Increases of up to 50% isn't too over powered, you should test it. You will love how it plays. Still get swarmed in Hordes since it's only one shot and stamina is limited, albeit one would die in style if timing blocks. Suppose it's easiest to test it on GK first, since that 20% lvl 25 talent doesn't really line up with the Lvl 5 30% increase in power. The timed block is harder to pull off than holding down the heavy button.

Fought skaven. Fought Chaos. Repeat.

I only have a little over 5,000 hours in this game, but I feel like I have enough game play to give a fair review of it now. You can't go wrong with this game. It is still getting updates from the developers, and it's been out for quite a while. If you like 4 player co-op games you'll love this game.  

The largest problem is starting the game. The first few difficulties can be a slog, and the real fun doesn't start until champion. Open your commendation chests, and any other chests up until champion emperor chests as soon as you get them. Your item power increases from opening them, and saving them just slows your growth and ability to get to higher difficulties quickly, and get better chances for red items. 

There are currently three modes and, but only two are available without buying an additional dlc.  The ones that come with the base game are normal co-op campaigns, and the chaos wastes. The normal co-op campaigns each take about 30 minutes to finish. You will find 3 Tomes and 2 Grimoires hidden in each of these maps and getting them to the end will provide you with more xp, and better reward chests. Picking up a tome will take your med slot. you can drop them and heal if you find a med just remember to pick them up again. Grimoires reduce the teams health bars by about 31% and cannot be swapped out like a tome. You will also lose them if you get completely killed. They can be thrown if you get in a sticky spot and need more of your health bars back by equipping them and then long holding attack.  

Chaos wastes is a roguelite version of the game. There are no books in this mode, and completing one takes a little over an hour. However, you will probably get 3 of the highest tier chests for the difficulty you attempt if you make it through to the end. 2 will be highest for sure, but the third depends on maps completed and coins retrieved. You start with just the talents you've earned and white versions of the weapons you start with. You will find blue coins scattered across the maps that will let you purchase weapon upgrades, weapon exchanges, and boons. You can get some pretty crazy builds in this mode and it's a lot of fun. 

The third DLC mode, is not played much by the community and usually is looked down upon. It is only available through the purchase of the Winds of Magic DLC. It has a few unique modifiers like lightning strikes, harder armored enemies, and thorny briars spawning where you kill enemies. they can be fun but you'll probably want to have a group ready to attempt finishing those as the difficulty becomes extremely high. 

They are working on a versus mode. As of the writing of this, only an Alpha has been released. I was not able to play that and do not have any information on that mode. If you like Versus modes, like that in left 4 dead 2, that might be a bonus coming for you.

If you are a streamer, there is another sub mode that allows your viewers to vote on hazards and boons that they want to have happen in your game. It is very easy to use. At the map, just click on the twitch button and enter your twitch name. Just make sure you are host or your host has it turned on too. If a few of you are streaming, as long as the host has it on, if everyone streaming starts twitch mode the chats from each of the streamers will be able to participate in the voting of what happens. The frequency of votes and the speed in which they finish can be adjusted in your option settings. 

A few things that may help you starting out...
In the game settings there are quite a few things that are not turned on by default that can help. If you don't want the game to recommend a different hero, you can go into the network settings and tell the game not to recommend other heroes. If you are having trouble keeping track of team members, you can go into the settings and set hero outlines from "on" to "always on." If you would like to have actual numbers on your hud, you can turn on the numerical display. Also, the game has a stamina mechanic. holding block will show you your stamina in the form of shield icons. a normal hit from a normal rat can be blocked for half a shield if you are blocking it from the front in your effective block angle, but you will also block outside of that angle and block behind you as well, it just would cost a full stamina shield  to block outside of that effective front angle. Each weapon has a different cone shape for what costs half stamina to block in front of you. if you hover over the melee weapons it will show that cone in the top right corner of the box that appears. You can also push using stamina. this will cost a full stamina shield to do.  To push, hold block and tap attack. If you want to deal some damage when pushing, instead of just tapping attack while blocking, long hold your push and you will follow up the push with a melee attack. get used to dodging and blocking as they will become very necessary in the higher difficulties. 

The players in this game are usually great to work with. There will be a few bad apples. but try to be friendly and don't hog all of the supplies, and most people will be great to play with. Another small annoyance is if a host leaves, it will end your game in normal co-op campaigns. In chaos wastes it will just kick back to the start of the map you've been playing. if you do get disconnected from a game in the CHAOS WASTES, if you are quick and get back into the same game with the same character with the players you were playing with, all your boons and coins, will be restored to you upon rejoining. 

I Hope this helps in your decision to pick up the game, and maybe i'll see you in there! Happy Exterminating!

[h1] Stunning experience  [/h1]
This game is truly one of it's kind. In this game you can experience the authentic Warhammer world with 4 player co-op. The maps are visually beautiful and the music fits in the gameplay. In the game you can play as different heroes and choose from multiple careers and decide what fits you the best. The the combat system is super satisfying. There are bunch of weapon options for each hero and all of them has their own unique and badass mechanism to sweep, stagger and block enemies. The more I play this game the more I feel there is stuff to learn. You can also play on different difficulties. Especially the hardest difficulty is [u]very challenging[/u] and demands the players to focus like never before. Only "downside" in this game is that there are too many in game micro-transactions in my opinion. However it's up to you if you want to buy new maps and careers. 

I would rate this game 5/5

edit: tl;dr: 10/10

I've played few games that deliver such an incredible vibe and atmosphere coupled with good gameplay. The maps are really well done and the music compliments them so well. The conversations/banter between the characters is what brings the game alive though. Their conversations between each other still manage to make me laugh and it never feels like I'm listening to a conversation I've heard before. Sure, maybe it happens, but the fact that there are so many different things they say, it never feels that way. They really put work into that and it allows the game to always feel fresh, even when you're playing a map you've played a lot of times before.

[h1] The Maps [/h1]
They are really well done and all of them are detailed and have thought put into them.
There are a lot of maps and with the DLCs the pool becomes even bigger. Not to mention, you don't even need the map DLCs in order to play the maps, if the person hosting the game, has the DLCs, it will draw from their map pool, which is amazing. Buying the map DLCs unlocks other things like quests, weapons, cosmetics. 

[h1] Music and Sound [/h1]
The music and sound in this game add so much to the atmosphere. Nothing bad to say, the music is wonderful. Each special enemy has a distinct sound (kinda like in L4D), so you know they are around somewhere and you wanna make sure to kill them as quickly as possible. Those moments are especially exciting when you are fighting against hordes of enemies and you hear a special and you juggle between fighting the hordes and trying to look out for the special. 

[h1] Visuals [/h1]
I don't think I have to say anything about the visuals, they speak for themselves. If you have a solid GPU and can play on high settings, the game is really beautiful. Playing this on a 3440x1440 monitor with a 2070Super and oh boy, is it a joy to play.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
The combat is simply 10/10. When you play for the first time, you will most likely only spam left click attack and wonder why some enemies wont take any damage from your mindless left clicking, ''what is this stupid Armor sign'' you will say.
The fun of the game comes from the harder difficulties though, as the mindless left click gameplay doesn't cut it anymore. Blocking, dodging, heavy attacks will be an important part of your rotation. You will learn how every weapon plays differently, has different attributes and has a different job, some have wide sweeps for cutting down hordes, some have armor piercing, some do higher headshot damage for those precise players etc etc etc.
For me the game became way more fun once I was playing Champion, as I had to actually turn on my brain and nowadays only Legend cuts it for me. If you find a main and level that character up and get some legendaries, switch to Champion and eventually to Legend once you're really comfortable and have good gear.

After each round you get a loot chest. Higher Difficulty = Higher value chest. What I like about this system is that 1. It incentivizes striving for higher difficulties and 2. Collecting the Tomes and Grimores throughout the map makes the run even more difficult, but the chest you get at the end levels up. Carrying a tome for example takes up a Healing pot slot and Grimores take up a buff potion slot AND give you a curse that reduces your HP.

There are 5 different characters with each having 3 (some 4) different classes, so there is a lot of variety in that. They all have different talent trees, passives and playstyles. Although usually the better talent rows unlock at higher levels.

So yea, pretty sweet game.

PS: Unfortunately the Vermintide 2 community consists of a bunch of cheapskates who will cry about cheap DLC, because they are spoiled. The base game is already super cheap on a sale and offers so much content. The map DLCs have between 2 - 3 new maps each. The reviews of the DLCs are filled with cheap babies crying about how a DLC that cost 10 (5 on a sale) bucks, only has 2 maps (and extras btw, like weapons, cosmetics, quests etc). Truly mindblowing how people can complain to spend a bit of money after they put a ton of hours into the base game. The class DLC reviews are even worse. The devs decided to split the DLC into class + weapons DLC and a class + weapons + cosmetics DLC, in order to allow people with less money to buy the class + weapons only. 
But then of course you have people crying over the fact that the cosmetics aren't included. They expect a new class, new weapons and cosmetics for that class for 4 bucks. Those people blow my mind. Not to mention, the others who complain that once you buy the cosmetics pack, it unlocks the quests to get those cosmetics and some people complain about that?? I for one, prefer that not everybody is walking around wit those cosmetics and you have to do quests to get them.

People nowadays spend so much money on 1 skin in a stupid game and yet complain about 5 - 10 bucks for map DLCs and then go crying on the internet about ''gaming nowadays is screwed, there are skins everywhere and not enough traditional DLC'' but when a dev brings out ''traditional DLC'' that takes more time to make, they want that DLC to be cheaper than a skin and give a negative review. LOGIC.

fatshark can definitely make some... highly questionable decisions, but holy sigmar can they make some fucking GOOD gameplay loops. graphics are amazing, the combat is fluid, punchy and satisfying, the characters have some truly spectacular voice acting, and playing through the maps always feels different thanks to the AI director that always keeps you on your toes.
some downsides however: beastmen. they're not fun. at all. a good word for them is 'over-tuned'.
the levelling process is slow and arduous, the crafting system isn't very good or user-friendly, and i'm not a fan of how hard fatshark are focusing on microtransactions and the game shop, but that's more of a problem with fatshark as a company than the game itself, so take it as you will.
besides a couple of nagging issues and nitpicks, i've enjoyed my experience. i have 713 hours as of posting this review, and i'm sure i will boot up this game every now and then and put even more hours into it. the gameplay is just THAT good.

The devs keep nerfing anything that was fun, instead of improving the crap nobody wants to use. Their latest victim was the Shade career (it's a class), which was squishy as hell, and was only good for killing bosses, so what did they do? They nerfed it's boss killing capabilities to hell and back by 15%. This is a recurring theme with this game.

A very fun game that continues to improve with time. If you're looking for solid melee combat against hordes of enemies this game is for you. I'm glad Fatshark has continued to support Vermintide even after Darktide has been out for so long because while similar the games offer different things. I've preferred the more melee-centered combat of Vermintide along with the Warhammer Fantasy setting and enemies. However, if that isn't your thing but the gameplay seems interesting, maybe try Darktide. They're both solid especially with a group of friends. There is a learning curve, but most of the community is chill and willing to teach you. 9/10

[h1] Time To Bring Chaos Into Order! [/h1]
The game is set in the Warhammer Fantasy universe during the early days of the End Times. The game follows the Heroes of Ubersreik from the first game against the Skaven hordes of Clan Fester and their new allies, the Root Bloods (a Chaos Warband dedicated to Nurgle, the Chaos God of Disease and Decay). The only thing standing between utter defeat and victory is you and your allies. If you fall - so too will the Empire.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]With huge attention to detail that gives each map a dark, and crueling atmosphere, Vermintide 2 brings in a dark look into a world filled with chaos and destruction. The lighting looks pretty good, even though in some sections it can look kinda dull. It’s not a common issue, so not a big problem. The UI fits the game so well. It gives off this dark fantasy look that I really appreciate, also the UI is easy to understand and not painful to the eyes. The weapon and armor models look absolutely stellar, even the enemies look terrifying and intimidating. They did the enemy design so well for the Chaos. I’m just really pleased with the art style this game provides. It’s so well done![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]This game gives me a huge Left 4 Dead feel (and some may not like that comparison), but I actually enjoyed it a ton! It fit the game perfectly and I’m so happy they went with this gameplay style. Melee combat is simple, but really effective and fun. Fight many hordes while reaching the end of the level and fight a boss near or at the end. It’s all really fun and feels rewarding once completing a level. You can dodge attacks which feel satisfying to pull off, and the gore is top notch, making the melee combat that much more intense. You have up to 5 characters to play as, and each character has 3 skill trees (or careers they call it). Every character has a special ability, and you also have light and strong attacks, making the combat fun and it doesn’t feel like you are spamming attacks aimlessly. The gameplay feels fresh and addicting, and playing on a harder difficulty requires good teammates and strategy. The bots are pretty okay I guess, sadly the bots don’t scale with you. That means that if you only play with one character and decide to play a higher difficulty, the other bots won’t scale to your level, so I recommend playing with friends or go find a match publicly.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎭Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]In my opinion this is where the game shines. I highly recommend playing co-op in this game more than single player. Playing with friends in this game is so fun and addicting! Going through the map on a harder difficulty with a strong character build felt so rewarding and intense. This is how you play the game. I had no desync issues, no connection issues at all. Everything felt polished in terms of multiplayer.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]With many cool levels and character builds, you will add many hours into Vermintide 2! With many character builds to create, and difficulties to challenge yourself with friends, this game can provide an easy 40+ hours of playtime no question.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The sound design is really good. The voice acting is superb and fits the characters perfectly, and the Chaos and Skaven sound scary as well! The weapon sounds incredible, especially when you hit your enemy, it has a satisfying feeling to it![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]I haven’t really come across any game breaking issues. Only some minor bugs but nothing too serious to bring up. The multiplayer even felt fine with no issues or crashing issues.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]Now for some reason, my PC has had some serious problems here. I can’t get a good framerate on my GTX 1070 which was super annoying. This just may be my end. But when a horde comes in I get around 40 fps even on low settings. I have watched videos with similar specs and they have had no issues. I’m not sure if it’s my graphics card, because I’m able to play many new games just fine on high settings. This just may be a me issue, but I thought I might point that out. You should be okay, but just keep this issue in mind. Besides that I have had no stutters or crashes, so it could just be my computer.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Really fun in co-op
[*]Dark/gritty atmosphere
[*]Amazing level design
[*]Great weapon variety
[*]Incredible enemy design
[*]Mod support via Steam Workshop
[*]Weapon combos are different for each weapon
[*]DLC maps are playable for everyone if the Host owns the DLC
[*]Characters interactions are hilarious and are the primary way of narrating the lore of the game
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Can be grindy in later stages of leveling
[*]Cataclysm difficulty is locked behind a paywall
[*]Bots levels are based on the levels of your characters.
[*]Game does a bad job at explaining its mechanics and providing important info in general.
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]8.5/10
I recommend this game on sale for around 25-50% especially with the content bundle.
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]Warhammer: Vermintide 2 is an absolute blast! From the intense action, the intimidating enemies, and awesome characters you can play as. The combat is truly addicting, with many action packed sections in every level. The game can get grindy, and the bots feel kinda useless in some situations. With a few friends this game will provide you with so many awesome moments and with many hours of playtime! Give this game a try if you are looking for a fantasy style action game with friends, it’s a must buy if that’s on the shopping list.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

Love Vermintide. I played the original only a little bit, but for some reason Vermintide 2 really took hold of me.  A perfect game with friends or just to kill an hour or two on your own.  I still have yet to find a game that does melee combat so well, I suppose technically Darktide does it too but I don't have much positive to say about Darktide.

Vermintide 2 is now over 5 years old, and though the playerbase is small, it is very dedicated. The content dripfeed has more-or-less dried up, but if you don't mind playing missions multiple times over, you can spend a lot of time in this game.  You really do stick around for the game's character though.  The banter between the heroes is fun and provides a mixture of comic relief, lore and character building, and tossing aside scores of skaven with each swipe of your weapon still feels great over 5 years after the initial release.

Not really much else to say.  It plays well, it runs well, the audio is great, the visuals have generally aged quite well.

Vermintide 2 is an amazing solo or co-up game with lots of replay value. It gets compared a lot to the Left 4 Dead franchise with it's well-written characters, A-to-B navigation survival gameplay and thrilling action.

[b]COOLS:[/b]
+ Perfect for beginners to jump into, it's what I did!
+ Game artstyle, theme and overall execution is absolutely fantastic and represents the Warhammer world and all it's nastiness perfectly. As a newcomer to the franchise it really engrossed me.
+ The 5 playable characters (each with 4 different classes!) are all fleshed-out, dialogue and gameplay-wise. Hearing the group banter on is half the fun. [b]Voice acting is superb.[/b]
+ [b]Combat[/b] is simple but has a lot of nuance, especially on higher difficulties. Enemy variety and design is great,  Mowing down scores of swarming rats out for your blood is thrilling and satisfying.
+ Playing together is encouraged and more fun but people often fail to mention it works just fine as a solo-player experience as well! 
+ Plenty of challenge to be had with lots of maps and difficulty options with an interesting rewards system: Find tomes during a mission that take up one of your equipment slots, the more tomes the riskier it gets but the rewards increase just the same!
+ Graphics are great. Sound design is great. Controls are straightforward and easily customizable.
+ Matchmaking is quick and the playerbase still seems plenty active! The many memes and funny fan-content is just icing on top.
+ [b]Is still being updated at the time of writing this review.[/b] Active devs who communicate with their fanbase! Great to see!
+ [b]HOLY SIGMAR APPROVES[/b]

[b]NOT-SO-COOLS:[/b]
-YMMV, joining other players through matchmaking might find you alone and confused as the party is used to rushing for loot and don't take new players into consideration.
-If you've played a while you will notice that characters repeat some lines a lot, which can get grating and breaks immersion.
-Failing a mission at any point means NO REWARDS aside from a bit of measly XP, which can feel real rough when you go down right before the end.  This harsh punishment is also part of the draw though, making failure weigh heavily means victory through hardship is all the sweeter.
-Weapon descriptions and traits are vague at best, It's really up to the player to try everything out to see how they all function in action.
-Blightstormers are camping wallhackers plz ban Fatshark :(

And that's it really. I don't have much critique aside from minor gripes about gameplay. I hear at release the game was SUPER buggy but that's all been fixed through time. The DLC's and in-game content are a bit pricey but never a must, so you can wait on sales. A bit tough to find your ground but if you spend some time with each character I can guarantee you'll find one that suits you like a glove! 

So if you've got some time to spare and feel like you could increase your heartrate with some massive plague rodent slaughter, this is definitely a recommendation!

Thanks for reading and if you have any questions please leave a comment~

This is a a great game if you like co-op games. You rely on team mates heavily. My favourite thing in this game are the characters and how they banter to each other. My most disliked are the cosmetics(The aesthetics are sad and wish there was more options cosmetically). There is gear progression to keep you playing even after you have beaten all the missions. There really isn't a campaign and the missions can sorta follow some kind of loose idea of a story but essentially its an instance match making mission runner with bonuses along the way that are fun to collect. The game allows you to have bots and you can keep your bots with gear load outs. I loved levelling my bots up so that they could work for me on harder difficulty's when i didn't want to rely on capable players. That is my main gripe with dark tide and wont be purchasing that game tell it has bots. That being said if you like games like Left for dead. Then you'll probably love this game.

Real Review:
This game scratches the itch for a horde clearing melee game. The game has a lot of different play styles that typically translates between different classes. If you want to play Left4Dead but don't really feel like relying too much on shooting guns, this is the game for you.

The pros:
- Amazing voice acting
- Cool character skins
- Beautiful maps (especially the newest maps)
- Twitch mode (fun to watch and vote)
- solo mode

The cons:
- Toxic player base that is prone to ragequit and disconnect, forcing you to start levels all over again.
- Lots of crashes in the new maps

Going to edit to give some context for the recent complaining spree:

There were a small number of nerfs to severely over performing items, characters, and abilities. With buffs to under performing  items, characters, and abilities.
A small subset of people think that PVE games should never be balanced and that you should just buff everything until the game is completely trivialized. They are now complaining endlessly about how the game is dead and that everything is ruined and there are no good weapons and blah blah blah. In reality the games playerbase doubled overnight because of a small balance patch that has been long overdue and long awaited.
 
Most of the complainers? Elves.. again... because javelin got the tiniest of nerf to be less spammable and braindead.

The other class mains took their nerfs like champs and in some cases (chad Kruber mains) didnt say a word about their nerfs and in other cases (chad bardin mains) have flat called his buffs unnecessary and in need of reverting.

The inevitable clowns on the review will be from angry forum dwellers stalking everything I have public in a vain attempt to discredit me because I DARED to disagree with them about their precious javelin. See previous SotT review for more context.

I would also like to add that all this whinging and complaining amounted to literally less than 150 negative reviews in the last 30 days.
Dont worry though guys, they arent the vocal minority.

Normal review:
Vermintide 2 is a great game that you can easily sink waaay too many hours into. The core gameplay is unbeatable, never found another game that does it as good or in quite the same way. The combat is so satisfying and weighty. The graphics are very good looking. It feels very rewarding to get better at the game and move up through the difficulty levels. Its also fairly challenging for those who want it but if you just want to enjoy the gameplay it has appropriate lower levels of difficulty. 

The DLC is fairly good as well, with the exception being Winds of Magic. The Devs have had a bit of a rocky road to getting this game going but they are trying and doing a pretty darn good job now. They are very active in the forums to help with technical problems and bug reports. They do a pretty decent job of bugfixing although it may be rather slow at times.

The community is mostly nice and welcoming. More experienced players are usually willing to help or answer questions. In my about 2600 hours I have had maybe 10 games with trolls, arsehats, or other less than desirable people. Not bad for that amount of time.

All and all give it a whirl. For 30 bucks its very well worth the money, and its frequently on sale for as low as 7.99 which is practically stealing. Very good value for money, very good game, you wont have played another like it.

[b] This game has the best melee dance of any game I've ever played [/b]

To explain what that means and why this game is so good, there are a few things to understand:
The battles feel epic to overcome as there are four heroes versus hundreds or thousands of enemies, and every enemy is capable of representing a real threat. Movement and attacks have real weight and momentum. The melee mechanics the player has control over include dodging, blocking, pushing, heavy attacks, and light attacks. While these are common elements in many action games, they have a far greater depth in this game than most. [b] It truly is a dance, and when you find the rhythm against a giant horde of enemies you feel unstoppable. [/b] The game also has FPS mechanics which heavily reward aim for headshots. Quickswapping to your ranged weapon and flick headshotting a special enemy (dangerous unique enemies) while also managing a horde full of trash rats and elites who are attempting to cut you apart is an amazing feeling.

To begin with: at higher difficulties, every single attack or movement option you make must be intentional. A misplaced attack, push, or dodge could result in an instant down on your character. Elite enemies in this game have powerful attacks, and will often surround and gang up on you. Tracking the movements and attacks of elites in chaotic situations and successfully countering them feels like a true desperate battle.

To control these enemies, you have many options which allows diverse and expressive play styles. Walking through the mechanics available to the player:

Dodging. The most important mechanic for evading damage. It requires timing as dodges are somewhat limited and dodging [b] into [/b] an attack can be very common. It is the preferred method for countering the attacks thrown at you by elites, and when mastered allows you to [b] cut down an entire horde of enemies while dancing around in their face. [/b] You can usually dodge about every second or so and not worry about running out of dodges.

Blocking. A useful tool for stopping incoming attacks, and is also limited by stamina. Some attacks from enemies can take your entire stamina out at once and guard break you. You can also time your block to exactly when an attack lands for a parry. Combining dodging and blocking alone makes a powerful and deep defensive toolkit.

Attacks. There are heavy attacks, light attacks, alt fire attacks, and dozens of unique weapons with unique attacks and combos to learn. You could spend dozens of hours learning a single weapon. Apparently some weapons have novel length guides (I'm looking at you billhook) written about them. Every combo has its place, and the weapons have unique categories they fall into such as mixed horde control (elites and trash), elite slaying, trash slaying, boss slaying.

Did I mention this game has bosses? It has several, all of which you can learn to solo. Furthermore, if the team misplays their pacing through the map, or sometimes even when they play it correctly, you can end up fighting ultra powerful boss enemies which require the full focus of at least one hero to manage. Combine this with a full wave of enemies and specials, and you have incredible and difficult battles. Overcoming horrible situations in this game feels truly special.

Anyway, this game is really good

Its a very good game. I thought to refund it while playing the first prolog mission because that one was really horrible made but If you play a few hours and play some missions you might like this type of co-op game so its not an easy start to get into this game.

You only need to buy these items to enjoy the game (I would recommend to wait for a steam sale):
1. Vermintide 2: Starter Bundle: It has the base game + mission DLCs
2. Necromancer carrer DLC: Its a great new class to play with
3. War Priest DLC: Its a great new class to play with

The start into this game is a bit of a grind and your class will most likely feel a bit weak. Your class starts with level 1 and you unlock the last talent on level 30. Thats not a big deal for your first class because you wanna play all those missions and maps anyways. But it can be boring to grind all those levels and talents for your 3rd, 4th and 5th class because at that point you might want to play hardmode. So its kinda boring to unlock all classes for late game. You better try out which class is in your favor and maybe stick to 1 or 2. This games has a lot of weapons. Try them out while leveling your class up. Some are really cool and strong, others could feel weak and useless. Each class has different weapons, only some are standard for multiple classes.

Its a loot game. You get 3 items after each mission if you completed it, failure will give you class XP but no items at all. 

This game is better with friends. I would recommend you to use discord or search players on steam discussion or just add people ingame that played well.

Left 4 Dead + Overwatch is fun. The careers are diverse and surprisingly balanced. I don't like to Tome & Grimoire system for loot drops all that much, but the game is pretty forgiving in general once you learn how to dodge and parry in addition to timing those juicy charge-attack headshots. Melee is life, 8/10.

Entertaining and memorable characters with great voice acting.
Very fun combat system, everything from slashing enemies with swords to burning skaven alive with fire magic feels great.
Successfully using mechanics like blocking and pushing feels rewarding and is basically necessary for higher difficulty play.
A varied and atmospheric collection of maps, great for replay value. Also, the OST is pretty awesome.

Not a big fan of the weapon acquisition loop, since you will constantly find newer, higher value weapons after just a couple missions, and the old gear will just sit there waiting to be broken down into crafting materials from the get go.
Plus the whole inventory crafting system and similar features feel like a chore more than anything.

A big issue I've found is that random players with a MUCH higher level may join your game and completely delete everything they see, which takes the fun out of the game since they'll feel very overpowered in comparison to a new player. Even the difference between a 4 lvl and a 17 lvl is extreme. But that hasn't been too much of a problem so far.

And when that doesn't happen, you've got yourself an absolute Gem of a Co-op Hack n Slasher.
I'm really glad Warhammer Fantasy has games such as Vermintide 2, it makes the setting that much more immersive.

Overall 9/10, may Sigmar bless this verbose Review. 🌠🔥⚡

I found this game to be incredibly fun back when I played it regularly, now I've been into some other stuff but Darktide brought me back to the universe of Warhammer and made me remember how amazing this was! I would spend hours grinding characters, leveling up. My favorite part besides the archer gameplay has got to be the fact that you only open the rooms for each character once you reach a certain level with them, giving you a little more lore just jumping around the lobby while you're waiting to queue. I enjoyed the expansions/dlc's for this game also, and bought them both. This is a highly recommended playing experience, especially if you have friends! Only issue, you can't create your character and have to instead base off of which ever class you want and abilities that class will have. For instance I played archer more of a sneak with double daggers than i did a back line archer unless there was a big guy who needed to be knocked down with some headshots first!

It's good. i feel most newer players casually play this and don't really get how deep the combat is in harder difficulties, a lot just spam attack and miss the concepts of creating space for you and your friends, playing certain roles to help your party like a elite sniper or a crowd controller. 

Lots of people give up on the game on the second difficulty and never really learn past that. I'm not a legend player, i can play there but i'm never the one carrying i can say that much, but just even getting to be very consistent on champion feels so good, greatly recommend actually going above that line from casual play and dedication to get the most out of this game.

Some of the best fun ive ever had with a coop game.
The game have had its issues over the years most of which in my opinion have been resolved at this state.
they changed the marketing strategy from paid dlc to content being free and releasing paid dlc skins 
which is good for new players since it means a lot more content for them.
They added chaos wastes mode which is a great 2-3 hour mode where you go through several maps with other players and progressively get stronger get better weapons and perks as you go quite a large addition about the size of the campaign. 
They are in the making of a versus mode which i suspect is going to be a lot like the one in left for dead which basically is where this game got its core gameplay from the way it plays is very similar apart from the added rpg mechanics like levels and loot which in my opinion is honestly also where the game runs into its biggest issue its bordering on openly hostile to new players in terms of how fast you level and get the talents that make a huge difference later on.
The same with the overall gear power it just takes to long for new players to get into.
i have had several friends that have put down the game because of this which is a shame.
once you get to max gear level and you hit 30+ on your characters and play on higher difficulties the game really shines the most it can be brutally punishing at times however.
but once you learn how to go about melee combat in terms of switching up your attack patterns to get certain attacks at certain points and when to use which attacks for stagger armor pen or cleave etc it really does end up with some of the most satisfying melee combat ive ever played unfortunately the game also does little in terms of teaching you this as a new player.
the amount of content available to you with the base game at this point is very good with about 21 levels without dlc plus chaos wastes which is more or less the same size as the base campaign.
The dlcs are decent the 4th careers are priced reasonably in my opinion but the winds of magic dlc is way way overpriced if you do not want to play weaves which most people ive played with do not
So an option to buy only the mission and weapons related would be a better move for newer players because the pricing issue is not adressed unless its on sale.
The gameplay in terms of combat is what makes the game what it is so if you do not find the combat enough to keep you coming you will not get much out of the game the weapons and gear is not what is gonna keep you coming because once you get weapons that are 300 the difference between orange gear and maxed out red gear is honestly negligible it is nice that it always rolls with maxed out stats but even at 800+ hours i find myself using just as many orange weapons as red ones which is a plus because it means that getting gear to be able to play on the hardest difficulty with the properties and traits you want is very fast once you hit 300.
That also means that the reward you get from red gear is not that noticeable playing which in my opinion it is good because it takes focus away from gear and puts it on you improving your playstyle which is easy to learn and very hard to master.
Playing on anything above legend does not net you better rewards in terms of gear it only let you complete challenges to earn portraits, skins and frames which i do think is a good choice since it makes it easier to go for red gear if you for some reason feel like you need to get that legend is a lot easier and it puts cataclysm as a thing to only do if you want a challenge and some very brutal punishment for making mistakes.
The fact that gear from chests carries over from character to character in terms of power is a great thing because it means that you get going way faster and it means a lot less grind because once you get trinket charm and amulet with high stats you will be able to use it across all characters so you only really need to look towards weapons which takes us to the weapon differences
I don't really find any weapon not usable even at high difficulty however there are some weapons that will preform better on cataclysm than others of course. 
There is a good variety of movesets in your arsenal and it does change up how you should approach combat quite a bit in especially since there are is a very large difference of how effective the weapons will be against certain enemies and in certain situations and it forces you to change your playstyle around the weapons you play with to make the most out of them.
You do have some very easy to pick up weapons that will preform very very well on cataclysm without being all that hard to use effectively but there are also weapons that have a very large skill ceiling and require you to be a lot more aware of your surroundings and which targets to engage as they tend to have some movesets that require you to be very good at shaping your comboes and animation canceling. 
The classes are very varied and as of this review the only class that felt lacking (pyromancer) has been buffed and now every single class is in fact viable on the harder difficulties some will of course preform better than others but every class is quite playable on the unmodded dificulties.
speaking of modding this game has an official realm for you to play on which actually does allow for some modding as long as it is a sanctioned mod that has been approved for official servers.
And it does have a modded realm to go wild in if you wanna do that.

If you enjoy playing with friends and have a couple to play this with its in my opinion one of the best games around in terms of coop it requires you to plan ahead and on the fly in terms of who does what and when to do so.
it requires you to play as a team and communicate and work together to play on high difficulties and feels massively rewarding when you do so sucssesfully.
if you intend on playing it alone this will significantly limit the game because playing on cataclysm with bots is just borderline impossible 

at this state the only real gripe i have with this game is its hostility to new players in terms of the amount of time they have to put in before the game is at its best.
The devs also seem to keep focusing on new content and no end in sight so far so you can surely expect more content to be added with time even with the release of Darktide however we did have a whole year(2022) with almost no new content apart from 1 new level which surely had to do with the main focus being switched towards Darktide even with the game being released in that mess of a state that it was in.....

This review is long, long overdue. I could simply point to the number of hours I've played this game and leave it at that, but I'll try to put in a little more effort. I've been a big fan of first-person melee games ever since Dark Messiah of Might and Magic, I've put hundreds and hundreds of hours into titles like Chivalry: Medieval Warfare over the years, so when I saw footage of Vermintide 2 back in 2018 I was immediately intrigued, despite not having played the first game. I resolved to try it out to see if it was as good as it looked. 

I vividly remember struggling a bit at first, with memorizing the map layouts and book locations, dealing with specials during hordes, figuring out the best way to defeat specific bosses, and learning the hard way that I should be wary of getting stabbed from behind by little ambient rats when I least expect it (there's always at least one). I often got frustrated, mostly with myself. Still, despite having a demanding job at the time, I persevered, and soon enough I was playing on Legend difficulty with relative ease (we now usually play on Cataclysm, albeit without taking books). This might sound a little dramatic, but I can say without exaggerating that I had many of my all-time best gaming moments while playing this game. There's just something special about forming a line or circle with your teammates, and then staying mobile as you're fighting a horde, elites (possibly a whole patrol), and a boss at the same time, all while hearing the menacing, telltale sounds of several specials approaching. You get into 'the zone', your muscle memory takes over, and you and your comrades get to experience that very satisfying, visceral sensation of power as you slaughter hundreds and hundreds of enemies while remaining mostly unscathed yourselves.

Summarized, this is a very specific sort of game, almost in its own genre, as it is both co-op and mostly melee-based. It's not going to be for everyone. You have to decide for yourself if it is something that speaks to your preferences. I got lucky in the sense that Vermintide 2 seems almost tailor-made for me, and I happened to make some very good friends while playing it - you know who you are. Fatshark are also known for their occasionally baffling, counterintuitive, or poorly implemented design choices and balance changes, so keep that in mind.
However, for these same reasons, if the game [i]does[/i] end up clicking with you, it's a completely unique and intoxicating experience, like nothing you've ever played before. That's why I would ultimately recommend that you check it out if you're on the fence, unless you already know for certain that this style of gameplay doesn't appeal to your sensibilities at all.

Got me hooked so much that I played it every day, every week until I got about 140 hours of playtime and then got burnt out. My online friend that I found in the game kept playing it until he got almost 500 hours of playtime.

The combat is really satisfying and well-made, rewarding quick thinking, good reaction time and mechanical skill. The RPG aspect of the game is also well designed, there are a multitude of characters with their own classes, made for varying playstyles but can also be further adjusted and customized via Talents, the weapons you equip and the properties/traits on those weapons and your Necklace/Charm/Trinket.

DLC classes are very fun but not OP/P2W, pretty cheap but the only problem is that the cool cosmetics for DLC classes are locked behind another DLC which is more expensive than the DLC classes themselves for some reason.
DLC campaigns give (reportedly) very good weapons but are locked behind a fairly high paywall for only a small amount of missions. For the price of Winds of Magic, I could get another good game or two small neat games.

Overall, the game is pretty fun. 8.5/10

In the grim darkness of the age of Sigmar, there is only war, and in this dire epoch, I bring unto you tidings of a digital battleground where valiant warriors battle against the unrelenting tide of verminous foes. Let your hearts be filled with zeal as we delve into the essence of this virtual crucible.

Behold, brothers and sisters, a game where the righteous purge the world of vile rats in various forms – armored rats, big rats, even bigger rats, sneaky rats, ratatat-rats, and the foul stench of stinky rats! As if the minions of the Horned Rat were not enough, chaos and beastmen emerge, their malevolent forces adding further torment to this perilous journey.

Yet, take heed! Though you may not embody the rat in this sacred digital crusade, you are blessed with the opportunity to embody noble warriors of diverse statures. 

Rejoice, for the community that gathers in this digital realm is largely benevolent, ready to extend a hand of aid on your treacherous pilgrimage. Alas, occasionally, amidst the harmonious camaraderie, you may encounter a nerd or two – their labored breaths and questionable remarks may assail your ears and insult thy kin. Fear not, for in the name of Sigmar, thou canst forsake these heretical Gamers and seek refuge in the embrace of a more virtuous gathering.

Marvel at the accessible entry point of this sacred endeavor, a low skill floor inviting all who wish to vanquish rats with shoot-smash-singe-stab fervor. Yet, as you ascend the ladder of proficiency and equipment mastery, a high skill ceiling awaits, challenging thee to become a paragon of rat-slaying efficiency.

Adjust thy trials, noble warriors, for there exist various difficulty levels to suit thy preference – control the rate at which rats meet their demise or the severity of thy own trials. As you march forward, consecrate your chosen warrior with the sacred rites of experience, unlocking divine equipment to tailor your righteous playstyle and strike the rats with even greater ferocity.

In this sacred congregation, be excellent unto each other, converse with your comrades in pure umgak, revel in the joy of fellowship, and above all, my brethren, revel in the sublime ecstasy of rat-slaying. May Sigmar guide thy hand as you embark on this digital pilgrimage!

[h2]Good Game - 7/10[/h2]



[b]The Good parts:[/b]
[list]
[*]Great combat, lots of weapons and classes.
[*]Good co-op, you can also solo all the game if you want.
[*]Good enough main campaign to play trough.
[*]Lots of maps to play.
[*]Chaos Wastes Mode is fantastic, has lots of replay-ability, loots of fun with randoms or friends.
[/list]

[b]The Bad parts:[/b]
[list]
[*]Horrible loot system, the classic chest loot roulette, very annoying and tedious.
[*]Weapons level up system is bad once you get to orange, sometimes even blue, its pointless to upgrade.
[*]Mediocre bot AI, just learn how to solo it or find some good friends.
[*]"Premium content", DLC, microtransanctions or whatever you wanna call it, its just mediocre.
[/list]

[b]Final Thoughts.[/b]
Great at parts, mediocre at others. The dialogue is entertaining, the weapons are fun as hell and the enemies are always fun to kill, the bad thing its all the modern gaming aspects like the loot system that sucks b**t.

Difficulty is between Hardcore and Casual, its leans a bit towards Hardcore (especially if you solo it) but never to much since controls are extremely simple and easy to learn.

I love a lot about this game, but I find it difficult to recommend. Got up to the higher difficulties and the game sure does become unforgiving, but for the wrong reasons. Enemy reach has always been a bit ridiculous, and the worst combination of enemies get thrown at you with no lube, repeatedly. Unless you're using the OP DLC career fields then good luck. 

To date, can't decide if A.I or actual players are worse teammates. 

And re-mentioning the DLC careers, I know the end times have basically oofed up warhammer fantasy and creative assembly, fatshark and others have basically been given carte blanche on doing whatever the hell they want but none of the background for the DLC careers sit right with me. Kruber is just a Holy Knight Boy now, Bardin magically becomes a master steamwork engineer, Saltzpyre is a Paladin now which may suit his zealotry but not his actions & Kerillian, oh my girl Kerillian - she's barely even alive at this point and it just breaks my heart after all the little bits and pieces of development of her getting closer to these "mayflies" and opening up to the world just to become a fucking tree-person that refers to people as "meat". 


I don't want to end this on a bad note

- Each career and weapons for them do have a great unique, but still balanced feel to them, even my least favorite ones out of the stacks. 
- The maps are stunning and I just catch myself looking around the map even 5 years after it's been released
- the recent free content updates are pretty good if challenging in their own ways, though I am hoping for more on the Dwarf series because it did feel just a tad short
- Dialogue between all of the non-DLC characters makes this game. My friends and I quote Saltzpyre and Bardin extensively when playing other games

This game is incredibly fun when it doesn't pull anything stupid. Problem is - there's a lot of stupid stuff by design, not coding problems or bugs, although there's plenty of that as well. But it's more efficient to name the things that are bad and in my opinion need to be changed for this game to be enjoyably good. (I have every character on lvl. 35, full red gear and usually play on legend)

 - Blightstormers need to either teleport more often, have their range decreased or be required to have line of sight to the blightstorm. Right now a fun run can end in a blightstormer that cast it's tornade from so far away you can't even tag them and everybody dies.

 - dedicated servers were promised before the game came out, it didn't happen, it sucks but that's fine. But The host disconnecting right at the end of a mission not even giving you the XP you would've gained if the mission failed, that rips out a piece of my soul every time i see the "Taal's Horn Keep" loadingscreen after wasting 20 minutes.

 - in quickplay you can get a team of 3 melee only characters which means you are going to die to the first occasion where there's more than 2 specials at the same time, especially if it's ranged specials. Now, i'm not saying it's impossible to complete a mission with 3 melee only classes, even on legend and above, but that requires coordination which random people playing quickplay don't have.

 - the netcode to this game sometimes feels more jank than Dead by Daylight's. Sometimes this game just... breaks. It's not your ping, not the hosts ping, not your PC failing or steam servers or anything else, it's just the game getting confused so that enemies skip animations, phase in and out of existence, slide around and teleport behind you with fully charged heavy attacks. sometimes enemies hit you right through your block or hit the spot you used to be in one second ago before you dodged, but hitting you.

Mkay that was my little rant after all this happening in a single game. I have vented enough now and am going back to playing.

Really only play this with friends and when twitch mode is enabled since base game can get pretty boring as Fatshark works on updates every 3 years. and adding maps  for some reason takes an ungodly amount of time for Fatshark to make. just now we got over three NEW maps( regurgitated maps are not new). 

Weaves were a bust, nobody asked for leaderboards. 

- no deed rework

Update: game crashes galore and no incentives for veterans. Fatshark does not listen to the community but of a select few.

Where are the deeds reworks?

Why do Cataclysm mission challenges provide commendation chests but not emperor chests?

Why are we focused more on the "balance" of the game when content like maps and cosmetics are what we really only want.

Fatshark is drip feeding content for Vermintide, new players get double xp, veterans get a thank you and a fuck off.

Also then there is the ability to buy cosmetics.... well i hope you like to penny pinch because FS is not happy about giving you currency to buy cosmetics. If you think about how much a new hat that they release which is about roughly 1980 shillings. you get 3 daily quests that amount to 5 shillings per quest. Then on top of that you get 5 weekly challenges that give you 50 shillings each... you do the math.

There are absolutely no incentives for veterans, now there doesn't need to be to have fun per se, but I would like to see the fruits of my labor when accomplishing a hard challenge but in the end still get just a commendation chest so the incentive falls flat and becomes a very boring a menial task to complete these challenges.


TLDR: 

FS does not care for veterans but if your a new player then you will have fun.
And make sure to grab a friend to play with.

Very fun game even better when you're grouped with players who know how to coordinate together and share loot.
The characters don't STFU, even when you have actual people instead of NPCs. It's nauseating.

Progression system kills it. Which difficulty you can play depends on how powerful you are, and your power is mostly dictated by an arbitrary number attached to gear, and how high that number can go depends on how high a level your character is
So rarity of weapons is dependant on the character, and which weapons you get is random from lootboxes, until you level up enough to get blueprints. At which point if you want to get a weapon you want, you need to scrap all the fucking junk of identical weapons you have to get the materials to craft it
Repeat each time you start playing a new character

And the easiset difficulty is just a braindead mashfest, both teaching you as a new player "Yup, this is a fine way to play", and making all the weapon stats completely superfluous.

So the weapons, then. Yet again, lootboxes, or grind to get blueprints to craft them (crafting sucks too, but we'll get there). Instead of having every weapon type available at the start, you first got to get it, and annoyingly enough, could be several games before you get something you like, and then it might not be the best in arbitrary numbers or other bonuses.
So as you progress, you're having to scrap all these other items that are almost identical, save for an arbitrary number and some other random bonuses, then craft and/or reroll the bonuses on the weapons you like. 

The bonuses, while they probably make a difference at higher difficulties, is hard to even notice, because it's stuff like "+8% damage against Skaven". Again, you're not gonna notice it on lower difficulties because it's not gonna make a difference, and even when it might start making a difference, you're really not gonna see it, unless maybe you go look up the health numbers on the enemies and do the math, or the bonuses become more significant later.

Then there's tons of other minor stuff that annoys me. Can't hear lots of enemies when they're right next to you, so constantly get hit from behind. Similarly can't hear teammates, so I don't know when they've fucked off unless of course they actively tell me, and they're really hard to see as soon as they're like 10 meters away from you, because they become tiny and blend into the environment (which happens often, because the levels are huge and open), it's actually easier to see them when they're behind a wall because then at least they get an outline (this is never a problem in L4D2, for example, because even if you're playing without outlines, the player characters stick out). Voicelines can get very repetative and annoying, when they're the kind that are long and not generic (the amount of times I heard "It's nothing, just a bit of skill, reflexes!"), and when I'm attacking with Melee using Markus, all I can hear is "Hua! Hu! Die! Die, would ya! Hua! Hu! Die! Die, would ya!". It all piles up to make for a frustrating experience.

i am a  warhammer fan, have been for a long time, but i write this with mixed feelings. it is a good game as far as fps warhammer games go, but the thing is- there aren't  many out there. ahhh, gone are the days of space marine, but lest we lament. there is a curse with warhammer video games, and that is they either suck,  get boring quick,  fall apart due to mismanagement, or like this game, DOW3, and others-  they are never truly fully realized, then flounder in utter mediocrity. there could of been more- more: careers, weapons, armor, cosmetics, enemies, maps, etc. But, there isn't. there could of been  a cooler home base area with better crafting, but there isn't. the ideas which make up this game seem less like a well thought out plan and more like shotgunned whiteboard diarrhea. And although I do play this game, it is a love-hate thing. when will game developers stop making cash grab games and start making masterpieces? you could theoretically make a fps game for every faction, whether it is in the warhammer fantasy or 40k world, and put it in one game for each universe.  a comprehensive game instead of a  narrowly interpreted and  ridiculously executed stop gap blunder.

Update- new careers should of been FREE. The Weave- wtf is that? Chaos Wastes- what a waste. Grudge marked bosses- give me a break. How about focusing on more 'regular' maps, with free updates to careers and equipment, and added races (both to play as and as enemies).

As far as the issues go there are a few glaring ones which just make the game stupid. First, dodging a Chaos Warrior who is attacking with two handed ax does not matter because he will slide to wherever you are even if it is like twenty feet away then swing downward hitting the ground, physically clearly missing, but will take you down. Second, the bunching up and clipping of an enemy elite mob who will all occupy the same physical space and hit you sequentially, rendering blocking ineffective in a couple of seconds. Third, the feeling you have no armor on whatsoever and the mega damage you take from weak mob members and their pointy wood sticks. Fourth, the weirdly unsettling character modeling especially some of the faces-yikes, uglier than the enemy. Fifth- the abundance of stupid cosmetics with only a few nice ones. I so wish this was a better game. Even Darktide with its issues is a way better game that also has a way to go but not as far as this one. It has run its course and has seen its sunset many moons ago. Third time is the charm as they say...

So keep your expectations low and you surely will not be disappointed.
Great game, even after hundreds of hours I am not tired of it.

I used to love this game, but it was bought as a one with Windows 7 support, which is no more after the introduction of DLSS in the Necromancer update. First of all, dropping support of Win 7 - 8.1 because of a minor optional graphics feature is insanity, but the nature of the problem makes this even worse.

All comes down to the sl.interposer.dll, which calls the SetThreadDescription function from kernel32.dll. This function is missing on all Windows versions prior to Win 10 ver. 1607 (the same and still unsolved issue preventing the start of the game on older versions of Windows 10) and used solely for debugging purposes, so it is possible to just remove that function call from a binary without side effects... only to be stopped by Easy Anti-Cheat from launching the game because files became modified.

It wouldn't take much effort to check OS version before trying to load DLSS libraries (or patch the sl.interposer.dll), if only devs cared about compatibility. Obviously they don't, and the anti-cheat is preventing me from fixing the game for myself, so screw it.

It's a good left 4 dead variant/clone but more melee focused and with a progression system. There's a set cast of playable characters that are unique and varied in personality, however during missions they get a bit too talkative for my taste. As for the dlc's... there are campaign dlc's which are nice and add variety, and with the later added free bonus campaigns there's not a lot to get bored of. But the character payable careers though not "pay2win" are more "pay2havefun", and that's not talking about additional strong weapons that come with them. Another problem with that content is that one dlc will add a generally unlikeable arce of enemies to fight during missions. Ultimately I like, but you get what you pay for, and you need to pay more to get a lot of the experience.

Changing this from a favorable review for the past several years to a negative one.  

The core game is an absolute blast and ~5 years or so of polish in the game has made a fairly satisfying in game experience.  If you enjoy hack and slash, L4D style games set in a grimdark fantasy world, this game is highly likely for you.

Unfortunately, and I don't do this lightly, Fatshark's propensity to make knee jerk changes w/o extensive testing (or what can only be described such considering their decisions), catering to a vocal minority on balance changes has worn me down to the point that I am fast losing my interest in this game.

This review is less about the current state of the game and new players who may just be signing on and haven't experienced the past several years of patching, fine tuning, tinkering, etc, but more for people who may want to get into this for the long haul.  Don't.  

If you need a cheap game on sale and haven't had to endure or don't plan to play this for the long haul, the game is fast, fun, try yard, sweaty goodness, but if you're looking for measured, reasonable changes this late into the game life where, more and more, the changes that are made are going to be or close to the final take on class and gear balance from devs who appear to cater to vocal minorities and ill conceived changes, you may find yourself frustrated at the direction FS takes with the game.

Like I said, I don't change my review lightly and I have seen so many changes in the ~4 years and over 8k hrs I've played this game so, while my decision is heavily influenced by the most recent changes, it's also the how and what they've done and the direction they've taken over the long haul and past several years, not just the most recent things that have completely turned me off.  

If you are new, you may not care or have any reference point so, in that case, this very may well be for you.

Ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls, and everyone in between or beyond, gather 'round for the most **earth-shattering**, **mind-boggling**, and **knee-slapping** review of **Warhammer Vermintide 2** that the internet has ever had the misfortune of hosting.

Firstly, let's talk graphics. They're so good, they'll make your grandma's old CRT TV weep pixels of joy. The level of detail is so intense that I could see the existential dread in a Skaven's eyes as I lopped its head off. It's like the developers took the concept of HD and cranked it up to "Is this real life or am I hallucinating?"

Gameplay? Imagine if your favorite carnival ride and a mosh pit had a baby, and that baby was on fire. That's Vermintide 2. You'll be swinging swords, dodging claws, and dropping witty one-liners like you were born in the Renaissance but raised in a meme factory.

The characters are so quirky, they make the cast of Friends look like cardboard cutouts. We've got a dwarf who's more beard than man, an elf who's 90% sass and 10% arrows, a soldier who's seen some stuff but mostly just sees red, and a wizard who's about as stable as your internet connection on a stormy day.

But wait, there's more! This game will take you on an emotional journey akin to watching a soap opera while riding a rollercoaster. One second you're cackling like a witch on Halloween, and the next you're sobbing into your keyboard because, darn it, these characters have grown on you like that mold in the back of your fridge.

In short, Warhammer Vermintide 2 is the digital equivalent of a fever dream you never want to wake up from. It's the kind of game that makes you question reality, your life choices, and why you can't seem to stop playing. If memes were a currency, this game would be the central bank. 11/10, would meme again.
