It seems to me the devs are completely out of touch with its player base and has no clue of what game they have made. They tried to run these free weeks or whatever they are called but for long time players there is absolutely no reason to be excited over the game other than self found satisfaction from the existing content. The Halloween events are really fun but instead of releasing more themed events they just slap on a free week and tweet about it. Most people install the game over the free weeks just delete the game after a few games. Instead they could produce meaningful content and I am sure people will pay for it. 

Things such as free DLCs are just one additional map and its free because they know they can't sell for peanuts. This brings on to DLCs such as Sienna. It took almost two years for it to come out compared to half a year for other career DLCs. There has also been no communication from fatshark in its usual style and coupled with no meaningful content releases are the reasons that many of the players have quit as they moved on to Darktide and realised its even worse than the state of Vermintide 2. The devs tried to balance out the release of Darktide and Sienna DLC ultimately didn't work out and we are now left with a half baked game that no one really plays and killing off their most popular game at the same time.

Hate to say that the game seems like it won't have any growth potential anymore after Sienna DLC as we can tell from fatshark's emails that they are constantly working on Darktide to revive it somehow xd. I'm glad for the people that has quit so they don't have to see the immensely skill inflated coru staff Sienna players now spawning in dead skeletons to fight as if they're playing BTD5 then telling everyone they have the highest damage in the official discord server. Not to even mention that it took fatshark months to address the flame walk bug that kills patrol in seconds. The game is fun but the devs simply does not know how to maintain their playerbase.

This game offers one of the best co-op combat experiences out there. The Warhammer aesthetic and the heroes didn't appeal to me at first - I only liked the wood elf because she evoked Lord of the Rings, so that was my gateway to trying this game out - but the devs did create a convincing world that's faithful to a beloved tabletop and multimedia fiction universe. 

You come to Vermintide for the combat, and the combat is good. That's really what you need to know. The skill floor is very low. Recruit and veteran difficulty are very approachable for casual players. The skill ceiling is VERY HIGH. You are almost playing a different game each time you step up in difficulty. Suddenly you have to pay attention to your dodge, your positioning, audio cues for spawns, timed blocks and parries, pushes and stagger, and sticking with your team.

A tide of individually un-threatening enemies and a steady drip of disablers, elites, and bosses keeps you on your toes and makes for a really rewarding co-op experience. 
The depth of combat/movement mechanics allows for a ton of skill progression if you care for the more challenging modes. 

Bonus points: There are a ton of different weapons, and they actually FEEL different. Even between several types of swords, they each have different strike patterns for heavy and light attacks and different strengths and weaknesses. Combined with the trait tree changing your "career skill" or ults and the different passives on each hero, you have a lot of variety in playstyle. Ranged, melee, and spellcasting alike.

Now for the negatives. Vermintide 2 is generally stable, but does have issues with crashing that seem unrelated to hardware specs (players who can run the latest and greatest without issue may face crashes here). I eventually figured out updating my BIOS and tweaking graphics settings could keep it stable. It's really demanding on your CPU.
The online co-op uses peer-to-peer (P2P) networking (not sure w/ or w/o relay servers). So this game works better if you have a reliable internet connection. Every once in a while, a host will simply close their game, leaving you in the lurch. Overall, I get good technical performance with occasional really annoying hiccups. Compared to other P2P games, this one's actually on the stronger, more reliable side, for what it's worth.

Rat Genocide Simulator. Great game. My Saltzpyre has recently hit level 35 +1000, so im finally ready for cata. clap clap clap clap
Everyone should play this game. Unless you intend to use Saltzpyre. Then i say, there's not enough room in the End Times for the two of us.

But in all seriousness. Its a very good game, with a wonderfully deep combat system, thanks to all the animation interrupts and movement tech mixed sneakily in the game. While likely unnecessary if youre good enough, they most definitely help amp up the ratcorpses per second. And faster feeling game = more dopamine. 
The Ai Director and all the mobs have 2 modes. Normal and Rude. Rats finding interdimensional ways to get behind you this round? Rude. Hookrat outfootsied you? Rude. Assassin methodically made his way behind a Monster and pounced you through him? Rude. Leech grabbed you while on the blight merry-go-round? Rude. First thing a Black Rat did was push you off a high place to your death? Rude. Two Blight Stormers? Rude. Enemies on Ice the Disney Musical? Rude. Patrol spawned right in your face? Rude. 400 Beastman Archers? Rude. Chaos Wastes Monster immune to Ranged Damage AGAIN? Rude. What you thought was a chaos jobber suddenly has two axes? Rude. You didnt stagger that guy cus he was still on the tail end of his climbing/dropping animation and got whacked? Well that one's on you. Assassin is stalking about and you have a heart attack only to realize that was actually a dwarf highlighted in a green outline and you just accidentally broke his jaw with your bullets? Im sorry.

But the moral of the story is to git gud, ain't it? That's why you get all this secret combat tech. To be rude back. All in all, the game is fun, and even more fun when you start dishing out as much as the game throws at you. Ive played too long to conjure up an actually coherent reason to play the game, so just know that there's alot and you should go do it. I leave you with this.

I played Vermintide 1, this one is an improvement, but not much. At least for me, this marks the endpoint in the road of Vermintide games and Fatshark. 
Gameplay is like I'm used to from the first part: hack, slash, block, push, dodge, nothing too fancy, but fun. Levels are okay, they look nice, but you can't really explore or check everything out, since there will be hordes so you can't really admire stuff. 
Combat is fun in general, sometimes the hit detection seems a bit off, but i can't say for sure without seeing hitboxes and taking a closer look.
Some of the better weapons are locked behind dlc, which is something I strongly dislike, and the armors you get on legend difficulty look like the base armors, only a different colour or with more gold applications, which is sad. Also many outfits don't match the helmets, colour-wise. The system is okay-ish, but i've seen better in other games.
As for equipment and progression, it is a bit slow at the start, but gets better later (although still sluggish), until you reach max power, still not as satisfying as I'd like, but still okay, I could work with that.

What personally bugged me the most is the tooltips. Sometimes it takes a google search to find out what a weapon or skill can do, since the tooltip won't explain anything, and sometimes the tooltips are just incorrect. This game ain't exactly brand new, and it still seems to be a problem. 

If you can get it on a sale, you might consider it, if you got one or two friends to play with.
Droprates for red items (rarest stuff) are decent enough, not too rare, not too common. 
But the game has a definitve endpoint when you got most of the stuff you want/need so the playtime (at least for me) is limited. 
The bots act as stupid as in the first Vermintide. I know this is an "online game" and meant to be played with friends, but you need a mod to make the bots play even half decent. And as for random online play, maybe i was just unlucky but in an average of 6/10 games in quickplay you get either (depending on difficulty) 
a) players that don't know how to block, dodge, or both 
b) players that flame you for not having all red items and at the same time say it's all about skill. or 
c) players that gulp down healing items while either having more than 50% hp or the natural bond effect so that its effectively wasted. 

[u] Tl,dr: Fun game for a limited amount of time, get at sale but avoid some of the dlcs. I'm glad i bought and tried it, but ultimately, I wouldn't recommend it. Last game I'll buy from this developer - no hard feelings, other people may like their work, but me and my friends felt a bit disappointed. [/u]

While they are definitely similar, Vermintide is much more involved than the likes of Left 4 Dead. The large focus of this game is on melee combat. There are ranged weapons and you can build your character around them, but when it comes to swinging swords and tearing your opponents apart, Vermintide II, and its predecessor, are best in class. I have more time in this on PS4 than I do here, mainly because Darktide, the spiritual successor, came out shortly after my purchasing this on PC. Plus, it was on sale for the ridiculously awesome price of 5.99. Considering the amount of content on offer here, I'd say that's a friggen steal.

[h1]Bad Left 4 Dead clone[/h1]

[b]TL;DR[/b]

[b]Very repetitive:[/b] run from point A to point B, killing the same waves of enemies over and over again.

[list]
[*][b]Bad movement:[/b] You move slowly, there is no sprint, and you can jump only over small obstacles.

[*][b]Bad melee combat:[/b] It is unsatisfying, much worse, and more primitive than in Dishonored or Killing Floor's 2 Berserker perk.

[*][b]Bad shooting combat:[/b] Guns are primitive in handling, like in mobile games; they don't require skills like recoil control, etc. You can't even aim with most guns.

[*][b]Repetitive combat:[/b] Spamming the left mouse button until you out-melee hordes of enemies.

[*][b]Bad classes:[/b] Instead of like in KF2 or PD2, where every perk is unique, here all classes have the same weapons: one melee weapon (often sword-like) and one firearm (often shotgun-like). The classes feel too similar and are boring to play with after a few rounds.

[*][b]Bad enemies:[/b] Instead of, like in KF2, L4D2 or PD2 where you had different enemy classes that required different approaches to kill them, here you even kill elite enemies the same repetitive way: Just spam the left mouse button. 

[*][b]Very grind heavy:[/b] The whole point of finishing missions and 'vacuum cleaning' the levels is about getting lootboxes with a higher chance of good-quality gear and weapons, that turn out to give you 1% more damage or accuracy.

[*][b]Bad stimulus of playing the game:[/b] In KF2 or PD2, you replay the same level dozens of times  as the combat is wonderful, and you enjoy the different gameplay tactics. Here, the gameplay feels like an unsatisfying but necessary side job barrier for the sake of the main part: grinding the player's progression and collecting loot boxes.

[*][b]Microtransactions:[/b] After 5 years, I returned to the game, and the only thing I noticed in the game were [strike]gameplay improvements[/strike] tons of paid DLCs, microtransactions, and in-game shops the developers added.
[/list]

So, there are good and bad aspects to this game.  Let's start with the good.

It's a fantasy horde FPS melee/shooter.  You get to kill hordes and hordes of Skaven (rats) and Norsca (basically Vikings) savages.  There are five characters with three base classes (careers) and one extra paid DLC class for each character.  The fifteen base classes are more than enough to have fun with though.  Each is very distinct with different weapons, tools/abilities, and play styles.

Once you've found a class, weapons, and a talent spec that you enjoy, there's a crazy amount of variety in the game with the maps available (with some good art design and lots of Warhammer Fantasy stuff to look at), and the number and composition of enemy forces you'll fight along the way.  

Add in a few friends for the four player co-op, and, as far as horde shooters go, it's a hell of a lot of fun.

Now the bad.

The loot system in the game is abusive and actively makes the game and the community worse.  When you beat a map, you get a loot chest generated based on your performance during the map.  If you die, you essentially get nothing (beyond some XP which will, eventually, get you a "commendation" chest which basically just gets you junk you can shard for crafting materials).  You can get higher quality chests by gathering items on the map that will make it even harder for you to complete the map successfully (by taking up healing item slots and by lowering your health).

When you do complete maps successfully, and go to open your loot chests, the game rolls to find out what kind of loot you'll get.  The most important stat on your items is the power level.  This stat ranges from 5 to 300.  When the roll is done, the game picks a power level that is in the range of -10 to +5 of the highest power level item you've received previously (whether that item is equipped or not, or whether it has been sharded for crafting materials or not).  If you want to play this game at high levels, you want to get all of your items up to 300 as soon as possible, but this system is designed to draw out that grind as long as possible.  It will be dozens of hours of play before you're getting level 300 items out of chests.  Items also have a rarity system (the color of the item, white, green, blue, orange, red) that determines the secondary stats that appear on items beyond the power level.  Red (veteran) items are always level 300 and have secondary stats guaranteed to be at their max values (e.g., some items can have +crit chance from +3-5%.  A red will always be +5% whereas items at lower quality levels will have that value in the range of 3-5%.  You could have an orange that's just the base +3%).

If you are playing this game at high levels, Legendary or Cataclysm, there is IMMENSE pressure to make sure that you are playing your class with certain talents, with gear that is all at power 300, and with stats that are max, or close to max, and are min/max'ed the right way.  As it is a team game, you are also at the mercy of your teammates and how they choose to play the game.  If they choose not to stick together, or go for the same objectives you are (for instance, getting the books that give you better loot chests at the end), you can have a bad experience.

Because this game is such high difficulty and so ruthless on gear and how you play the game, the player community has an astounding level of toxicity.  In just this weekend, I've encountered multiple TK'ers, people shouting racist slurs into voice chat, and multiple lobby leaders rage quitting and causing all progress to be lost on the map.  Do you enjoy playing through 30 minutes of a map at high difficulty for a chance at getting loot only to have the lobby leader (it's a P2P game and there are no dedicated servers) rage quit at the last minute and end the map?  I know I do!

Oh, speaking of which, let's say you've finally managed to find a good talent spec, decent items, and a decent team, and you've managed to beat some maps on Legend difficulty with a full book run so you can get the best possible chest with the best chance of getting red items!  Congratulations!  Even if you've done a "full book" run, you *still* need a large amount of luck to go from a "Generals" vault to an "Emperors" vault.  The General has a less than 10% chance of giving you a red.  The Emperor has a less than 20% chance of giving you a red.  Even if you've made the map as difficult as possible with the "full books", you still need luck to go from a General to an Emperor.  And then you still have more RNG to hope to get a red item.  In practice, I feel like my red drop rate is probably half of what I've seen online.

Oh, and when the game is actually running through its RNG to determine what quality of loot chest it's going to give you and what loot it generates when you open that chest, it forces you to watch gambling machine style flashing lights and animations straight out of casino gambling machines.

If you can play this game at lower levels (stay on Veteran or Champion difficulty) and not get caught up in the loot grind, you can probably have more fun with it than I do.

If you are the type to get stuck chasing loot and want to min/max your characters and their items and specs, you are in for a world of pain with very difficult / high skill ceiling game play, and one of the most elitist and toxic game communities I've ever played with.

And the devs are totally ok with all of this.  This is their vision.  Poopy loot grind, toxic players, and everything.

Oh, and that player community?  It's a mostly dead game.  Take a look at the player stats.  Most days have a peak of under 5K players.  https://steamdb.info/app/552500/charts/

I've still poured over 500 hours into this game.  I wish I hadn't.  Unfortunately, I *am* the type to get sucked into the loot grind and min/maxing my characters.  And I *do* enjoy the core game play of horde shooters and killing hundreds of enemies.  I just wish this game didn't have the super toxic player base and the awful loot grind.

Honestly, buy Deep Rock Galactic instead.  You can have the same 4 player co-op PvE experience, with a player base that is so much more positive, and the game doesn't have the abusive loot box system and incentive to min/max everything.  Easily 3-5x the player count at any time.  Even more variety on missions.  And a player base that is incredibly positive and helpful.  I've encountered more toxic teammates on Vermintide 2 *this weekend* than I have in the last four years of playing Deep Rock.  Buy and play that instead.

You know I think it's safe to say that I have a thing for post-apocalyptic campaign games. Of course it's not the ONLY genre I can appreciate but outside of Minecraft there is no other genre or game I have invested so much time and love into than Warhammer: Vermintide 2, taking the blueprint from other legendary titles and enhancing it and sticking with it through these five unforgettable years.

The characters are all slam-dunks with personalities and insights that do an incredible job of immersing you in their universe, while also not shoving it aggressively down your throat like they did in other games (Darktide). I for one find it really easy to connect with Markus Kruber who is by far my favorite character in the entire Warhammer universe.

The combat, while not perfect, for all intents and purposes is satisfying, skillful and rewarding, I for one lean towards melee combat but neither range or melee is below average on impact.

The evolution and progression of you as a player is paced pretty well. It took me over 1000hrs to get semi-comfortable with LEGEND difficulty. Another 2000 to get comfortable at CATACLYSM. And if that's not gonna keep you occupied for long, you still have 19 other play-styles you can learn and master to extend the lifespan of your experience for much, much longer. Oh yeah and there's like a bunch of different game-modes you can also mess around with- SPEAKING OF.

While not all updates are created equal, the massive Chaos Wastes update was a perfectly immersed secondary game-mode that provides a fresh and unique journey towards a climactic and triumphant finale. But it still keeps the traditional elements of game-play to keep you hooked!

The enemies are pretty balanced, the maps are breathtaking and fun, the crafting system... exists... which I would say is not really something you'd expect to just be delayed a bunch. Like come on Darktide get it together, you're supposed to be BETTER than V2 right?

There was a time when things looked bleak. Back when I had around 1300hrs, this game went through what I can only ironically call the Dark age of Vermintide's existence. No updates, bugs, crashes, lag, it got bad for a while. But to Fatshark's undying credit, they have stuck with this game and poured their heart and soul into this game even recently so. New maps, new careers, new items. I don't know what comes next for Vermintide, but you can sure as hell count me in for when it arrives.

Five thousand hours is just around the corner. It's hard to even think about that number. But it's coming. And I'll admit, as far as "lifespans" go, I might be closer to the end than the beginning. It's not a thought that I relish. But I will continue to play this game and love this game. I love Vermintide 2. And clearly a lot of other people do too. So thank you Fatshark for such an amazing game.

Overall, you'll have fun with this game.  The baseline game provides enough challenge to not be boring, so you don't have to get any DLC.  If you do, there's lots of fun non-cosmetic stuff to get, just know that the difficulty of some of the DLC levels is extremely difficult compared to the base game levels, especially Karak Azgaraz and the Winds of Magic DLC.  If you like having casual fun, you can just play the baseline game and get the DLC characters.  If you want a challenge, find your threshold with the baseline game and add expansions as needed.

Massive upgrade from the first with multiple classes and skill trees, far more weapon varieties, map types, etc. There are story maps with variations to paths or enemy variety each play. The Chaos Wastes expeditions are a set of randomized maps where you collect loot, upgrades and curses, all themed around a table top where you choose between branching paths as a group. It has been a lot of fun following the game's updates over it's development. 
Having said all that, the paid DLC classes are far stronger than the non-paid classes and updates have been s l o w. They've released an entirely new game in this same style before finishing the additional classes that they began in 2020.

A great game that was, for me, ruined by too many selfish players.

You are always in four-person teams rushing headlong into swarms of opponents on 15 minute long missions. Teammates can sometimes start as bots but usually humans take over. (You can also choose to play with all bots ... which was tempting!).

The combat mechanisms are great and I love how the different melee actions and weapon choices/upgrades work.

The BIG problem for me is that you'll often have someone toxic in your team. They can literally bump you out of the mission and back to the start screen, shoot you to death, or simply abandon you so that you spend a lot of the game being beaten-up and left captive (unable to do anything until rescued). They are the people who call new players "ret**d idiots" etc.

Also, a player doesn't have to be that toxic to spoil your fun a bit. Players who want to always get all the best items are incentivised by the game's mechanism to rush off and leave you, searching for hidden grimoires etc. Sure, you can try and keep up with them. But do you really want to spend each game sprinting 200 yards behind a powergamer working hard to keep up? To them, that's the game and you are stupid noob if you don't get that! To me, I just wanted a cool dungeon-crawler with teamwork.

There's so much to love in this game and a lot of the community are awesome. And I'm giving the game a thumbs up because, if you're less thin-skinned than me, it could be perfect for you. But I sadly uninstalled it.

Warhammer Vermintide 2 is fun because it is difficult.

The Vermin's, Northlanders and Beastmen are plentiful and dangerous. The mechanics are easy to learn but hard to master, which make for a fine recepe for the ambitious exterminator and Sigmar worshipper.

Despite being a mostly melee game, there are a lot of playstyles which enable you to experiment with different builds and abilities.

The characters and their interactions enrich the game world and the playing experience by setting the mood of a bickering group of eccentrics that fight through the impossibilities of the End Times.

You have Markus Kruber a mercenary who's your average Joe for a Warhammer character, Victor Saltzpyre a stirn and abrasive witch hunter, Bardin Goreksson with the personality of Gimli from LOTR, Kerillian a Wood Elf with a heart of lead and Sienna Fuegonasus who is on fire, literally.

Each character has multiple careers or subclasses to choose from. Each career has its own mostly unique skills and a unique ultimate ability which synergizes well with different weapons and traits. You can turn Bardin in to a stun-monster, a tank, a Slayer who jumps half naked into every patrol they can reach or give him a mini-gun which regenerates ammo by giving it the old crank.

There are a lot of different missions which mostly last 15-30 minutes depending on the difficulty level and with the free edition of the chaos wastes even a completely new game mode.

While on a mission your primary concern next to the main objective in form of a "go there and do something" mission type, is to not die by dodging, blocking and preemtively killing enemies. After you inevitably take some damage, you can heal yourself with very limited healing potions or bandages or generate temporary health by stunning, cleaving, critting or simply by killing more enemies which lets you seek out the danger, which is good, because there can be a lot of it. When a horde, a patrol, special ememies, a boss or a combination of these comes for your team, you should pick a place to hold. Thus begins the fight for your wiggle room, because the only situation where your death is assured, is when your guard gets broken, you can't dodge anymore, and your ultimate is on cooldown. This makes for an exquisite challenge because you and your team are powerful but you can also lose if you allow the enemies to corner you.

There is a unique thrill in being the last man standing and being able to clutch.

7/10 if you dont enjoy playing on higher difficulties or grinding for XP, [b]10/10 otherwise[/b]

[h1][b][u]Keynote:[/u][/b][/h1]
Dont go in expecting a single player campaign with story with a plot.
The plot is entirely missing as you fight simply to survive in the end times rather than to save humanity. You wont be getting any kind of closure with the campaign except for fighting bosses. However, the voice acting is amazing and the character interactions are very well-written.

[h1][b][u]Gameplay Summary[/u][/b][/h1]

[list]
[*] Plays like Left for Dead and Darksouls combined. Slash, block, dodge and push your way through hordes of enemies. Clench your butthole when a boss spawns with specials during a horde.
[*] Dodges dont make you invincible, you have to physically move out of an attacks way.
[*] Play as 1 of 5 characters with a choice of 3 Careers (Talent trees) for each character.
[*] Choose from a variety of weapons. Each weapon has different Stamina points and properties (armour penetration, stagger strength).
[*] Its a common misconception that you will be spamming attacks to clear hordes, which is only true for a few weapons. Each weapon has a moveset of its own. You'll have to alternate between Light and heavy attacks to create your own moveset. Movesets and combos differ between weapons. For example: Using a heavy attack after using push attack will result in Heavy 2, not Heavy 1. This ensures that you dont resort to button mashing.
[/list]

[table]
[tr]
	[th][h1]Pros[/h1][/th]
	[th][h1]Cons[/h1][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]	1. Large variety of weapons and careers to choose from

	2. Weapons combos differ from weapon to weapon, ensuring that players dont resort to mere button mashing 

	3. Characters interactions are pure gold and are the primary way of narrating the lore of the game. Characters races and backgrounds are well picked, It's fun watching the Witch hunter berate the Witch or to see the Elf doing the same to everyone else.

	4. For those with a penchant for roguelike elements, Chaos wastes is an excellant game mode where you have to make do with whichever weapons and boons you happen to come across.

	5. Fun with friends

	6. Mods are fully supported

	7. DLC maps are playable for everyone if the Host owns the DLC.

	8. Devs listen to the community. It should be noted that the [b]Devs added an exploit back to the game simply to reduce the grind for Red items[/b][/td]

[td]1. Save files are server tied despite the game using P2P connections. Game cannot be played online and will become unplayable when the servers are inevitably shut down.

2. May be too hard for your taste and boring when you play on easier difficulties

3. Lack of story may be offputting for some players although the dialogue more than makes up for it. 

4. Bot levels are based on the levels of your characters. This may be a problem if you only play a single character and start playing on higher difficulties with Level 1 bots.

5. Cataclysm difficulty is locked behind a paywall (Winds of Magic DLC). In my opinion, its bad practice to lock non-content based gameplay behind paywalls. Winds of Magic DLC deservedly has a low rating on the marketplace. I bought it anyway since I enjoy the base game a lot and need to play it on the highest difficulty.

6. Game does a bad job at explaining its mechanics and providing important info in general. Each type of attack of any weapon has modifiers. For Example, L3(Light Attack 3) of Sword and Dagger has amazing Armour penetration but the game does not tell you so. [b]Luckily, you can add a mod to gain access to such info within the game itself.
[/b][/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1][b][u]Characters Summary[/u][/b][/h1]

Each class has certain type of weapons and careers (talent trees) to choose from, summarised hereunder: -

[b]1. Elf (Kerrilian) [/b]- Glass cannon with mostly light weapons and good ranged capabilities. Choice between Ranged/Stealth/Support in Careers.
[b]2. Knight (Kruber) [/b]- Horde clearing tank with access to both Light and Heavy weapons. Choice between Horde Clear/Ranged/Tank in Careers.
[b]3. Dwarf (Bardin) [/b]- Access to both Light and Heavy weapons depending on career. Choice between Ranged/Super Tank/Berzerker in Careers
[b]4. Witch (Sienna) [/b]- Glass cannon with mostly light weapons and amazing horde clearing capabilities. All of her careers are damage focused and only change her playstyle.
[b]5. Witch Hunter (Saltzpyre) [/b]- Access to both Light and Heavy weapons depending on career. Choice between Support/Boss killing/Support + Damage in Careers

One of the best gaming purchases I've made in the past year at least if not longer. It is very obviously a melee/fantasy oriented take on the Left 4 Dead model, with more than just a thin veneer of Warhammer Fantasy splashed on top. Each of the four characters and their class options feels fully fleshed out and imminently playable. None of them are necessarily better than the others, they all lean into a playstyle of some sort. All are meant to support and be supported by a team. Going "lone wolf" is just a recipe to die alone. Depending on the difficulty and your skill level you might do ok running solo through a mission, but it's entirely possible your team will struggle and or fail without that fourth member there to keep them going. The game leans heavily into encouraging the group to work together, especially as you advance the difficulties.

The DLC's are great to have but the base classes available to each character are all great in their own right, the DLC classes are not overpowered "must haves" - if you can catch em on sale as I did, then I highly recommend them.

The cosmetics are generally not great, and always not worth the cash. But there are cosmetics you can buy with the in game silver coins you earn. Many of those are just fine for making the character you prefer to play stand out a bit etc. Ignore the actually cash shop cosmetics unless you just really don't mind throwing money around on games like this, in which case if you're enjoying the game and think those look cool, go for it. Some of them are pretty cool looking.

The game is ok if looking to meet up with random folks and crush some Skaven and Chaos stuff, but the game really shines when you have a group of 3-4 people who can play together as a group. Randoms can be great fun, but it's a roll of the dice. You might also get someone who's oblivious to what's going on and leaves you fighting a horde + a boss to run off into the deeper part of the level to rescue another player who got downed earlier. It happens, that's the internet, not the games fault. That said, it's not always easy to find folks to play with. It does make the game infinitely more enjoyable.

Vermintide 2 takes everything that made the first game great and cranks it up to eleven. The atmosphere is still top-notch, immersing you in the chaos and terror of the Warhammer universe. The environments are even more detailed, and the enemies are more grotesque and challenging than ever.

The combat Itself is even better this time around. The characters have new weapons and abilities, making the gameplay even more diverse and engaging. Slicing through the Skaven and Chaos hordes has never been more satisfying. They really upped the ante with the action, and you'll feel like a total badass!

Of course, the cooperative play is still a major highlight. Team up with your friends or join forces with other players online. Communication and teamwork are as crucial as ever, and the sense of camaraderie when you conquer tough missions together is unbeatable.

Vermintide 2 also adds new enemy types and special events, keeping the gameplay fresh and exciting. You'll face even greater challenges, and the game constantly throws surprises your way.

But, as with any game, there are a couple of things to keep in mind. Some players might find the difficulty level to be quite challenging, especially in higher difficulties. It can be a tough nut to crack, but that's also part of the appeal for many players.

The sequel has addressed some of the AI issues from the first game, but you might still encounter a few odd moments. Nothing game-breaking, though.

Overall, Vermintide 2 is like a solid game for me. It takes everything that made the original great and polishes it to perfection. If you loved the first game or are a fan of co-op action with a dark and thrilling atmosphere, this sequel is an absolute must-play.

Prepare to be hooked, my friend!

All things considered I would still recommend this game as it is a solid co-op experience. As with all co-op games it is definitiely a better experience with friends.

Vermintide is a 4 player first person, class-based, melee focused game. Ranged weapons play into it and are a vital part of survival, but your main toolset for handling the hordes of skaven/chaos/beastmen are the melee weapons. As you move through the different maps completing your objectives hordes with simple grunts and fodder will be assisted by various stronger elite enemies as well as specials. The specials are similar to the special zombies from Left4Dead, and can either pin you down with warp fire or bullets, or disable you completely to the point of needing aid from your friends (e.g. hunter from left4dead). 

Added to this mini-bosses can spawn as well (called monsters in this), and chaos can ensue as a horde with specials spawn at the same time.  

This means that your party needs to consider different roles if you aim to survive on higher difficulties. You need a balance of monster killers, horde clear and special/elite snipers. The gameplay and feeling of bashing rats is great and the sheer chaos that can develop during a run is a lot of fun. This is why I definitiely recommend it. 

That is not to say there aren't issues. The weapon attribute system feels lackluster and is mainly an annoyance. The coveted "red items" aren't really worth the effort since all they do is give you the max stats on the attributes, something you can get close to by re-rolling later on. This means that there isn't that much motivation to grind later on, something I don't mind as the gameplay is still fun and the challenge of getting through the highest difficulty is my main motivator. 

The issue with the DLC Winds of Magic is also there. Beastmen simply aren't as fun as I hoped, they are only an annoyance for me. They had issues with being able to distinguish the different types early on, something I still feel is a problem. They also introduced a different game mode with the weaves, which has a separate attribute leveling system for the weapons you use in the weaves. I never played this apart from a couple of weaves as I don't see the point of grinding up my weapons AGAIN, and the modifiers to the weaves aren't all that special to attract my attention. If the system for weapon attributes allowed you to do things you couldn't in ordinary gameplay I might play weaves to experiment with it, but they are simply the same systems but in weaves you outright pick the attribute you want instead of rolling.

All in all VT2 has a split personality, somewhat weak endgame, but it is a solid co-op experience with the potential for a lot of fun. It stays faithful to a lot of the lore, and has interesting characters and group dynamic. In a world which needs more good co-op games this is one of them.

Edit: 
Might as well write a line or two about the last addition to the gameplay loop of VT2. Chaos Wastes is all I play these days in. It is a "rogue-like" type of mode where you head out into the wastes and play a number of maps with various modifiers on them, eventually reaching the Citadel of Eternity. The maps feature a "standard setting" (e.g. Slaughter bay or Holseher's Tower), but other parts/tiles of the map can be randomly fitted together. This introduces some replayability as other times you may be entering a particular place from the opposite direction. Or other times a certain map tile is not there. 

The maps may have modifiers adapting the spawn rate of different enemy types (e.g. specials or elites). Then there is the possibility that a Chaos God has "cursed" the map (khorne making blood whirlwinds or slaanesh draining your hp steadily). You will, however, be able to buy "boons" that are essentially new traits over the course of the run. These can vary from removing the consecutive dash penalty to being able to duplicate an item you have on you when you use your special ability. This is what makes Chaos Wastes fun. 

The different Chaos Gods' effects brings, well, chaos to the run. You are never quite certain when all hell will break loose, but when it does it is typically just stupid fun. Then that high of suddenly getting all those boons that synergize and turn you into a nuclear warhead just clearing the map one Morgrim bomb at a time. 

My friends and I play at Cataclysm difficulty, and we often fail our runs (mainly for running non-meta builds, because who wants stale gameplay), but we always return for some more chaos and suffering. That in itself is a good indicator of how much fun this is. Why Fatshark missed the opportunity of bringing some of these mechanics into Darktide is beyond me, but hey, that is what they do best. Missing the mark.

Vermintide II is kind of a mixed bag of wanting to be a Warhammer Game, wanting to be on online 4 player Co-Op like Borderlands or Left 4 Dead, and wanting session based play. As I am not that well versed in Warhammer I cannot really speak to the accuracy or lack-there-of in translating a PnP game to a Interactive Real Time Brawler/Slasher/Shooter.

I can, however, type for hours on the genius designs of L4D and BL then delving deep into how their sequels diverged from the strengths of their progenitors.  I can also quite distinctly type on the conversion of a campaign based play system into a session based play system having sunk a few years into Planetside. Taking an experience that is, in some ways, meant to be drawn out over a long period of time and trying to cram that experience into Arena-Driven Brawl/Slash/Shoot very rarely ends well. 

Vermintide II starts out fairly strong with an emphasis on a campaign experience to familiarize the player with the control scheme and intended battle flow. Scant seconds after finishing the tutorial that practice round is collectively heaved off the side of a cliff, and instead of a consistent story based progression in-vein of other Brawler/Slasher/Shooter's turned Role Play Game (Metroid, Elder Scrolls, Fallout) the player is immediately thrust into online matchmaking focused on session-based quick plays. 

Well, how do I put this. 

When I pick up a game with "Warhammer" in the title, I don't expect Quake-Like. I don't Expect Doom-Zero. I don't expect "Call of Battlefield Xbox 360 Edition with no Single player Campaign." Yes, that is as insulting as I mean it to sound. 

I expect a campaign driven world following the exploits (or lack there-of) of the character(s) I am introduced to in starting the game. 

So, right off the bat, not getting what the game's advertising, store page, and other official information lead to believe i would be receiving makes Vermintide 2 a rather hard sell to other potential players. If I want a squad-based + session-based quick round with friends... well... what, exactly, is wrong with BL or L4D? Absolutely nothing. 

Now, I'm not saying that Vermintide II is a bad game mind you. For what it is it probably is a pretty good game. There are massive differences though between a game you enjoy, a game that you would recommend others play, and a game that you would like other players to play WITH you. 

Quite frankly Vermintide II needed to spend a lot more time in the UI development, character pathing, and the design of a cohesive experience, time the game clearly didn't get, and time it will NOT be getting "now." 

Overhauling the front-end of a game and re-configuring the entirety of progression for a game because it's present release state is somewhere on the other side of ****ED UP after release just doesn't happen. Again, that makes Vermintide II an extremely hard-sell to new players. 

It also makes an subsequent release in a series an equally hard-sell. Grab bags of different genres and styles just don't make for a compelling experience.  

Now, personally, if I had the ears of the dev team I'd grab those ears, drag them into the conference room, and make it clear that single player campaign comes first in development. Interactive Games operate on a long-Tailed Economic Model. Long after the multiplayer base has dried up and everyone else has moved onto a new game or gone back to the games they like, a game can still be sold as an experience. Not having that factor in mind during development screws any number of games over harder than a Democrat in an elected office screws over voters. 

Also ignoring the single-player experience exposes how vulnerable online games are to latency and lag. All it takes is a really bad connection, and an enjoyable night's play becomes naught more than utter frustration. To put this in perspective, Microsoft, routinely the villain, found out that a vast number of Xbox/Windows users with Games Pass subscriptions on Cable or 5G internet connections preferred to use the Xbox Cloud Gaming to try out new games, and then just download the game to actually play. Just because someone has a great connection to the internet does NOT mean they have a great connection to your service. It also means you should probably consider methods of making the game playable when your service is NOT available. 

Read into that last section what you will about my own online experience with Vermintide II. Jumping through hoops to launch a private server with relatively offline(ish) play is possible, but that should have been the default experience. Not the hoop jump option. 

Again though, it's probably too late for any of the desperately needed overhauls and focus changes Vermintide II requires to go from a forgettable title into something worthy of telling other players about to actually occur. Oh well.

Imagine Left for Dead with melee and big frickin' rats instead of zombies.

TLDR: This game follows, almost to the letter, what Left 4 Dead did right.

The core mechanics of the game are solid. Combat is fast and visceral, cooperation is vital against the special enemies; hook rats, lich... liches? and such (don't wanna spoil much), basically this game version of L4D tanks, boomers, smokers, spitters, etc). The game has some interesting objectives and level variations to keep things from getting dull. Randomised item placement, such as health pick ups, bombs and such also makes you check more places when you're in a pinch, keeping things a bit more interesting. Huge crowds of mobs, patrols and random bosses are also things that will be thrown at you completely at random. It's all in all great. I mean it can be, at times, overly stupid, like climbing a tree and having an ogre spawn in the branches, that ain't great. But most of the time it keeps the team close together, pinging any pick ups, and helping each other whenever possible.

The game allows switching between 5 heroes with 3 base classes, 4 if you get the DLC (which each play very differently w/o mentioning that each weapon works very differently, ex: 2 handed hammer vs sword and shield) makes the game have extra depth.

Audio is nice, the clashing of weapons isn't overwhelming, even if it is constant. The characters talk A LOT, but they're actually kinda funny to listen to.

Graphics are ok for the game's age, it ain't Witcher 3, though.

Controls are simple, 1 through 5 for items and weapons, left click and right click will depend on your character and weapons, some ''builds'' have weight behind their movements and some are slick and quick. 

Fun with friends, but may get repetitive fast. I got it on sale and I don't regret it.

I'd give this a so-so rating if I could. Buy on sale, not full price

- It's an awesome co-op game with a good amount of maps that all feel different
- DLC Map sharing ( if someone in your party owns the DLC maps, they're available for everyone to play regardless if everyone owns it or not )
- The enemies are super cool looking and combat is very satisfying
- Characters and their classes have nice diversity and designs between them

BUT

- They have a micro-transaction cosmetic shop that uses real money or in-game currency that you can earn slowly from logging in daily and doing challenges or you can buy more with real money
- Some of the best weapons, classes, and cosmetics cost are micro-transactions
( I think this is greedy and lame, since I already paid for the game and there are no meaningful updates that come that don't cost money )
- There are plenty of bugs, server/connection issues, and performance issues ( from what I've experienced )
- Some DLC maps are lackluster and boring

Impressively bad. Instead of playing this, spend your time making this great cheesecake

Crust:
8 whole graham crackers, broken into 1-inch pieces
6 tablespoons (3/4 stick) unsalted butter, melted and cooled. Plus 1 extra tablespoon butter for brushing on pan
3 tablespoons sugar
Filling:
2 1/2 pounds cream cheese, cut into chunks and softened
1 1/2 cups sugar
1/8 teaspoon salt
1/3 cup sour cream
2 teaspoons fresh lemon juice
2 teaspoons vanilla extract
2 large egg yolks
6 large eggs

For the crust: Adjust an oven rack to the middle position and heat the oven to 325°. Process the graham cracker pieces in a food processor to fine, even crumbs, about 30 seconds. Sprinkle the melted butter and sugar over the crumbs and pulse to incorporate. Sprinkle the mixture into a 9-inch springform pan. Press the crumbs firmly into an even layer using the bottom of a measuring cup. Bake the crust until fragrant and beginning to brown, 10 to 15 minutes. Let the crust cool to room temperature, about 30 minutes.

For the filling: Meanwhile, increase the oven temperature to 500°. Beat the cream cheese in a large bowl with an electric mixer on medium-low speed until smooth, 1-3 minutes. Scrape down the bowl and beaters as necessary.

Beat in half the sugar and salt until incorporated, 1-3 minutes. Beat in the remaining sugar until incorporated, 1-3 minutes. Beat in the sour cream, lemon juice and vanilla until incorporated, 1-3 minutes. Beat in the egg yolks and eggs, two at a time until combined, 1-3 minutes.

Being careful not to disturb the baked crust, brush the inside of the prepared springform pan with 1 tablespoon of melted butter. Set the pan on a rimmed baking sheet. Carefully pour the filling into the pan. Bake the cheesecake for 10 minutes.

Without opening the door, reduce the oven temperature to 200° and continue to bake the cheesecake until the center of the cake registers 150° (about 1 1/2 hours).

Transfer the cake to a wire rack and run a knife around the edge of the cake. Let the cheesecake stand until just barely warm, 2 1/2 – 3 hours. Chill until ready to eat. Serve as is or with Strawberry Topping.

Having played about 200 hours, then uninstalling for a few years (yes, YEARS) I deleted my "old" review (which was also a very HIGHLY recommended score) to make a new, updated one.  After played DarkTide for about 800 hours, I was in need of something fresh and I decided to give VT2 a try again.  In the past few years there are several new careers, a boatload of new maps, a plethora of new weapons, and several different game modes to choose from.

I gotta say, this is probably my favorite game again, now.  It's so unbelievably well done - every aspect of it.  The 'new' content (I have no idea when all this was released, but it's all new to me) is amazingly fun, and fresh, and interesting.  I really can't score VT2 high enough, honestly.

Playing DarkTide for ~800 hours, it always completely baffled me how it could have mixed or negative reviews.  After playing VT2 again for approx. 2 weeks in full, I can now fully understand the hatred toward DT.  Granted, I still have to take it will a grain of salt because they *are* different games.  If DT had the features and content VT2 had, I'd never look back, but here I am, enjoying the living hell out of VT2 again in all its fresh, new, glory.

Great hack and slash coop game with Left 4 Dead style dialogue.

Well, I guess it's fun for a few hrs.
.
.
.
.
.
Jokes aside, honeslty one of the best coop experience I've ever come across.
A (most of the time) wholesome and helping community, I've met some new friends there, with which I also play other games or just talk in general.
Well crafted combat-system with a high skill-ceiling going to higher difficulties.
Good variety of melee and ranged weapons, as well as build variety on every character-class (5 characters with 3 classes each), though some builds just being stronger though than others.(if you care about meta stuff that is)
Lots of story-missions, Chaos Wastes a fun Rogue-like game-mode and a few DLC missions (some paid, some as free updates) which hold some secrets for you to find. (and one, where you play drunk and need to keep drinking, honestly one of the most fun missions ever made)

Negatives are:
Highest difficulty Cataclysm (was added later after release) is behind paywall together with another game-mode, the Weaves.
Paid DLC for some of the best weapons in the game, not to say the base-game weapons are bad, those DLC ones are just better in many situations.
And a 4th class for every character (also added later after release), which is behind a paywall, some being a bit overpowered in comparison to the base-game ones.

As a finishing note I'd like to mention one of the strongest argument for this game, the Characters. The dialog of the characters and their interactions in hub-area or on missions between each other (even different depending on your class) is probably the greatest aspect of this game. So much passion and talent was put in to this, delivering most memorable voices to those characters. They will very likely grow on you over time, developing favorites and saying their voice-lines along side them.

So yeah for me personally a 10/10, but considering the negatives more of a 7 or 8... so I will meet you at the middle and give this a 8.5/10.

I am a huge fan of the first Vermintide game. It was a perfect, simple, entertaining hack-and-slash first person action. But THIS... To make it less repeptitive, the devs used a random generator in the game. So now instead of a rat ogre appearing at the same moment in a level, it js just a random tank: pgre, spawn, ...  Sounds like a great thing? No, because it is broken. Some playthroughs there is an ogre, and the next time one plays the same level there are THREE SPAWNS. Oh, and did I mention that it became pratically impossible to beat a tank unless one's level is probably above 15? I finished the first game with level 7. And it was fully playable and fun. 
Unless there's a major level balance update, I won't start this game again. 
I would give the first Vermintide 11/10 if I could.

I'm a 50-year-old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game.
I am a single father to my son, who is now 14 years old. My son started playing Warhammer: Vermintide 2 for the first time
In less than a week, he has already played more than 20 hours.
It was terrible for me, because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son.
the fact that he was always with his friends or watching videos on YouTube.
So I decided to return to my Steam account to play with my son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game since 2010, so I was pretty lost. I asked my son for help, and we spent several hours together playing this game.
I liked it because it was the best time I've spent with my son since my wife died. Playing video games reminded me that there is pleasure in everything, and it brought me and my son closer together again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house.

Amazing graphics that are well optimized even for low end PCs. As you play the game, you'll eventually know what DLC you want and when to buy it.

Probably the best L4D clone and one of the few good games in this genre. It manages to capture L4D's formula just right, and it also introduces new mechanics that plays well with said formula. Gameplay wise it ain't so different, the controls are simple, you go from point A to point B, fighting hordes of rats/rotbloods etc etc. However every time you finish a map you return to the Keep (your base) to choose the next one. Every character has 3 careers (4 with the DLCs) each one of them has different skill trees, that adds to the variety and replay value of the game.

Pros:
-The best melee focused combat of all time
-Simple gameplay, with high skill ceiling
-Incredible enemy design
-Great special enemy design
-A good variety of bosses
-A lot of content
-Really good level of detail
-Fantastic map design
-Top notch voice acting (honestly just watch Warrior Priest's trailer)
-Incredible character design 
-Good gore
-Good audio and sound design
-Good graphics

Even though the game is incredibly good, it suffers from a lot of Balance/Bugs/QoL/Progression system/Reward system and some enemy design problems that hold it back from its 100% potential.
Cons:
-Probably the worst BOTs I have ever seen
-Hilariously bad rewards for in-game challenges
-80% of enemy spawns and hordes are scripted (could be 100% if you don't sit and wait for 5 whole minutes in the same spot like an idiot)
-Progression system is also terrible, why am I getting the same amount of XP for a mission I completed on recruit as the one I completed on Cataclysm?
-RNG loot system (it's always bad)
-Why Strangler has pushback resistance and that much HP?
-Why gas rat doesn't die in one shot yet it is able to burst you from afar?
-Some of the worst enemy design in gaming history: Blightstormer, Stormvermin with shield, Banner Bearer (DLC enemy, luckily). So for the first 2, there isn't any actual counter play and they are very tedious to play against. Blightstormer will summon incredibly huge hurricanes even through walls, that will probably cover 50% of your space, and they will hunt you down for an incredible amount of time, wait what's that? You can't even see the dude because he is behind walls or 15km behind you? What? You have a melee only class? Well too bad for you, we are too lazy to redesign the guy, good luck dealing with this BS on Legend/Cata while fighting hordes. You know, actually we will make this guy even more tedious, it will shred your HP if he catches you, and while you are helpless in his hurricane which takes really long to release you, other enemies can also hit you LMAO, you got smoked mate, and you could do nothing about it. Hey how about we spawn 2-3 of them at the same time? Yeeee our wives hate us.
Stormvermin, not much to say, just tedious to fight there is not a way to break their shield, you just hit them untill you stagger them. They break the pace of the game.
-Live service (so you basically cannot play without internet) and that leads to other problems as well, if you are mid-map and your internet goes down for whatever reason, the game kicks you. (even if you play solo private)
-You have to complete the map to actually earn the rewards for a challenge. How retarded does that sound? So out of idk 900 in-game challenges this game has, 500 of them are based on luck and require a really good premade team. So if you actually are lucky some day and have that Rat Ogre jump and kill it (I got this challenge on my 600 hour hit mark by accident, not because it's hard, but because rat ogre will barely jump) you still have to complete the map for the challenge to count.. What's that your internet went down or the game decided to fuck you up? Well jokes on you, grind another 500 hours only to reward you with commendation chest who is already obtainable by simply leveling up lol 

Overall: 7/10

The game plainly doesn't function on the Steam Deck.

You can technically play, but only among the separate group of users who aren't approved by the anti-cheat. The game doesn't save your progress there, so I sure hope you enjoy the first level.

Additionally, as the Steam Deck user, you must be the host, which  means that you literally can't play with other Steam Deck users.

Edit - Not to be misleading, I should clarify that your (non Steam Deck) friends are able to opt into playing in the same unapproved section with you, but it resets their progress to 0 for the duration.

Also, to top it off, it's a nightmare to uninstall from the Deck for some frickin' reason.

I've been using 3rd party Windows apps and emulators since day 1 with the Deck, and nothing else has come close to being this awkward to deal with.

[b]By SIGMAR, the HAMMER, and the EMPIRE! [/b]

Vermintide 2, developed and published by Fatshark, is an adrenaline-pumping cooperative first-person action game that transports players to a grim and treacherous world filled with endless hordes of vile enemies. Set in the Warhammer Fantasy universe, Vermintide 2 offers a thrilling and immersive experience as you and your comrades fight to survive against the forces of Chaos and the relentless Skaven rat-men.

[b]Combat and Gameplay: [/b]
Prepare for intense, heart-pounding battles as you engage in a seamless blend of melee and ranged combat. The game offers a wide array of weaponry, allowing each hero class to adopt different playstyles. Whether you prefer the brute strength of a two-handed hammer or the precision of a longbow, Vermintide 2 caters to diverse combat preferences.

The combat mechanics are weighty and satisfying, with impactful strikes and gruesome takedowns that make each encounter a visceral delight. The enemies, ranging from lowly Skaven warriors to towering Chaos warriors, present formidable challenges that require skillful dodging, blocking, and coordinated attacks with your teammates.

[b]Heroic Progression: [/b]
Vermintide 2 features a robust progression system that rewards you with experience points and loot as you vanquish enemies and complete missions. As you level up, you can unlock new talents and abilities, enhancing your hero's capabilities and allowing for greater specialization. The progression system provides a sense of growth and encourages players to experiment with different builds and strategies.

[b]Cooperative Mayhem: [/b]
The true essence of Vermintide 2 lies in its cooperative gameplay. Join forces with up to three friends or other players online and embark on thrilling missions together. Teamwork is crucial as you coordinate your attacks, cover each other's backs, and revive fallen comrades. Effective communication and strategic cooperation will be the key to surviving the relentless onslaught of enemies.

[b]Rich and Foreboding Atmosphere: [/b]
Step into the dark and brooding world of Warhammer Fantasy, brought to life with meticulous attention to detail. The environments are masterfully crafted, from the war-torn streets of cities to the eerie forests and dank underground tunnels. The haunting soundtrack and atmospheric sound effects further immerse you in the grim ambiance of the game.

[b]Conclusion: [/b]
Warhammer: Vermintide 2 offers an adrenaline-fueled cooperative experience that will captivate fans of intense action games and Warhammer enthusiasts alike. With its exhilarating combat, rewarding progression system, and immersive atmosphere, Vermintide 2 stands as a testament to the strength of cooperative gameplay. Brace yourself for unrelenting chaos, rally your comrades, and prepare to face the Vermintide head-on in this gripping and unforgiving adventure.

Crazy?  I Was Crazy Once.  They Locked Me In A Room.  A Rubber Room.  A Rubber Room With Rats.  And Rats Make Me Crazy.

In all seriousness though I can't not recommend this game to a majority of people.  While there are some drawbacks like Fatshark not actually delivering on promises they've made (Big and very disappointing), the relatively bad online play (Really depends but it's not the best), and how you obtain loot in a slow loot-box style fashion (Although it feels better than Vermintide 1 praying for the dice to land).  What makes me stay is the gameplay loop they have and just the variety of abilities and weapons you have at your disposal.  Also, I'm a masochist and want to get all possible Okri's Challenges done at some point.  

TL;DR: I [b]really[/b] enjoy the game even with some of the issues that still persist and if you're reading this I recommend you give it a try, at least when it's on sale!

I've played for 300 hours on PS + here. The good of the game has been done to death so instead I'll be talking about the negative in this review so that they can be looked on for room for improvement. Some nitpicky, some more than that:

Winds of magic - DLC for the most part is great, except for winds of magic which on its own is a terrible DLC because the selling point is the dogshite gamemode that next to no one plays. Buts its also way too overpriced for what your getting, dog gamemode, 5 new weapons all of which are good, a singular map, (a good map IMO but some disagree) but the most INSULTING part of this DLC is 'Cataclysm' an entire difficulty locked behind a paywall. That is just asinine and i don't think i need to go further than that. So if you don't care about the gamemode (you shouldn't) you're ultimately overpaying for a map, 5 weapons and a difficulty...very silly John Fatshark. 

Crashes - As of right now there are an occasional amount of crashes which can range from inconvenient to soul-destroying. For example, crashing while loading into a match, inconvenient. Then there's crashing at the end of a chaos wastes...pain. 

PTSD - *packrat noises*

Gear Progression - Nitpicky and probably comes from me going from PS to PC. the way gear works is a linear growth from whatever gear number your item is and when you open a chest you have a chance to get another piece of gear higher than what you have until you get to 300 (cap). I just wish there was a faster way to get 300 than opening a million chests or cheesing with crafting.

Players - Some people are dumb and/or rude. It's an online game, to be expected but still fuck off

Grudge challenges for the white outfits in chaos wastes - Chance whether or not you get the monster you need, annoying when you consider the length of the matches

And that's it or what i could think of right now, there may be something I'm missing but regardless you should get this game the other million positive things that everyone else has said would warrant that.

Happy hunting :)

Bashing out a review for Warhammer: Vermintide 2 several years after it came out is a salute to the replayability of this genre-defining gem. Throw yourself into the higher difficulties and remember to dodge and block as you hack and slash your way through this hilarious masterpiece of mayhem. Man-rats and goat-men come at you and your pals in massive hordes and it is up to you to slice them up, blow them up, set them on fire, gun them down and squat jump your way to safety. The awesome soundtrack is heavy on the drums and big on adrenaline, shoving you through a heap of gorgeous maps from reasty dungeons to snowy mountains. Years have gone by and Fat Shark are still adding content. Keep it coming.

Fantastic game. I got in to the genre of 4-player coop games via Deep Rock Galactic. However, I  craved something a bit more.. confrontational in its gameplay. Enter Vermintide. The game is everything I had hoped for and more. All characers feel truly distinct, and all careers ("variations" or "subclasses" for the characters) truly feel like variations of the same playstyle, all while it all feels similar enough thay you could pick up any character and perform on a similar level without ever having played berfore. Cleaving through hordes of enemies have never felt better (if the reviews on Darktide are anything to go of). And yes, the community is still active and it's easy to find people to play with as long as you play in active hours. Highly recomeded!

PROS: 
- Beautiful, well designed maps which can be played repeatedly
- In-depth game mechanics requiring (and rewarding) teamwork
- Well crafted heroes with superb voice acting, including entertaining banter, varied personalities & fittingly appropriate costumes
- Excellent use of narration, music and sound effects to provide a truly immersive experience
- A large variety of weapons to choose between, for each hero
- A feature rich match-making system which makes it easy to find other players to play with

CONS: (There aren't many!)
- Veteran players would welcome a few more maps now that the game is 3 years old
EDIT (June 2023): In 2021, 16 more maps were added as part off the "Chaos Wastes" expansion and more "normal" maps which can be played "stand-alone" are being added in 2023, so this is less of an issue now

- The cosmetics available in the in-game "shop" lack variety, with some being so similar as to be indistinguishable from each other
EDIT (June 2023): This remains a problem in 2023, 5 years after the game's release. There are more varied cosmetics available now, but these must be purchased using real money and are expensive to buy individually, forcing you to wait until they're on sale.

- The levelling system makes it difficult for veteran players to play with novices
- In-game "events" and "special rewards" are few and far between

Whether you're a die hard Warhammer fan or just looking for a challenging co-op experience; your time and money is well spent on this title. Simply put: the combat is intense, unforgiving and brutal. Surviving your third wave in a row of enemies will leave your heart pounding and your palms sweaty; only for the reprieve to be interrupted by the roar of a Rat Ogre as your party scrambles into position in a desperate attempt to survive the next three minutes of what the game throws at you.

I have around 450 hours invested at the time of revisiting my review. Fat Shark has just released a massive balance patch that has fixed a lot of weapon and general combat issues and has reiterated that they plan to continue to balance the game moving forward. This patch specifically has re-tuned some of the more overpowered weapons and brought some of the weaker load out options in line with the more popular choices. This comes after a prolonged drought of much needed updates. Fat Shark gets a lot of shit I feel maybe even unfairly for the development cycle of this game on PC but I think they have done an excellent job with this franchise as a whole and I cannot way to see what content is around the corner.

The game, like it's predecessor remains one of the most challenging and visceral multiplayer experiences available on PC and console. Whether you're a Warhammer fan or not.

Fun core gameplay, but it becomes less optimized with each update. I have been forced to lower my graphics settings with each major patch just to keep the game playable. Hordes can cause my fps to drop from 60 to 10, and character abilities are constantly breaking (e.g. Waystalker's ult does 0 damage or ignores enemies altogether). Cannot recommend this game in its current state due to how punishing it is when bugs are encountered.

Chaotic stressful fun with great artwork and voice acting. The grind to max out character and gear levels gets very tedious after 20+ hours as you'll have played all the missions more than once by this point, but fun to dip into now and again to scratch the Warhammer itch

LOVE THIS GAME!

From the moment I stepped foot into the grimdark world of the Old World, I was enraptured by the relentless onslaught of the rat-men hordes and the putrid forces of Chaos. The unyielding tide of enemies, like an unholy manifestation of sin itself, relentlessly tests the mettle of any brave soul who dares to stand against them.

The variety of heroes at your disposal, each embodying a different aspect of war, is commendable. Whether I wielded the might of the Empire's hammer, the grace of the Wood Elves' bow, or the explosive fury of the Dwarf's gun, I felt a profound connection to the rich lore of Warhammer. The progression system, allowing me to unlock devastating abilities and upgrade my arsenal, further fueled the flames of my righteous crusade.

The gameplay itself is a symphony of carnage and tactical prowess. The co-op aspect, reminiscent of a righteous crusade with fellow warriors, is a shining beacon of camaraderie. The need for strategic positioning and teamwork in the face of overwhelming odds is reminiscent of the glorious battles fought in the name of the Emperor himself.

Visually, Vermintide 2 does justice to the grimdark aesthetic of the Warhammer universe. The meticulously crafted environments, ranging from desolate cities to corrupted forests, are a testament to the attention to detail paid by the developers. The blood-soaked battlegrounds and nightmarish enemy designs are a sight to behold, igniting a righteous fury within my soul.

Alas, even in the face of such greatness, I must express a minor grievance. The occasional glitch and lack of polish in certain areas tarnish an otherwise exemplary experience. While these missteps do not diminish the grandeur of the overall game, they do serve as a blemish on the armor of this valiant endeavor.

So I've played my fair share of VT2 and It's not often I write reviews but I think it's time I write one.

Honestly, I love this game. I always find myself coming back to it. I started playing on PS4 and eventually picked it up on PC. The maps are fast and interesting enough to keep me going and the classes are all unique. The core game is very well polished and the combat is unparalleled. I've yet to play a game that feels as good as this to play.

But I am become more disappointed with the developers. Stringing out the release of the final class, perhaps knowing it will mark the end of this beloved project. Instead, they're releasing maps which just bog down the quick play queue. When one of the new maps pops up, I just lose motivation to play. Trail of Treachery has been one of the biggest disappointments, the map where parties of random players often discuss the option of just jumping off the mountain to skip it. To make it worse, the map pops up more often than others. 

Then the newest maps have just felt empty. I'm sure effort has gone into them but they're a long way off the same quality of the original and DLC maps. It feels like they're making maps just to pretend the game is still being supported. After the release of Darktide, maybe they have switched back to supporting Vermintide and they're rushing to make up for lost time. 

Unfortunately the poor quality of these free maps and inability to remove them from our quickplay queues means I just don't see myself putting much more time into this game. 

To top that off, the empty promises of Sienna's final class being released with the next map, no actually the NEXT map, no actually the NEXT map. That's just not right. If they're having problems could just say that, instead they choose to mislead us and attempt to keep our attention. 

TL;DR
If you're reading the reviews, you'll probably enjoy the game. It's honestly a great game. Just be aware that the golden age is gone and the new releases are not adding value but rather diminishing it. The developers are not working on improving the game, only extending it's life-span enough to rinse more money with their cosmetics shop. 

Unfortunately I can't bring myself to give this game a negative review but this positive comes with some big caveats

As of now, I can only recommend this game if you have friends to play with. Otherwise it feels like it's only worth grabbing on a sale or playing something else.

The aesthetics, lore, general settings, gameplay are all fine at its core. Sub classes are a good way to differentiate in play style and games.

As of 6/16/2023 Steamcharts says that there are more daily players on Vermintide 2 than in Darktide, but it doesn't feel like it. It's difficult to find players for matches and most games will be played with bots. This makes playing on higher difficulties unfun as bots are mostly useless. A problem with matches is unlike Darktide, Vermintide 2 only allows 1 class per person. If you attempt to quick play and the class you want is already chosen, too bad, pick something else. Can be frustrating when you spent 10-20~ minutes searching for a game because you want to play a certain character.

If you happen to find players for your game, it's a roulette wheel for toxicity and skill. There's an abundance of people who will purposely troll and throw games or insult and instigate fights for seemingly no reason, Beyond the issue of toxicity, this problem extends to the matchmaking. Unlike Darktide, Vermintide is peer-to-peer. If a host decides they no longer wish to play and leave, it kicks everyone from the match, gives no experience, and returns people to the hub. It is extremely unfun to wait 15 minutes for a match, play for 15 minutes and the host decide to leave because someone decided to be mean and have everyone kicked.

Despite years of updates there are still bugs. Nothing game breaking, but having grims drop and fall through floors, elite specials attack through walls, phantom hits on people.

If you can find a group of competent, kind people to play with it's an enjoyable game. Otherwise it can be very frustrating and not fun.

Vermintide 2 is a seriously mixed bag which comes with a caveat. I do not recommend the game for its current price, although picking it up on sale would certainty be worth it. Vermintide 2 is a game that I should probably hate. Graphically, it ranges from bland to bland and ugly. The art direction is not very good (with some glaring exceptions) and it has microtransactions and horrible menus. However, the combat is solid and it can be really fun at times though it gets old quickly. The enemy designs, from what I have experienced are bland and uninteresting, though the elites are an exception (haha flamethrower rats go brrr). The premise alone is great and if you want a fairly mindless game about killing rats, go for it. Vermintide does not, however, hold up to other horde combat games such as Risk Of Rain 2 or other multiplayer games like Monster Hunter. The next time it goes on sale, pick it up, although it is horribly overpriced as it stands at the moment.

OLD REVIEW:

It's a beautiful game and quite fun with friends but there's a lot of bugs that can ruin your experience, particularly in higher difficulty levels. Collision detection is absolutely terrible in this game and sometimes enemies pass through me and hit my teammates behind me or stand inside me and hit me but I can't hit them. If you can look past a few frustrating bugs like that, then you'll have a blast with this game. It's a lot more fun than L4D2 and has high replayability.

EDIT:
Stopped playing for 2 months and started again recently hoping that some of the bugs would have been fixed. I found out that instead there were EVEN MORE bugs now. This game is stupidly buggy and can make the game really frustrating and annoying to play. Spawn of Chaos is now really buggy. One time the Spawn of Chaos just got stuck trying to hit wtihout actually hitting, allowing us to just keep hitting it and killing it without it doing any damage. It was actually a nice bug. The 2nd bug was not so nice. The Spawn of chaos got stuck when eating one of our teammates . My teammate didn't lose any health and the spawn of chaos didn't gain any health but just kept doing the eating animation. Unfortunately the rest of us were down so there was nothing to do and we had to quit the game or we would have had to wait forever for it to end. The MOST annoying bug is when enemies just pass through you sometimes or stand inside you and keep hitting you without you being able to move or hit them. The game is still fun to play but as long as these bugs are there, I can't recommend buying and playing this game until the devs fix this broken game.

List of annoying bugs:
*Collision detection is shit. Enemies including specials like gas rats just pass through you.
*Pack rats(stranglers) sometimes ignore collision and drag you down through the floor to hell or drag you up through the ceiling to heaven sometimes.
*Bots are dumb.
*specials sometimes spawn right in front of you. A ratling gunner spawned few feet in front of me once right next to a barrel. Fortunately the barrel exploded and killed it before it could do much damage.
*After the update, Saltzpyre is now included as default instead of Sienna for bot games even though my Sienna is level 20 and Saltzpyre is level 1. It's not really a bug but it's annoying that you can't change the default bots.
