While Fatshark's latest venture as of writing this review hasn't impressed me, Vermintide 2 still stands as their crowning achievement. Great characters, clever writing and beautiful carnage, all set with the backdrop of the deep Warhammer Fantasy universe. While it is in many ways comparable to Left 4 Dead, there is much more focus on simple yet deep and satisfying melee combat. Hack your way through hundreds of ratmen with a cleaving greatsword, scorch chaos worshipping northerners to ash with blazing magic, land headshot after headshot with your trusty bow, or use a rapier to methodically execute armoured enemies before they can reach your friends. 

While the difficulty curve is slow to ramp up through the four (five with DLC) difficulty levels, you will be happy you stuck it out once it does, and the game is a blast with up to three of your friends. Will you be the one to stem the tide?

Vermintide 2 is an absolute masterpiece that checks all the boxes for a thrilling co-op action game. What sets it apart is the exceptional dedication of developer Fatshark, who listens to players and delivers outstanding updates and content based on their feedback. With a staggering number of meticulously designed levels, including the heart-pounding Chaos mode that offers a roguelite experience, Vermintide 2 keeps players on the edge of their seats. The game's attention to detail, immersive atmosphere, and cooperative gameplay create an extraordinary experience that is truly unmatched. If you're looking for a game that listens to its community and delivers an unforgettable adventure, Vermintide 2 is an absolute must-play.

I bought this in 2020, but dropped it after two hours. The reason for this, was that I'm not a big fan of marathon games, like L4D2. I have played many Warhammer games over the years, and learned about the lore. Returned last month, to give this game another chance. Now that we have a lot of more content and patches, it's more enjoyable to play. Also, this is the type of game that you can play without worrying too much about the story, world etc. Just pick a character and reach the end of the map, while killing some enemies. It has advantages over L4D, but it also has many things that I don't like, including the balance.

[h1]Technical side of the game[/h1]

+ AMD FSR. I don't need, but it's nice to have it. Old version 1.0.
+ Anti-cheat.

+/- Always-online requirement, even when you play with bots. Not a big deal for me, and it makes sense here, but I prefer when solo modes remain offline.

- Poorly optimized performance. I play at max settings, on a good PC, 60fps/1080p. Fps drops very often. Not a critical problem for me, but I can't get stable 60 fps on max settings. Performance was a huge problem in Darktide Beta too. It seems that Fatshark needs more experienced programmers, or they should work with a third-party company, on game optimization.
- As a host in online matches, you can't add requirements for your lobby, such as level requirement. Players experienced a negative situation, when newbies/noobs joined difficulties above their "skill", and ruined the whole match. Of course, if you are a VT2 frequenter, and don't care that you will need to carry your teammates, then this is not a big deal for you. For others, it's a negative experience. The tutorial doesn't tell you much. Newbies and retarded players pick characters, level them up just a bit (or don't), don't learn basic things and go straight to high difficulty lobbies. I'm not saying that I'm a great player, but at least I'm not too selfish.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

+ Better combat and enemies, than in other games of this genre. There are armored enemies and armor-piercing weapons. Some enemies have shields. There is a dodge mechanic and blocks. All of this makes the combat more advanced and worth of your time. At least in my case. In L4D4, it's just a boring trash mob shooter. In VT2, you need to dodge, block etc.
I wish it had more tactical/counter elements, rather than being a trash mob cleaner game. 
+ Five playable characters, with different funny conversations. You only need four characters for matchmaking. Also, there are no clones in matches. One Kruber, one Bardin etc.
+ Bosses.
+ Loot system, without tons of drops, unlike many isometric Hack&Slash games, or games like Borderlands.

[h1]Characters & Careers[/h1]

+/- Each character has 3 base game + 1 Premium careers (class). Some of them change the play style of your character. Ex: Kruber can be a balanced character, ranged squashy guy, or full melee-oriented class.
1. Not all careers are interesting, or unique. Mercenary isn't very different from Ranger Veteran. Both are balanced roles. Witch Hunter Captain is also a balanced type, but actually a bit different. Foot Knight is a strange choice for me, at this point, when I can pick a full melee Grail Knight, with high damage career ability, or a balanced Mercenary. 
2. At least twice, you will get the same talents to choose from, for each class. Heal 20% of ally HP, while healing yourself. Stagger related talent etc. It could have been career related talents, but no.
3. Most weapons, for most classes, aren't locked. Ironbreaker (melee tank) can get good ranged weapons, while ranged Bounty Hunter can get all of Saltzpyre melee weapons. There are other examples. 
4. Weapons are poorly balanced and explained. You'll look at weapons, see the same "Crowd Control, Wide Sweeps, High Damage", and wonder what's the difference. Game UI doesn't tell you this. Also, some weapons are much worse than others. Some are too similar. 
5. Some career abilities are almost identical. Big circle around your character, enemies are pushed away, you get a buff.

[h1]Story[/h1]

- While there are funny conversations and simple objectives, the game lacks the actual story. No animated intros and endings. No mid-game scenes/dialogues or interesting objectives/missions. 

[h1]Cosmetics[/h1]

+ You can change hat/mask and outfit. 
- VT1 outfits aren't compatible with hats.
- Most outfits are simple recolors.
- A lot of junk/funny cosmetics. Fish on the head, hat with candles etc.
- Lack of good cosmetics. Especially for some classes.
- No store cosmetics for Premium careers.

[h1]Interface[/h1]

+ UI was updated with patches. Some useful functions added, such as friendly-fire indicator and numerical HP value.
- You can't resize or move UI elements. I would prefer smaller teammate portraits, without names (except in TAB menu), on the left corner of the screen. Also, an option to disable your own character portrait.

[h1]DLC[/h1]

I don't want to write a review for each DLC, so I will mention some things here.

+ Premium careers are good.
+ Back to Ubersreik adds weapons, portraits and few other things.
+ FRP adds some decent weapons.

- DLC for DLC. I'm talking about Premium career skins. Also, many skins are locked behind challenges. You pay to buy DLC for your DLC, then you have to unlock the DLC content. Amazing business practice! 
- Ubersreik DLC should have a discount, for owners of the first game. It uses maps from VT1.
- Winds of Magic adds new faction - Beastmen. Many users criticized this faction, and you can't disable it. New game mode isn't popular. The highest difficulty is locked, if you don't own this DLC (in case if you care).
- DLC weapons don't drop as loot. You have to craft and upgrade them.

[h1]Elf[/h1]

She deserves a separate category of this review.

- Has a weapon for any task. AP, crowd, DoT. I don't know any other career with the same arsenal.
- Has two DLC weapons with infinite ammo. One isn't much worse than a Longbow, another is better.
- Fast character. Combine this with her weapon arsenal, and you'll get a character who is good in both, melee and ranged. I tested all available careers. Kerillian is better than all the "balanced" careers.
- Waystalker is what I mentioned above + much more ammo, and a career ability that can kill few enemies at once.
- 90% of her arsenal is available for all of her careers. You basically swap between different talent sets. Slayer can't use ranged weapons. Huntsman (ranged) is very squashy, and requires good aiming to use his full potential. Warrior Priest can't use ranged weapons, and most of Saltzpyre melee weapons. 
- I'm not saying that all Elf players are pure evil, but many Elf players are hated for one reason or another. Not even counting what I said above. They often rush, die and DC/blame other players. They are the main source of friendly fire. Not only that, but they f-up more often than others, most likely because Elf allows more mistakes, than other characters. To say it politely, they are not what you would find, if you search for a definition of a "team player". 
- Her premium career, Sister of Thorns, a (?) support role, has SoT-only weapon - Staff. It would have made sense if it was her only type of ranged weapons, but no. She can use bows, javelin etc. 
- Kerillian players are sometimes (often?) toxic, dumb and think that they are super skilled dudes.
- She often speaks like a spoiled Western teen girl. Plus this "mayfly" joke, which I heard 1000 times by now.

I don't know if it is a poor design choice only, or a strong bias. Elf can do it all. She is a better ranged character, than other characters. She is a better well-rounded character, than other characters. Her support and melee careers have more weapon choices, than other characters. Too many reasons to hate the Elf.

Lets be real, its been 5 years and this game is still WAY better than 95% of the existing games out there.

What is good:
-Melee Combat extremely flushed out, extremely satisfying
-Objectives never really overbearing, just gets you moving
-Chaos Wastes is a genius addition to the game and clearly helped retention
-Quickplay = Finding teammates within seconds, even at 3:00 am. Game is bussin.
-Weapon options
-Weapon optimization and balancing 
-Build Freedom

What could be better:
-I think this game is unbelievably refined, and this explains why public feedback has always been so positive and why its left Darktide in its shadow for so long. That said, there are still some changes I would make.
- If red weapons are going to be so difficult to find, then I think there should be some mechanism that distinguishes them besides the stat rolls. I've rolled perfect stats on gold weapons over and over again, making me realize that having red weapons actually does not serve much purpose... Solution: another property? a new (balanced) trait determined by dev team? idk, but reds need a change. 
- Shop very obviously dictates, "good skins, real money. low effort skins, shillings". In all reality, shillings are pretty wack, only to be used for skins that you need dlc for (Bogenhafen, obviously)


Over all though, I love this game. It will always be a staple in my library and I see no reason to switch over to Darktide any time soon.

Warhammer: Vermintide 2 is "easy to pick up, hard to master" realized. Its nearing the end of post launch development, but has had years of tuning and post-launch support. I recommend trying to pick up the ultimate edition during a heavy sale and giving it a go, especially if you enjoy 1st person pve melee combat. Whether youre a casual player that logs in to run a mission or two every night with randoms or the bois, a roguelike enjoyer or one of those filthy masochists that loves spreadsheets and numbers more than the gameplay itself; vermintide has something for you. 

p.s. do not buy winds of magic unless its heavily discounted. good weapons locked behind it for some classes but "weaves" the gameplay element of that dlc are largely ignored by the active community and for good reason. Theyre an exercise in tedium ad nauseam
It's good.

+ Great setting, Warhammer universe  is superb.
+ Deep melee combat system, even after 600+ hours there's still stuff to learn.
+ Lots of classes/weapons to play with all of them beeing viable.
+ Melee combat feels visceral and satisfying. Smashing a dozent rats against the wall with a swing of your great hammer!

- Crafting system is mediocre
- Some cosmetics/weapon skins are cheap reskins of previous ones
- Slow development/balance updates

If you like mastering the skill based melee combat and slaughtering filthy ratmen by the thousands you will enjoy this game, and for this price i can only recommend it!

I'll admit to having only payed .4 hours of this game according to Steam. I enjoyed the art direction, the gameplay and the performance. It was smooth, fun and engaging, and the different player-characters made for a fun way to play...but then I saw the in-game item shop offering me shiny new armor and skins, all cosmetic, all for real money and with a big banner telling me I only had 6 hours for the current deal.

I've never uninstalled a game so fast.

This game has so much potential to be even better than the first, but it's plagued by bugs the developers have ignored for several months now. I would not recommend it IN ITS CURRENT STATE as of 27MAY18.

Mobs can and frequently will spawn in your immediate vicinity, giving you little to no time to counter them.

They'll occasionally hit you through blocks or dodges due to latency, as there are no dedicated servers.

The devs tried to fix an issue with their being too many specials, but instead actually somehow increased both the spawn rate of specials and hordes, including during boss fights. This has led to multiples of each special spawning at once, and hordes chain spawning with specials with no breaks between swarms as intended.

The caster specials (leeches and blightstormers) are able to spawn outside the players view distance, outside of areas where players can reach, and cast their abilities through impassible terrain making it nigh impossible to kill them for excessively long periods of time, all while they continue to attack players.

Overall, these bugs have lead to the game being an RNG fest of whether or not you'll be able to complete a level. It's inconsistent and more frequently frustrating more than it's ever fun, and the devs have shown no interest in fixing any of these issues.

EDIT: Howdy, it's now May 28, 2023 (so 6 years since I wrote this). All those issues have been fixed and tons of new content has been added. Love me Kruber, simple as.

I got into Warhammer thanks to Total War Warhammer 1 and 2. After a friend told me about a first person game set in the world of Warhammer I decided to give it a shot. It was a great decision because Warhammer Vermintide 2 is an amazing game for both fans of Warhammer and people that have no idea or don't care about the setting and lore. The game is similar to Left for Dead, 4 characters go from point A to B while fighting enemies and completing objectives. At the end of some chapters and levels you will fight a boss and or a large horde of enemies.
 The game focuses on melee combat and some gunplay (depending on which character you play as) and one character uses magic. For me I prefer guns and ranged fighting in most games however the melee combat is so good that I have a blast getting up close and personal with great swords, spears and ax's. Aside from the games good range of melee and ranged weapons, you also have a range of powers, hand bombs and power-ups to help you during missions. The game has a large number of missions, bonus content and challenges even if you do not buy any of the DLC's that can be brought fro the store. As of right now, the game is still getting support and content at a slow but steady pace.
 I enjoy the game for a number of reasons. I love the combat, the wide range of weapons, the great visuals and of course the setting. I think that is one of the bigger reasons why I like Vermintide. I fell in love with the Warhammer world thanks to Total War Warhammer and to have a game that takes you right into the World of Warhammer is great. Bouncing back and forth from this game and Total War Warhammer 3 provides endless fun for me.
 I love the five playable characters and the Tavern owner who gives you missions. The banter from the characters is great, although it does help if you know some Warhammer lore beforehand. I am a huge fan of the game, however I do have some issues with this game that will probably never be addressed. The first is the fact that the game is only 4 player Co-Op, not five despite the fact that there are five characters and the game makes it seem like all 5 go out to complete missions together. While 4 player Co-Op is great and it could have been worse (Destiny with 3 player Co-Op outside of cancerous raids comes to mind) it still would make the game even better gameplay and lore wise.
 There is even a character who makes a joke about the lack of 5 player Co-Op multiple times during missions. Another issue I have is lack enemy faction variety. The game does have a wide variety of enemies thanks to the fact that you fight 3 enemy factions. However the game has not added any new enemy factions since the Beastmen came out and new enemies are for the most part never added. At first this is not a big deal, but when you fight Skaven for the 1000th time and when you learn about the massive variety of hostile factions you could and should be fighting (Vampire Counts, other Chaos Gods) you will end up wishing for new factions and enemies to fight.
 Aside from these issues and a few bugs that are not too bothersome, I really enjoy Vermintide and recommend it for Warhammer fans and fans of games like Left for Dead and Payday. May SIGMAR grant this game a long life, and hopefully more Warhammer games.
Wish we had Nurglings all year round in the Keep. Great game though, lots of fun purging the streets of Skaven, Beastmen, and chaos warriors.

Shocked I haven't written this review sooner. One of the best co-op action games I've played, and by far the best first-person melee combat I've ever seen. Some of the best combat in general from any game, to be honest.

[u] Combat and Feel [/u]
The animations, sound design, and general feel of the combat is incredibly satisfying. Every impact and cleave is sold perfectly, and carving through hordes of foes is extremely fun. Even the ranged combat is good, solid hit registration and aiming. Each character and career gives a different style of play that can then differ further based on weapon preference, all of which are viable and most feel just as great to use, as far as I've seen.

[u] Difficulty and Co-op [/u]
There are multiple difficulties, and the higher ones are significantly challenging. I HIGHLY recommend playing with friends, but even just playing with bots can be fun, especially since the AI characters use the gear and skills that you have equipped on them. I've found it's much more preferable to play with friends or with AI than random players, at least queuing solo.

[u] Progression and Gear [/u]
The progression is solid, earning a pick of 3 talents every five levels on a character. You can change these talents anytime between missions. You earn stronger gear the more you collect loot from said missions, and there's a crafting system that lets you scrap unwanted gear and forge the kind of gear you want.

[u] Different Gamemodes [/u]
Chaos Wastes creates an entire new way to play beyond the campaign and DLCs (all of which are worth it if you love the core game imo). It creates a longer, roguelike journey that adds some unique progression. A ton of fun, and adds even more replayability.

[u] Characters and Writing [/u]
The characters themselves are great, too. The dialogue writing is superb, probably some of the best I've seen, and the characters are deceptively well-developed. They have so many interactions that I'm still occasionally hearing new ones even after hundreds of hours.

[u] Performance [/u]
The game looks incredible and runs well, even on my older PC. No major issues.

Having played Vermintide: The End Times, I can summarize my experience with Vermintide 2 in two thoughts - the game is an upgrade in almost every way possible (gameplay, UI, character interactions, enemy and level variety, you name it). Despite Darktide being in the works, the game has been receiving updates, bugfixes, new content etc. However, due to a history of developer misinformation and a lot of hiccups regarding previous content updates, the DLCs get their well deserved negative receptions. Stuff like Weaves and the Versus Mode trailer are thorns in their side that often get mentioned in the community. Devs adjusted their approach and remain silent until they're 100% sure the content can and will be delivered.

The game is in my eyes still worth buying. It's one of the best co-op games out there with an enjoyable skill curve and difficulty settings that reward actual practice and skill. Other co-op titles come and go, but V2 remains strong and genuinely enjoyable (and with a playerbase)

If you do not own this game in the year 2023:
Don't worry, this isn't Darktide, with its mass of bugs and general lack of polish. This is what Darktide was intending to be, and the reason why there is so much hype surrounding Darktide in general.
The reason why is because Vermintide 2 is good. The difficulty is well tuned, the ratman hordes are without number and you're forced to fight them in good old fashioned melee combat. Ammo is hard to come by in higher difficulties and the infinite ammo class has to carefully manage their magic or they'll detonate with the force of a 22 kiloton bomb. Enemy variety keeps you on your toes, and yes, there are specials that can pin you. You can dodge these attacks with a well timed sidestep or backstep, but work together or die alone. Bosses are roaming, challenging and plentiful in a similar way to the way Back 4 Blood does it, only there's a big boss at the end of each act.
I haven't touched the DLCs for the game, but there's plenty to do even with only the base game.

Warhammer: Vermintide 2 is an outstanding first-person melee combat game developed and published by Fatshark. It is the sequel to the critically acclaimed Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide, and it builds upon the strong foundation laid by its predecessor. Set in the Warhammer Fantasy universe, Vermintide 2 is a cooperative game that pits you and up to three other players against hordes of Skaven and Chaos warriors.

One of the things that immediately stands out about Vermintide 2 is its impressive graphics and art style. The attention to detail is incredible, and the environments are richly detailed and immersive. The sound design is also top-notch, with every strike of your weapon and every screech of a rat-man sounding appropriately visceral and impactful.

But where Vermintide 2 really shines is in its gameplay. The melee combat system is deep and satisfying, with a variety of weapons and playstyles to choose from. Whether you prefer to smash through enemies with a hammer or slash them apart with a sword, Vermintide 2 has you covered. The game also introduces new hero classes, each with its unique set of abilities and weapons, providing even more gameplay variety.

The enemy AI in Vermintide 2 is also worth mentioning. The Skaven and Chaos warriors are relentless and unpredictable, forcing you to stay on your toes and adapt to the situation on the fly. The game is challenging but not unfair, and with proper coordination and teamwork, you and your allies can emerge victorious from even the toughest battles.

Vermintide 2 also features a loot system, rewarding you with new weapons, trinkets, and other items as you progress through the game. These items can be upgraded and customized to suit your playstyle, providing an additional layer of depth and replayability.

The game's campaign mode takes you through a variety of different environments, each with its unique challenges and set-pieces. The story itself is serviceable but not particularly memorable, but it's not really the main draw of the game. The real fun comes from the gameplay itself, and Vermintide 2 delivers that in spades.

One thing to note is that Vermintide 2 is primarily designed as a cooperative game, and while it is possible to play solo with AI companions, the game is best experienced with other players. Thankfully, the game has a robust matchmaking system that makes it easy to find other players to team up with.

Overall, Warhammer: Vermintide 2 is an excellent game that improves upon its predecessor in almost every way. With its deep and satisfying melee combat, challenging enemy AI, and immersive environments, it's a must-play for fans of cooperative action games. Highly recommended!

Best first-person melee action game made to date. Runs well on Steam Deck. Great solo, better co-op, DLCs are fantastic, fun community, huge build variety. An incredible game that's well worth your money and your time if you enjoy intense melee action. I'm 185 hours in and looking forward to spending another 200 hours getting better.

The only real downside is the lack of in-game information about core stats and mechanics. Everything from the duration of abilities and consumables to the crit chance on your weapons and the categories of enemies you'll fight need to be learned out-of-game. And good luck finding pickups without looking them up lol 

The environments are amazing. The base game with free updates is 18 campaign maps + the roguelite Chaos Wastes mode, and the three content DLCs (Winds, Bogenhafen, Ubersreik) add an additional 6 campaign maps. Campaign levels are almost universally fantastic from both visual and game design perspectives. Enemies are varied and interesting. 

Progression is a little weird. There IS an item level mechanic but it's only relevant as you level up; after your initial time with the game you'll ignore it. Then there's a grind for top-rarity (red) weapons, and you'll want to get all five characters to level 30 so you have build options. 

But honestly, the real progression curve is your personal skill, far more than in comparable games. An expert player with their level 5 perk and base rarity items can carry a team on legendary, while a new player is mostly useless even with a perfect level 35 build and perfect 300-power red gear in every slot. Gameplay is about map knowledge, understanding the team dynamics, knowing enemy attack patterns, mastering stamina and dodge management, and mastering the physics of your weapons. The heavy attack on Warpriest's greathammer arcs up at the end, whereas Footknight's stays flat, and accounting for that makes the difference between lifesaving headshot damage and getting killed by a Stormvermin.

Anyway. Play Vermintide. It slaps.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

It's literally Left 4 Dead with RPG elements. There, I said it. I can't grasp how people develop an interest in this garbage, especially the story and world. Every map just drags on for too long and encourages me to leave my team behind just so I can rush all the objectives and run to the end on my own to escape this boring nightmare. The players who play on the easier difficulties are also majorly braindead. I usually exaggerate for the sake of comedy but this time I'm actually serious. They take too long to move forward and stretch the long maps even more. By the time I've reached the end, they haven't even made it halfway through most of the time. And if a special infected... oh excuse me, I mean an elite incapacitates me, these low IQ players have the audacity to blame me for running off on my own. Pardon me for not wanting to spend half an hour on every goddamn map. Move your asses and I won't have run off alone. Once more I'm confronted with the sad reality that Europeans are indeed idiots. I was fortunate enough to find an Asian lobby, unsurprisingly they managed to play like athletes. Thankfully it's possible to finish maps by just having one player reach the end so I didn't have to rely on intelligent players too much.

Let's get to the core problem now. Once again I'm tormented with grindy achievements. Being forced to level up each character shouldn't be as tedious as it is. No matter which map or difficulty you choose, you will always get the standard amount of experience. You can get collectibles to boost that but getting them will often take up more time than it's actually worth. There is also the issue of the bots being nearly as braindead as the average player base and simply refusing to pick up items. So what does this mean? It means I had to grind the shortest map a hundred times. I checked out some speedruns to assist in this endeavor and can confidently say that I could cut the top 5 if I submitted a run of my own. Fortunately the map I picked could be soloed easily which is a luxury not many of them have. Most of the time you need to accumulate all players in a spot to be able to proceed unless you're playing with bots. The only reason I occasionally decided to play with other people was so I could join a game in progress and hopefully get some quick experience, without much effort. It worked a dozen of times and was certainly more fun than grinding the same map on repeat. That's where I noticed another problem, however. Which is that a lot of these maps are indistinguishable. I had segments memorized but couldn't tell for the life of me on which map they occurred. Sometimes my brain would stitch together several maps into one because they're essentially all the same.

At least L4D doesn't rely on gimmicks that are introduced in this game and has a lot of memorability. Even after multiple years of not playing it, I could launch it and still remember what segments follow on every map. And the fact that the higher difficulties in this game demand you to grind loot chest for better equipment or fiddle around with the crafting system is just absurd. The skill tree is also hit or miss. Some perks are genuinely useful while others barely affect your gameplay. Any item stat or character perk that boosted my movement speed was always welcome because the characters in this game are just strolling through every map at snail's pace. What quickly infuriated me is how the momentum of your movement speed isn't carried over into your jumps. You can run at the speed of sound but if you jump you turn into a snail until you touch the ground again. And I'm almost certain that the developers did this intentionally since a lot of these features that cripple you can be disabled via the skill tree. There is a perk that prevents enemies from slowing you down when being hit. Thank you very much for this perk, too bad you decided to give it to me when I'm just 5 level-ups away from being done with this character. Either way, I'm finally done with this shit. Took me 50 hours of my precious life but I'm finally out of this hellhole. I wish the rest of the community a pleasant time in this hellscape that you declare a game. Warhammer has officially made it to my blacklist with this glorious entry.
This is the greatest 4-person Co-Op game ever made

The following review is connected to my review of Dark Tide

After years of play, this game has cemented itself as my favorite of the modern era. It is filled with content, charm, a world with so much lore it'll make your head explode, and some characters that are full of quips and history, spanning eons.

It's strong points:
- 5 characters, each with 4 variation classes each (last one is still coming for Sienna)
- Each character has a wide selection of weapons, both ranged and melee. The sheer quantity of weapons creates diverse experiences for each playthrough, which allowed me to stretch my gametime to around 300 hours. A very good return for the price.
- Graphics are beautiful. Allows for a unique tension and atmosphere that few other games can come close to. It all feels very grim and off, like you are in a magical beautiful place thats being contaminated by evil forces, which you must defeat endlessly.
- The dialogue between characters brings some levity and humor to an otherwise bleak game. The relationships between the characters really make you feel like theyve known each other for a long time, and that they are used to facing absolutely mind breaking horrors. This could've easily been a Lord of the Rings game (still hoping for a mod someday, or that Fat Shark gets the rights to LOTR...)
- Replayability up the wahoo. The Chaos Wastes added a great RPG rogue-like system that makes you actually feel the difference between weapons and abilities, instead of just slightly more damage or more stamina (chain lightning ftw)


Weak points:
- Game becomes a little repetitive (300 hours will do that), and while you can keep grinding forever to obtain red weapons for all characters, I don't really feel any incentive to because the difference between a gold weapon and a red weapon is really quite minor once they are at 300 power (max). It's like they created a system that is designed to make people come back for grinding, but the actual pay off is quite limited... Luckily, the actual gameplay is of such quality that the grind isnt a bother.. but the gameplay itself is more rewarding than the loot and weapon maximization.

- This game feels like it was made with love, but that it's still not everything it could be. The 4 player structure, while it does create for compelling teamwork and makes you feel like you are part of an actual team, forces the game structure into the "go from point A to point B and pull the lever" sort of gameplay that Left4Dead was designed for. It does manage to pull this off quite well, so I can't fault it for that, but I feel like this game could be cracked wide open and more potential could be manifested. The chaos wastes kind of prove it. I could see this game be a Diablo-esque, or perhaps moreso like a Borderlands looting adventure game.

I've been playing Warhammer Inquistor lately, and my early attempts at playing it left me a little wanting. But having played Dark Tide and Vermintide, I now see the greater diversity of the game, the lore, the enemy types, and Dark Tide now makes me fee like I'm playing a FPS Inquisitor.. and it just made me want more out of Dark Tide and Vermintide. Both have their Diablo-esque equivalent, Chaosbane and Inquisitor, but both Dark Tide and Vermintide seem a little show about introducing diversity of enemies that exist in their universes. The minotaurs were a welcome DLC enemy, but there could be so much more that could really push these games to the next level.

And then I came back to it after a few friends bought it on sale recently, I think I've sunk 30 hours in the past 2 weeks already. I've gotten much more interested in the higher difficulties along with learning the mechanics in more depth than I ever had before. Chaos wastes keeps the game fresh with its rogue-like features and the AI Director keeps every playthrough from feeling the same. The gear grind isn't too grindy besides getting the veteran gear later on after hitting max gear level. And the gameplay is top tier.

Latest patch (Tower of Treachery) seems to have broken multiple things making the game incredibly frustrating, if not impossible to play sometimes.

- Enemies spawning on top of players or in the open, as in everything from single enemies to even entire horde waves just appear from thin air 2 meters in front of you instead of spawning hidden behind walls or buildings or corners.
- A lot of enemies seem to spawn behind you now (and again, not behind you and a bit further away hidden behind a fence or corner as they usually would, no, they spawn in the open right behind you and ready to attack) leading to you taking hits from behind even though you just checked to see if there's any enemies a mere second ago.
- Enemies don't attack players properly anymore, as in they will go past one player that is close to them and currently not fighting anything (so their slots should not be filled) in order to attack another player that is further away.
- One of the most extreme examples of this that I've had was some enemies that spawned close to the party but instead of attacking any of us, they pathed AHEAD to the center of the next room (they literally walked through me to get there) and after they reached the center of the next room, that's when our location seemed to "click" for them so they started pathing properly back towards us.

Specials behave weirdly as well:

- Globadiers will now almost always throw globes from behind cover (behind walls or buildings, usually outside of where players can walk) without requiring any line of sight to the players so they're impossible to prevent.
- Assassins will get stuck a lot more often doing that thing where they pick a 1-2 metre path and they just go back and forth really quickly before eventually teleporting away.
- Blightstormers seem to spawn way further from the players now and they also seem to spend more time far away after they have spawned and I've even seen them cast storms on random areas where there's no players. For example on a Garden of Morr run, we (the party) were getting close to the guaranteed ammo box that spawns on top of a coffin a bit after the first tome and there was a blightstormer spawned somewhere around the little maze where the first grimoire is (judging by the sound) and after a few moments he cast a storm in the large open space that is AFTER the ammo box, even though there was nobody there as none of us were even at the ammo box yet.

Bots are also similarly way dumber than before the patch (all of these bugs would happen before as well but you used to see it once every few games whereas now it seems to happen multiple times in a single map):

- They get stuck very frequently in multiple spots and refuse to move, it happens frequently in "checkpoint" style areas of the map where you can't backtrack but it's not exclusive to those areas, I've even seen them get stuck on incredibly small geometry elements such as rocks or pavement corners in otherwise completely open stretches of the map.
- They can't pick up some books properly anymore. There's always some books that are hard to reach for them so they usually just "try" for a few seconds and then pick them up from a distance, however, this patch (ironically) seems to have made those books even faster (they pick them up instantly) while also making the easy books impossible. Now when you tell a bot to pick up a simple book (one where you can easily walk next to and pick up), they just become rooted to the ground in the spot they were when you gave the order and they don't get unstuck until you cancel the order somehow (order another bot or pick it up yourself).
- Revives also seem incredibly difficult for them, previously they would sort of "judge" the situation and revive if it was deemed safe enough. Now, when someone dies close to a bot, the bot will immediately attempt a revive no matter the situation, however, not only that but they will also cancel the revive as soon as they start it. And as a bonus, it seems that if they managed to do this weird attempted revive, they will no longer revive that hero even if there's no more enemies present (I have seen it happen with both players or bots being downed).
- The bug where they pull out a ranged weapon and then get stuck like that and never switch back until they die seems to happen way more often than before as well (most frequently on Kerillian bot).

All of these bugs have occurred as both client and host, in both solo games as well as partially or completely full games so it's not an issue with the connection or syncing between players. I understand that every patch comes with some bugs (as is the case with every game), however, there seems to be something fundamentally broken that affects multiple things and with a big impact too. If I were to guess there's a problem with pathfinding in general or maybe the way AI (enemies and bots) determine the position of certain entities (such as players).

As it stands I would unfortunately recommend avoiding the game for now.

I'll change this review since it was made not long after launch and doesn't reflect the current state of the game. 

As I said previously, this game is overall a masterpiece. Playing Left4Dead in one of the best rendition of the Warhammer fantasy universe at the time, with amazing gameplay to go with it and countless other qualities, it's just great fun. 

But I won't change the review to a recommend.

Originally, I thumbed it down because the connection stability was awful and never being able to progress due to this almost made me go crazy. It's pretty much fixed now. But a whole other issue replaced it altogether : the game is now a grindfest. You'll go through the entire content unlocking heaps of useless bits and bobs to process through annoying menus and systems in the hopes of getting something decent to upgrade your characters, eventually repeating levels over and over again until you hate it in order get the good stuff. You can't even be mindless about it, the game is hard, the levels are long, losing a map feels like you've wasted so much time, yet winning and getting crumbs feels like a slap in the  face. 

It is all, of course, avoidable through microtransactions, which is very much the point. And no, this being the current industry standard is no excuse. 

If you get it for a big discount with the intention of doing a playthrough with friends then go for it. But if you intend to complete and unlock everything, avoid it unless you like pain.

Warhammer Vermintide 2 is a thrilling and action-packed first-person co-op game that takes place in the dark and gritty world of Warhammer Fantasy, this game offers players a chance to experience the brutal and unforgiving battles between the armies of Chaos and the Empire, as well as the verminous Skaven who seek to overrun all of humanity.

The game boasts an impressive array of characters to choose from, each with their unique set of skills and abilities. Players can choose to play as one of the five heroes - Sienna Fuegonasus, Bardin Goreksson, Kerillian, Victor Saltzpyre, or Markus Kruber - and work together to battle hordes of Skaven and Chaos warriors.

The game's combat system is smooth and responsive, making it easy to switch between weapons and abilities to suit different situations. The game also offers a range of difficulty levels, which makes it accessible to both casual and hardcore gamers. The harder difficulties provide a satisfying challenge, but the game never feels unfair or unbalanced.

One of the highlights of Warhammer Vermintide 2 is its stunning visuals and detailed environments. The game's world is richly detailed, with plenty of hidden secrets to discover and explore. The game's sound design is equally impressive, with atmospheric music and sounds that immerse players in the game's dark and dangerous world.

Overall, Warhammer Vermintide 2 is an excellent co-op game that offers a thrilling and challenging experience for fans of the Warhammer universe. The game's smooth combat, stunning visuals, and immersive sound design make it a must-play for anyone looking for a visceral and exciting co-op experience.

Update 533 horas: Despues de tanto tiempo sin jugarlo decidi instalarlo para probar el ultimo update y la verdad que despues de tanto Destiny 2 y Fortnite, Vermintide 2 me resulta aburrido. Supongo que termina pasando, pero el juego se resume a hacer click, click, click para pegar y click, click, click para esquivar constantemente. Igual sin lugar a dudas lo sigo recomendando pero supongo que el mood sci fi me va mas ahora. Asi que cierro una etapa definiendolo como un juegazo en primera persona de modo horda, pero que se quedo corto a la hora de innovar y la verdad que hay un limite a las skins que uno quiere comprar para los mismos personajes que ni siquiera ves en el juego. Tal vez si fuera tercera persona podria ser mas interesante, pero por ahora lo juego un rato mas y lo desinstalo probablemente por un largo tiempo. 

Despues de mas de 300 horas de juego Vermintide 2 sigue siendo mi eleccion favorita en Steam.. Super adictivo con eventos que te dejan regalos, una enorme variedad de armas y estilos de combate en cada una de las 5 facciones. Realmente una maravilla de producto. Y encima no para de crecer. Pronto van a agregar a las bestias y eso le va a dar una renovacion a la prediccion en combate. Tengo mis serias dudas de que me canse de jugarlo por demasiado tiempo. No puedo evitar decir que la curva de aprendizaje de cada personaje es larga y hay un periodo intermedio en el que parece que no das pie con bola, pero una vez superado llegas al final de los escenarios legendarios sin mucho problema a menos que seas un loco arriesgado o que no juegues en equipo. No lo recomiendo porque expulsar a un miembro que no juega en equipo sigue siendo parte del sistema. Asi que como la practica hace al maestro no puedo dejar de recomendar probar todos los personajes pero especializarte en uno hasta que te aburra antes de pasar al siguiente. UN JUEGAZO!!

I bought this game with all the DLC included, now its all included with skins - making the 'Content Bundle' more expensive because of the added content. 

You can equip items of varying rarity which you can't pay to win which is odd in a modern game but very welcoming. 

Expect new players that don't know what they are doing, though if you are going to be one of them yourself just ask your teammates. Friendly bunch that you party up with usually. Has a surprisingly quick, active online que times. 

Though I can hear others say, is it as fun as when Left 4 Dead was in its hay-day? 

This game is super underrated and recommend it to anyone that enjoys that type of gameplay, check out gameplay just in case if you're on the fence about this one.

Well, well, well, look who's back with another hilarious review! That's right, it's me, your favorite game influencer, and I'm here to talk about Vermintide 2. Now, I know what you're thinking, "But Kraut, you're not even a real gamer!" And you're absolutely right, I'm not. I just play games to write reviews that get likes. It's a tough job, but someone's gotta do it.

So, let's talk about Vermintide 2. I played this game with my friends Julian and Dennis, and let me tell you, it was an experience. Dennis is a pro gamer, and he's very ambitious. He's the kind of guy who takes gaming so seriously that he eats, sleeps, and breathes it. Meanwhile, Julian is a hacker who's fascinated with the game's technology and how to hack it. I'm pretty sure he spends more time trying to break the game than actually playing it.

But despite all of that, we had a great time playing Vermintide 2. The game is intense, challenging, and a lot of fun. We spent hours fighting off hordes of rat-like creatures and exploring the game's intricate world. And let me tell you, it's a good thing I had Dennis on my team because I'm pretty sure he carried us through most of the game.

Julian, on the other hand, spent most of his time trying to find ways to hack the game. I'm pretty sure he's already working on a way to teleport through walls and take down bosses with a single hit. But hey, that's just Julian being Julian.

Overall, I would definitely recommend Vermintide 2 to anyone who loves action-packed, cooperative games. It's a blast to play with friends, and the game's technology is so fascinating that even Julian can't resist trying to break it. And as for me, well, I'm just here for the likes. So, if you enjoyed this review, be sure to smash that like button and subscribe for more hilarious game reviews from yours truly.

Before I start my review, some background stats. I own every DLC, I've put in around 500 hours into this game, completing every single level on at least legendary difficulty, and with every character, and gaining every single achievement. Also, TLDR at the bottom.

[b]Story[/b]:
You play as one of the Ubersreik's five (or four, it doesn't matter), the protagonists from the last game. This game picks up after the end of the first game, and the main antagonists (the skaven) have made some new alliances via the Norsemen. These brutal vikings and ratmen have teamed up and caused mayham throughout the land, and it is up you and your friends to make sure they don't succeed.

[b]Gameplay[/b]:
This game a co-op oriented PVE hack 'n slash, where the goal is to reach the end of the level by with certain challenges and objectives. You can play as one of 5 characters and, at the time of writing this review, a total of 19 subclasses. They differ greatly, from a mage blasting enemies with fire from afar, to the mighty slayer that has foregone (almost) all ranged weaponry in favor of more melee weapons.
Enemy- and item placements are randomized every game, making every run distinct from the last. The enemies consist of the aforementioned skaven, norscans and the later added beastmen. Very much akin to left4dead, they include specialised enemies that can disable a player, or big bosses the size of small houses. You will need to work together to increase your chances of survival.
Besides the 13 vanilla missions, a plethora of new missions have been added (almost all of them for free). These include old missions brought back from vermintide 1, trips to a castle from a former necromancer, and more. Alternative gamemodes like weaves (regular missions, shuffled, on steroids) or chaos waste expeditions (a rogue-light gamemode that gives you boons ranging from explosive bullets to literally thor's lightning) greatly expand the variety of missions this game has to offer.

[b]Atmosphere[/b]:
Fatshark has outdone themselves with the atmosphere in this game. The imperials cities, burning hamlets, pristine elven forrests, Nurgle infested sewers or gothic castles all add flavor to the game. Combine this with the witty banter between the characters and a beautiful musical score (especially the newer missions!) and I have yet to play a game that rivals the immersion this game has to offer into the Warhammer Fantasy world. 

[b]Community and teamplay[/b]:
Why dedicate a whole segment to the community? Because you need to co-operate with your teammates. Luckily, the community is as great as they get. Matchmaking is quick, and it often takes mere seconds to find a game. Furthermore, crashes are infrequent if not non-existent. You don't need to have a group of friends to play this game with others. Matches will fill in quick. And if you don't want to play with strangers, you can always host your own private game, where the very capable AI takes control of the other 3 characters that will stick close to you.

[b]Conclusion[/b]: 
Pros:
+ Fun, fast paced combat
+ Beautifully crafted levels
+ Fun characters with witty banter
+ Stable matchmaking
+ Free levels

Cons:
- frequency of content drops
- Can't think of any more

TLDR
If you want a fun, fast-paced game, with mages and knights, that you can play with friends, this is the game for you. Free levels, funny banter and bloodshed aplenty!

This is the BEST fps co-op game I have ever played. This game has so much content including maps, heroes and careers, and of course weapons. I'll talk about them all. 

Firstly maps: 13 regular campaign maps with 4 free dlc maps (3 Return to Drachenfels maps and 1 (so far) Trail of Treachery map) and 7 paid dlc maps. Each map can take between 10-20 minutes to beat depending on the difficulty. Every map also contains collectibles that make levels harder but give better rewards at the end. No 2 runs will ever be the same: monsters, specials, and elites can spawn in different combinations and numbers.

Heroes and Careers:
Each hero and their careers bring many benefits to a team. Any hero can fill any role at any time but some do things better than others. With 15 default classes (3 classes per hero) to choose, you have plenty of options. The default classes fit how each character progress through the story in Helmgart. There are currently 4 available dlc careers available that progress the characters even further and I would 100% recommend them. (p.s. the dlc careers go on sale frequently on Steam). Pick a hero and career you like and get slaying.

Weapons:
The melee weapons in Vermintide 2 all feel really good. Like the heroes that use them, every weapon can do everything, it's just that some are better than others at certain things (exp: a Great Hammer destroys small enemies with ease while a Spear does lots of damage to a monster). Vermintide 2 also features a variety of ranged weapons like: javelins, bows, rifles, shotguns, pistols, and flamethrowers. Every weapon has traits and skins to suit your playstyle. Get some weapons that you like, learn how to use them, get slaying, simple as that.
(p.s. if you buy this game, don't listen to those that give you crap about your weapons or other gear, everyone plays the game differently and you are no exception ;)

DLC:
Back to Ubersriek:
Back to Ubersriek has 3 main missions from Vermintide 1 and a new secret mission and gives each hero a new weapon. 
9/10

Shadows over Bogenhafen:
Shadows over Bogenhafen has 2 main missions and adds new weapons skins for all the heroes' weapons.
8/10

Winds of Magic:
Winds of Magic has 1 new main mission and gives each hero a new weapon and skins. It also adds the Beastmen as new enemies, a harder difficulty called Cataclysm, and Weave missions. Imo the Weave missions aren't that great but the Beastmen enemies are a great addition.
7/10

The Curse of Drachenfels:
This free dlc takes players to Castle Drachenfels from Vermintide 1 with 3 new missions and 1 new boss. Fight your way through the "abandoned" halls and stop the evil from within.
9/10

The Chaos Wastes:
This free dlc allows players to go to the Chaos Wastes. There you must complete expeditions to find The Citadel of Eternity while levels are warped by the 4 Chaos gods. This mode acts like a rouge-like version of the main game. Beating a level makes you stronger, losing means you have to restart your expedition. This mode will challenge you like nothing in the main game. Only the bravest can travel the Chaos Wastes. Happy hunting.
10/10

Final Note:
Like most co-op games, it's better with friends but public lobbies are good to. The folks at Fatshark usually have this game and its dlc's on sale but tbh it is worth getting it at full price. This game has been out for 5 years now and is still fully supported. Fatshark is one of the few companies that actually listens to its player base and is worthy of that praise. Feel free to add me on Steam if you want someone to play with.

I recommend getting this when it's free.

Amazing game so far and there's lots of fun to be had--fun of all kinds, both for casual players and sweats/hardcore players, etc.  I'm also extremely pleased to see that they still update the game and I really hope they continue to do so, EVERYTHING seems so well done and it plays so smoothly for me.

The only thing so far that I wish they would add is a little more variety with cosmetics--body cosmetics specifically.  The ones that you can buy with shillings are just recolors mainly, which can be fine, but that's all there is (besides the $ cosmetics).  Even in the Holy Grail cosmetic dlc that I got for example, when I started looking at the body cosmetics, I'm pretty sure that they're simply just recolors--nothing new, and that's something you have to pay for with real money.  Also, you have to do some decently long challenges to unlock them, which, I didn't think they'd be as long as they were and I was surprised there were any challenges at all but... maybe they could adjust that in the future.

I also hope they can update the Winds of Magic dlc because it sounds like it has a lot of cool content like maps, weapons, (especially) cosmetics, enemies, and so forth, but every time I see something about it, it's negative--all focused on how the fun is sucked out of the dlc.  Besides these couple things though, the game is great in every other part.

-3/19/23 Review-
Oh man, I am very happy with how they've treated the game since I last played. Before the game was laggy, unbalanced, and terrible to play with other people. Now, they have worked on the actual feel of the game, and made the game not only fun again, but also balanced. They made the game better overall! They are remaining consistent on the updates and patches, and generally are paying more attention to who they listen to. Yeah, they're still doing things I'm not happy about, such as having DLC for your DLC, but I'm just happy the game is finally playable. Now if only we can get the PVP game mode they said they were working on...

-Old Review-
I really was late to Vermintide (The first one) game, but I became a fan of the advanced melee combat, and the ability to blitzkrieg though Man the Ramparts, and I spent a lot of hours on it, but Vermintide 2, it's a mess. 

As I said, I was late to the party for Vermintide, so I was not around when the bugs and unplayable game-play was a thing. So keep that in mind.

Vermintide 2 is, as I stated a train wreck. There were problems between players screens (Such as a door being open on my  screen, but not on my friends screen, and a lot of bombs were thrown in our faces because of this :/) Also, some of the characters were broken, or just unplayable. There was some questionable actions that the devs made that just made me confused. Like removing potion stacking, or adding only 3 (or 4, I can't remember as I write this) maps from the original Vermintide, and they were the least liked maps. There is also making the PVP game-mode, just to find that it was buggy, unbalanced, and was made to milk more money. 

Some of their ideas were cool, I'll give them that. And the lore, while not totally accurate, it was impressive how much they got accurate. The characters are amazing, and will forever stay with me!

Unfortunately, the cons outweigh the pros in this case, and it really disappointed me. I will always love Vermintide 1, but because of this, it left a bad taste in my mouth for the devs, so I don't even play V1 anymore. Thus, a negative review.

Cautious recommend: it's beautiful, easy to get into, and light fun, but (despite not being free to play) is loaded with F2P-style dirty monetization and addiction tactics. Bugs are occasionally annoying, but problems mostly don't reoccur if you just repeat things.

Not much story but plenty of atmosphere in its highly developed dark fantasy setting, this game is all action with short, linear levels swarming with varied, interesting enemies who come at you in waves and occasionally require teamwork between your 4 squad members. Best played with friends, but still ok with bots and random matchmaking.

Worth a few bucks and a few hours, but don't let it trick you into forming a habit of playing whether you're having lots of fun or not, which is what some of these design features seem intended to do.

Warhammer: Vermintide 2 is without a doubt some of the most fun I've had in any game I've played. It is a co-op melee-oriented horde game with some of the best combat in any game out there. There are five characters who all have four classes, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. You pick a combination of melee and ranged weapons, perks, and supplementary gear to bring into the battle against hordes of enemies. You play in teams of four, and teamwork is key for survival. The game has a wide range of difficulty options and can be fun no matter how easy or hard you like things to be. It is set in the Warhammer Fantasy universe, but you don't need to know anything about it to enjoy the game. I had no interest in Warhammer Fantasy or 40k before playing this game, but my friends convinced me to pick it up as a fun co-op game and I fell in love with it. I certainly don't have a lot of time in the game as of writing this, but I feel like I could keep playing it forever and never get bored. I would rate this game a strong 9/10, maybe even a 10/10 depending on how I am feeling.

The first topic I would like to cover is melee combat. When it comes to first person melee combat I genuinely don't believe anything tops this game. An argument could be made for some games like Chivalry, and I will concede that some other games do have absolutely stellar melee combat, however this is best in class for PvE games. Every character has a wide array of weapons to choose from, and each weapon brings something different to the table. Every melee weapon has a light string, a heavy string, and a push-stab. Some weapons also have an extra utility attack such as the rapier's pistol which can be fired while blocking. Each attack has its own properties such as varying levels of cleave, stagger, and armor piercing. This means that you can chain together combos using different attacks from light and heavy strings to find the most optimized way to deal with any situation. Some weapons are simple like the rapier or the executioner sword, light string for hordes, heavy string for single targets. Some are more complicated where the combo depends heavily on enemy density and enemy type.

As I just talked about melee weapons, I feel that ranged weapons would be a good next topic. Melee weapons are the cornerstone of your gameplay, and ranged weapons are usually there to compliment your melee weapon. Ranged weapons require ammo, which inherently makes you use them more conservatively. However, every character has access to a ranged career that greatly increases the power of ranged weapons as well as helps to lessen the restrictions they have in exchange for some melee power. Though, even as a ranged career, you still will find yourself using your melee weapon quite often, mostly for self-defense.

For the last bit of information before I talk about combat as a whole: enemies. There are many different enemies, each with their strengths and weaknesses. There are four different types of enemies: generic, elites, specials, and monsters. You will have likely heard these terms before from other horde shooters if you are familiar with them. Elites are powerful enemies that demand attention before they are allowed to deal too much damage to the party. Specials are disabler enemies that can temporarily incapacitate an ally. They are easy to manage in isolation, but hard to deal with in the chaos. If they catch you, an ally will have to help you get the special off of you. Monsters are the bosses of this game, all present unique threats that you have to learn to deal with in order to cleanly take them out.

Now, finally, onto the flow of combat. Vermintide takes place in missions on preset maps. The enemy spawns are random, so you will never have the exact same experience twice. The levels are generally linear with little events along the way you have to clear before proceeding. The flow of combat is extremely fun and rewarding. You will have to play combat very actively; constantly dodging in and out of enemy ranges while blocking attacks and delivering blows of your own. All the while, keeping an eye out for ranged and special threats and dealing with them before they are able to disrupt your team. The extensive combo system allows each weapon to have its own niche while also allowing you to have a lot of tools at your disposal in the form of various types of attacks. Having enough knowledge and skill will allow you to deal with nearly any situation by yourself, no matter how impossible the odds may seem.

As stated before, teamwork is core to success. While you can do a lot on your own, everything is manageable as a team. The enemy diversity ensures that no one weapon can do everything and that every person can have their own role in combat. Weapons that are good at cleaving hordes may not be able to keep up against armored targets; Weapons with a lot of defensive capabilities may not be able to kill enemies very efficiently. Specials work to distract you and disable your allies, opening up the more powerful elites to take advantage of the distraction. This helps encourage everyone to watch out for each other and gives a really rewarding feeling of teamwork.

Speaking of allies, next up are the characters. Each character has four careers (Sienna only has three at the moment, but her last career is on the way). These careers have varying stats, weapons options, and their own perk tree. This allows for a lot of playstyles for every character; you are bound to find something you like. Every character is incredibly charming and I found myself really falling in love with this charming band of heroes. They are the perfect example of their respective stereotype: Bardin is a gregarious and prideful dwarf on the path of self-discovery. Kruber is a loyal and light-hearted mercenary who does his best to do what he thinks is right. Kerillian is a moody and enigmatic elf who looks down on everyone else but secretly cares about all of them. Saltzpyre is an eccentric and overly-confident zealot brimming with holy fury. Lastly, Sienna is a carefree and impulsive wizard who would love nothing more than to just let everything burn. The game is brimming with banter and exchanges between the characters in a way that really communicates each character's captivating personality.

To finish things up, I'll cover everything that wasn't in a previous section. The overall balance of the game is quite good. Almost nothing in this game is bad, every option is perfectly usable. Some choices are stronger than others, but everything is able to get the job done. The game has a lot of DLCs, though none of them are really core to the experience. Most of them add maps and weapons, others add each character's fourth DLC career. You can buy all of them, none of them, or just pick out what you want. As for cosmetics, there are paid and earned cosmetics. The earned cosmetics are acquired by completing specific challenges on the respective career. The hub is a fun place to run around and parkour, you can freely test out weapons and skills as well as hear a lot of banter between the characters. There are some alternate gamemodes like the Chaos Wastes, a roguelite mode. This game really is endless fun, especially with friends. If you have the money, I highly suggest picking it up.

Caveat - bring friends. As in, a full premade or almost full. Playing with strangers is entirely unfeasible. 
As an example, I tried to queue up for a match and was put into one that was in-progress. I was put in the position the bot was in, which happened to be surrounded by a giant horde. The other players were a thousand miles away, apparently trying to run away from the bot for fun?
This type of experience is very common. People will also leave randomly, causing the game to end because they happened to be the one hosting it. 

Also, there is an in-game voicechat. Turn it off if you play with strangers - it's unhelpful and not even in a funny way. I didn't realise there was voicechat until I was in the middle of the light-hearted anniversary "bar crawl" mission and some guy started taking it way too seriously, bossing me and my friends around like his life depended on it. It was on the second easiest difficulty.

Did you bring 3 friends? Good, then it's a fun hack-n-slash game that doesn't take itself too seriously. The combat is fun and there's a nice variety of weapons and characters to choose from. Just don't expect a shooter, ammo is limited for a reason. Oh, and take breaks - you'll be clicking a lot, like Diablo-levels of "a lot".

After a rocky launch five years ago, Vermintide Two  has reached a level of polish that is a joy to experience. It's a great way to kill 20 minutes when you just want to mow down a hoard of rat-men and enjoy the fantastic combat mechanics and immersive warhammer fantasy world.
Things to know before playing: uninstall the game

Coming from Darktide (I never usually like going 'backwards' with games and VT2 is 5 years old), Vermintide 2 feels very fleshed-out;

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
There's nice campaign styled maps that follow a story.
The item crafting is very straight forward and available ASAP.
The cosmetics are enough that I can sort-of find a look I like, without paying cash, but they are mostly recolors. 
The professions diversity is VERY cool and I love that I can just swap mid-game without having to exit a game to change like MOST games do.
With the professions, you can also assign one of your other characters/professions as an AI... It ACTUALLY makes playing the other character have a purpose (I personally would not have played the dwarf otherwise), SUPER cool!
Feels like there is plenty of replay-ability

[h]Cons:[/h1]
I can tell that the game is 5 years old... It's not a fault, just a fact.
Wonderfully designed 'personal' space, that is virtually useless because it can all be accessed via the start menu.
Haven't really encountered anything else yet. 🤷

If you enjoyed the first one, I almost guarantee you'll like this one. More of the same + a lot more.

If you never played Vermintide, it's conceptually similar to Left 4 Dead. Four characters venture out and face swarms of monsters, with occasional "special" monsters mixed in. The characters are charming and funny, and you'll still be hearing new interactions after 100+ hours.

Where it differs is in the RPG elements. There are 15 separate careers (19 if you have the DLC), 3 for each of the five characters. There are some similarities between the careers of a character, but each have entirely unique traits and talent trees. As you level up to level 35 you slowly unlock new passives, and are free to swap between them at any time. Where Left 4 Dead eventually lost it's charm for me, I'm still perfecting my build in Vermintide 2.

I won't lie - it can be pretty punishing, but once you learn how to play it's the best "co-op swarm shooter" I've played.

The melee combat system is very enjoyable, intuitive and satisfying. The map design is very beautiful, atmospheric and immersive. The soundtrack really fits the mood and elevates it to a new level.

On first glance the game might seem like a mindless hack & slash but there's way more than meets the eye. That becomes very apparent on higher difficulties (Legend+).

Time to update my review after 700 hours later.

Its my absolute favorite coop game up to date that even after 700 hours doesn't bore me at all. The default game as well as the roguelike mode are fantastic and offer alot of replayability and the balance is at a very good place right now making everyone viable and nobody OP.

What stands out to me especially in comparison to lets say Left 4 Dead are the bots, the characters and the world around them. The gameplay also feels timeless, the build possabilities are amazing and the gore is fantastic. Great variety too with all the maps and gamemodes, not a fan of the WoM DLC however.

1) Bots are insanely good, you can beat Legend with them and they are better than 90% of the players. Some people even beat Catacylsm with them - absolute chads, just make sure you give them the tanky career and a mod to further improve them. They even tag enemies for you! Back in the day when Legend was the highest difficulty and the max level was 5 levels below what it is right now I frequently played Legend with bots and even took all bonus items that made the run harder and had a better time than with players.

2) Characters. They are STUNNING, the voice actors and cast is just absolutely amazing and fun to listen to as well as very immersive and great in explaining the world around them. I never get tired of listening to them, especially Saltzsypre.

It's like Left 4 Dead where guns are swords and zombies are rat-men. But Vermintide 2 is so much better than just L4D with swords and rats. 

I never knew how good it feels to decapitate a virtual rat-man with a pickaxe until I played this game. The melee combat is flawless and you can really feel like you are in full control of your weapons; and there are a lot of great weapons. Spear, sword and board, great hammer, dual wield axe & falchion, flaming flail, bow, crossbow, pistol, portable explosives cannon, the list goes on. Some of the best weapons are unlockable via DLC which can also unlock more maps, skins, achievements, etc. I thought 90% of them were worth it.

In terms of progression, there is always something to look forward to even if that thing might be a hat that you may never wear. At least it's there and gives players a reason to play after having unlocked all gameplay possibilities.

The final point I want to make is how amazing the voice acting is in this game. It is so so soo much chef's kiss. It adds so much more depth to what is already a great experience.

If you like first person coop games, this is a no-brainer! 100% recommend.

This game uses EasyAnitCheat which has kernel access to your computer.

It steals data and does keylogging. It has been seen to keep running even when the game is not in the past.

*edited, lol misspelled kernel and access. Some reason everyone saw the first but missed the second.  Anyway to answer some of the comments. 

I know that having kernel access allows for modification of the computer without my knowledge, that's all I need to know. Take as much precaution as you can. A leak is better than just being open.

As for the claims I made here eh, its not as cut and dry as I made it out. It does have kernel access. It has been caught running in the background.  There are mixed claims on the keylogging and data stealing.

Fundamentally there are plenty of games out there that are multiplayer that can prevent cheating without being as invasive. The fact that some people have gone to some pretty horrific insinuations makes me think they know it is wrong and want to justify their weakness to resting privacy invasion. Just remember, you know the man and they are in your pocket. Give away to much about yourself, and you give up yourself.

As for the game itself, pretty fun with friends, but so is anything. Grindathon with good flavoring.

This game is a hot mess. It's a live service. It has lootboxes. It's peer-to-peer with no host migration. It has invasive anti-cheat despite being PvE only. It crashes a lot. The leveling and gear systems feel so arbitrary. Meanwhile, updates consistently degrade performance, introduce or reintroduce bugs, and include inexplicable changes in balance or class design, making you wonder if anyone at Fatshark does the most basic playtesting before shipping builds...

...but the game is incredible. There is nothing else like this game's melee combat. Its micro reminds me of the original Doom with how there are several different enemy types that can dictate how you approach a situation. 

Despite the devs' best efforts to kill this game (check the reviews for the Winds of Magic DLC), this is the Left 4 Dead clone you should be playing.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

One day I was walking by this small cafe with a huge glass window out the front stretching from either side of the building. Some local kids had obviously key'd the glass so it read dick.breath in the bottom right hand corner.  Upon further observation I found a small CD nestled on the window ledge with the words Left 4 dead 3 written in black sharpie all over it. I jumped with excitement, screaming in my mind with a high pitch squeal. I quickly rushed home with my treasure safely tucked under my bosom. The second I get through the door to my one bedroom apartment, I slap that god damn CD straight into my floppy disk drive. To my whimsical surprise it instantly boots up but strangely it was titled differently from what was on the disk, it read Warhammer : Vermintide 2. I was shocked and sceptical but I had to delve deeper. I built up the courage to press that start game button and what happened afterwards has scarred me for the rest of my life.

I spent hours upon hours being sexually violated by scrawny rat men with poles, viciously abhorred by grotesque apostates of the chaos lords, rigorously rimmed by rat assassins, burnt alive at the stake for no reason other than they can and to top it all of forcefully grabbed, abused and flung around like a d.ildo found between a lesbian legs. 

The only thing I can honestly say about L4D3 is that if you like to be treated like dirt in a abusive relationship then this game is the game for you, especially with the combat updates!!!

One of the best 4-man co-op multiplayer FPS out there. Made with love by hardworking fatshark devs. Astounding graphics, medieval aesthetics that strive to be realistic but faithful to warhammer fantasy. Gameplay is magnificent; playable in VR, and a focus on melee- parry and stamina systems combined with non-repetitive movelists/trees that make for variety in melee combat. Ranged combat is a beauty to play with either, as different characters with different classes use different weapons with different mechanics. Maps do not get boring easily due to the loot aspects (but may be a turn off for those who don't like grining). Cosmetics are grindable. Almost everything is kinda free. Grinding is not much of a chore either as you can try for better loot by adjusting difficulties or craft better loot to your liking. Some expansions are also free, so there. Overall, great game. I recommend warhammer fantasy (and/or AoS) fans to try it. Feel like an Empire footsoldier in a siege by skaven or chaos? This game is for you!
