SMASHS THE RAT SMASH THE SRAT THE RATS ALLL OVER AND THE HORNGUYS.

I gotta admit, this is THE melee combat game. I do not regret buying it along with it DLCs (cosmetics not included). I like almost everything about this game, from the melee combat to the sound effect of the monsters, to the weapons hitting the enemies, to the goddamn conversations, all are master pieces. The thing that sucks are some of the songs, which it fits the chaos of the combat but it sounds like noise. Now on to the main point of the game, dissecting it piece by piece. First off the story.
The story is pretty simple, there's a big gate that can summon a large army of Chaos and Skaven really deep inside the Empires land, which is very bad for the war. But inside the game are bits of lore for Warhammer Fantasy which is a nice way to learn about the world around them.
The melee combat is the best part of the game and probably the reason people get the game. The hammers have impact and feel powerful, the axes and sword can dismember enemies and feel very light, as they should for characters of their history. None of the weapons are bad but there are just better version of some of the weapons, for example the mace and shield is way better than the sword and shield for Kruber.
The ranged weapons are also pretty good but they're not the main focus, so their ammo is more limited but they hit like a truck, and they're just used to kill specials and bosses, and at times elites. They have nice sounds and look amazing and fit into the fantasy world.
Now most people complain about the DLCs and its understandable, having one class locked behind a paywall sucks and having some pretty OP weapons also locked behind that paywall, but the base characters are solid and can do their roles pretty well.
Other thing to the game is the roster, there are 5 characters with 3 classes (and one locked behind a DLC), they're solid, each has a role and they have banter and conversations with each other and the conversations are a bit edited depending on which class you pick. There are youtubers who explain it in more detailed so I won't bore you with that, but they're nice, interesting and have lore behind them which they will discuss.

Overall, the game is worth it, it can get repetitive but there is a huge free DLC called "Chaos Wastes" which makes it fun to replay.

Interestingly enough I only decided to write this review after playing Darktide for about 100 hours, realizing that Vermintide 2 is a better game in every way, and going back to vermintide. This game has an incredible amount of maps and game modes with the maps having a linearly connected story that feels like a campaign. This is in stark contrast to Darktide where the maps feel more like one off missions with no relation to each other and with way less map variety. The interactions and voice lines between different characters are well thought out and give the characters personality and charm that I sorely missed in Darktide. If you get bored there's always the rouge like game mode to keep things interesting. Crafting is also fair and rewarding allowing for optimized character builds once enough time has been spent playing the game. Unlike the dumb shop system in Darktide, your given way more control over the weapons you're able to obtain and getting rolls you want since you can simply craft the weapon instead of praying you get the one you need in the rng Darktide shop. All in all if you were disappointed by Darkide, play this game instead since its way better.

After a few hours of gameplay, let us make a judgment on this game.
Fun, that's the first word that comes to my mind hot, I played only "quick matches" so only with random teams and I admit I had fun. 
There are various difficulty levels, at the lowest level things are very easy and even if you are not an expert in the game the missions are easily completed without too many problems, as you go up in difficulty the enemies become more aggressive, do more damage and it becomes essential to use the parry and dodge commands in certain situations or to assess well how to move against certain enemies. Even at the item level obtained the difference changes depending on the difficulty level selected. Item crafting system quite good but not great, maybe it's me who didn't really understand how to make the most of it.
Otherwise, this game is keeping me company at times when I want to relax for a moment after work and is proving to be, as I said initially, fun, so my final rating is positive.

Easily in my top 3 games of all time, maybe even at the top.

What I do not like about this game: randomly generated loot, item properties/traits and a general absence of information when it comes to said options of properties and traits

Other than that it's a pretty good game. Fun banter between the characters with just enough fantasy racism to hurt no feelings; good weapon options and character options that allow for whack builds if you take your time to think about what you want, a lot of freedom when it comes to how you want to play and most important of all; a shitton of rats to kill. If you want a more challenging experience, there's higher difficulties, but there's nothing like plowing through a crowd of ratmen with your buddies. 

All in all a very enjoyable and relaxing game that's great for venting frustrations.

Warhammer: Vermintide 2 is the sequel to 2015's Warhammer: End Times - Vermintide. The game is set in the Warhammer Fantasy universe during the early days of the End Times. The game follows the Heroes of Ubersreik from the first game against the Skaven hordes of Clan Fester and their new allies, the Rotbloods. The expansion, "Winds of Magic", also introduced the Beastmen, a herd of Chaos mutated humanoids, in search of an object known as the 'Herdstone'.

So I hadn't played this since the year it came out, and it was pretty good then, though the menus and loot boxes were a pain to slog through.  Darktide comes out recently and had me wanting to try this one again before I think about purchasing Darktide (which looked like it still needed work anyways.) 

ANd just...WOW.  The game is MUCH better than when it came out.  The loot box tally at the end of missions can be sped up now, they've added challenges and quests to do alongside the main missions, the menus are a HELLUVA lot nicer to get through, the AI for the bots is MUCH better (and you can issue them commands!) and my favorite part....They added a rogue like mode where you gain perks/boons/weapons on a large expedition campaign that is like having multiple missions tied together.    The weapon/loot progression of the main campaigns become a bore once you  regularly get the max power'd items in lootboxes for weapons you don't want anyways.  Fun progression until you hit that point though.

The new mode, chaos wastes, is an arcade version of this Left4Dead formula that is fun as hell for me and starts everyone out at the default power level for weapons, with no trinkets, which evens the playing field of old and new players.  Only difference is the experience levels of the characters themselves still being the same, which only grant special Talents every 5 levels (max is lvl 35, atm.)  Each expedition is randomized and teams vote for the next area on the map to travel to, similar way to other roguelikes like Peglin/Slay The Spire/Inscryption.

And I've not even checked out the modded realm yet, still trying to get through all of the chaos wastes.  

So yeah, this game is worth trying out if you want a team based game ala Left4Dead/Deep Rock Galactic with satisfying evisceration.  

Fair warning though: The Banter between the characters, though very well acted for Voice actors (Saltspyre and Bardin are fantastic), REALLY takes it toll after a while.  And you cannot turn it off, ever.  Kerillian's VA does a good job, but Kerillian is tiringly oversnarky.

I'd love to see this kind of game gain the melee control of other Melee FPS's like Mordhau/Chivalry in future iterations.

It's a beautiful game with decent mechanics, kinda like Left 4 Dead.

But what ruins it for me is the grinding lootbox mechanics that feel out of place here. You're sometimes limited not by your skills, but by your gear. This game doesn't need that.

Despite Darktide's current... situation, Vermintide remains an exceptionally good example of the cooperative horde-clearer genre. It has a bit of a learning curve regarding mechanics like Armor, and there are some QoL features missing from the base game, but the game is in and of itself excellent.

I fully expect Darktide to become what Vermintide 2 currently is, and that is a highly replayable and enjoyable experience.

As of this moment, the game is a bit of a buggy mess. I love the new units, classes and features, but, they are not balanced into the ai directors rng formula well yet. Mobs use overly aggressive rng dodge and block calcs to bi-pass most skill-based combat methods from the first game which leaves the game feeling to random.

This is especially true on LEGEND which they may as well re-name RANDOM. on Legend mode, the game just decides if you win or lose based on dice. Plus, the extreme number of armored units on legend necessitates certain equipment choices and classes which combined with the randomness of the ai director and imbalanced unit damage/dodge mechanics leaves the game feeling more boring than challenging.

I played V1 for something like 2000 hours, at least 1500 of which were pure cata pug groups. The thing i liked about cata was that even though we lost a lot, it could always be chalked up to human error. The AI director didn’t just execute 2-3 team members randomly with unstaggered spawns and buggy unit mechanics. So, while we wiped a TON in V1, it was almost always something we could control and subsequently laugh about. In this game it’s just like "yep, 2 gutters, 1 hook, a chaos horde, 4 SV's and 2 CW's all just aggro at the exact same time right on top of us, we lose i guess. I don’t feel engaged, I feel like it was never winnable in the first place and that is just plain boring.

Truth is CATA sucked on V1 at first to though. It took them a long time to balance it to the work of art it was later in the games life. I’ll keep trying back and I am sure they will make it more fun eventually, but as for right now, I would pass.

At near the end of the road, this game is fantastic. With probably the greatest melee combat of any game I've ever played, a world that is gorgeous and well-designed, and characters that are both distinct from one another mechanically, and infinitely memeable as individual personalities, the game does a great job placing you within the End Times, fighting Skaven, Norscan Chaos, and Beastmen.

That being said, Having owned this game for a long while, the journey to get to where its at has been... rocky, which makes me cautiously optimistic for the future of the developers of this game. Some changes, like the Chaos Wastes (Free DLC), add repeatability and excitement back to the game, while DLC like the Winds of Magic (Paid DLC) split the player base into two different random queues and introduced a frustrating new game mechanic.

All around fantastic game as it is now. It goes on sale a lot, and if you can pick up the game with all the DLC (excluding the cosmetic DLC for each character), then it is well worth the cost, though it's even still worth it at full price.

Edit: This review is now negative because they STILL HAVEN'T RELEASED THE SIENNA CLASS EVEN AFTER DARKTIDE CAME OUT. Every other class has received their final class.

Warhammer: Vermintide 2 is an action-packed and highly entertaining cooperative first-person shooter game set in the fantasy world of Warhammer. The game features intense melee combat and a wide variety of weapons and classes to choose from, making it a thrilling experience for both casual and hardcore gamers.

The game's graphics are stunning, and the attention to detail in the character models and environments is impressive. The game's AI enemies, known as Skaven, are varied and challenging, providing a nice level of difficulty for players. The game's co-op play is one of its strongest features, allowing players to work together to take on hordes of Skaven and complete missions.

Funny points:

The game's dialogue is often hilarious, with characters frequently cracking jokes and making puns
The character animations are so over the top that it's hard not to laugh when you see your character flail around wildly while fighting
The Skaven enemies are so comically evil-looking that it's hard not to chuckle when you take them down
Rating:

Gameplay: 9/10
Graphics: 8/10
Co-op Play: 10/10
Replayability: 9/10
Humor: 8/10
Overall, Warhammer: Vermintide 2 is an incredibly fun and engaging game that is well worth checking out. The combination of intense combat, great graphics, and humorous moments make it a must-play for fans of the Warhammer universe and cooperative first-person shooters. I highly recommend it.

Since the game has been on sale frequently, here are some things new players should know to enjoy this game to it's full potential:

[olist]
[*] Install [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1395655171] Bot Improvements [/url] mod and start by playing a few games on recruit with bots. This will give you time to explore the map and try out new things without worrying about your team rushing ahead.

[*] Some other Quality of Life mods - [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1369573612] Mod Framework, [/url][url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1397265260] Numeric UI, [/url][url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1395453301] Skip Intro, [/url][url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1464907434&searchtext=]Armory, [/url][url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1502859403&searchtext=] Notice Key Pickup. [/url]

[*] Pick one hero and a one class (e.g. Kruber/Mercenary) and [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2034609078] read the entire section for that class in this amazing guide [/url] by [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/dylanrong] Royale w/ Cheese [/url]

[*] And lastly, don't worry too much about collecting all the optional Tomes and Grims at the beginning. Just have fun!
[/olist]

Amazing game, it's a lot of fun and even more so with friends! Great graphics, not sure about lower settings, but if set on Maximum the game looks astonishing. The gameplay is nothing special, reminds me of similar games in terms fights, however the talents, looting, crafting and in general all systems set in the game are very well made. The story is interesting, but hard to understand and follow (in my opinion) as there is no Campaign mode and only Quick Play, which allows you to delve in to different zones and missions to complete with others. There are also weekly challenges with effects on creatures and other fun challenges that drop off certain mobs (e.g. Deeds). I would highly recommend getting the game, its totally worth its price (full and especially, if on Sale) a lot of fun, evil creature bashing, amazing characters and interesting gameplay with beautiful views (if you have the time to looks, due to all the fighting and blood around you). Better with friends, for sure. Overall I would rate this 9/10, as I have a hard time personally understanding and following the story, as well as that there is no solo option to play with and that you either have bots or players in the lobby (players > bots in any case).

A fun, polished horde slayer set in the Warhammer universe (obviously, you should've realized that by now silly). I was worried at first starting off, thinking there could be a lack of content and that after a few days I would be bored. Having now 14 hours under my belt, I can see that the variety of missions and design of the progression system will keep you playing for a pretty long time. Not grindy, just fun progression that doesn't let you hit cap lvls too quickly (although for some of you no-lifers this may not apply). Recommended for smooth, polished coop fun! Best with friends.

Great game if you like the "Left 4 Dead" style of game play with boss fights. It has collectibles to find throughout the levels as well as Grimoires and Tomes for greater risk/ reward. Great graphics and seems to be well optimized.

If you were thinking of getting Darktide, I'd say skip that for now and get this instead.

In its current state, Vermintide 2 is probably one of the best horde combat games out there, though it took a long time for it to get to the excellent state it is in now.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ Top-class melee combat system with great depth. You'll very frequently find something else to learn about the combat system, whether it be early stuff like learning to best use your block and shove, or later stuff like learning a proper dodge dance + weapon-specific attack combos to maximize your effectiveness.
+ Varied weapons and classes give you many different ways to play the game.
+ Charming characters with amusing banter gives the game a bit of welcome relief from the rat-induced horrors and general darkness associated with the End Times setting.
+ A free roguelike mode which can give you some fresh (and chaotic) experiences should you ever tire of the main story missions.

[h1]The YMMVs[/h1]
= Occasional weird bugginess, but not enough for me to call it a hard con. Most of the time, the bugs are pretty innocent or even amusing.
= Player hosting for lobbies can leave you at the mercy of the host's connection. Though, in my experience, it's a solid netcode that really will only fall apart if the host has a particularly awful connection. 

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- Poor in-game explanation of much of the game's mechanics. You'll need to check around for some resources if you really want a numerical understanding of what different weapons are exactly capable of.
- Getting good gear is a bit of a grind, as you'll frequently be subject to the whims of RNG.
- Some enemy hitboxes can be extremely janky. Don't be surprised if a Plague Monk (the loud screechy rats with the awful puke green cult robes) somehow chunks your HP bar despite you being on a cliff 5 feet above them.

- Replayability
- Cathartic
- Good progression and loot system
- Decent talent/build system
- Great combat system
- Nice graphics, character designs, level designs and general aesthetics
- Challenging (at higher difficulties)

CONS:
- Can be inconsistent at times (miss a hip fire with a sniper weapon when enemy is LITERALLY like 2m away)
- Has a nice quick play system; however, qp randomly selects the same like 4 maps over and over and over...
- Higher difficulties require decent teamplay, but the game has a solo-minded community and no incentive mechanic to play as a team. Playing as a team increases survival odds tenfold, but no one seems to care. Everyone will also have more fun as a team :)
- A LOT of knockback/ stun enemies and bosses

microtransactions don't get in the way of the gameplay and you can go hundreds of hours not dishing out any extra money unless you want a funny little hat on your dwarf. A lot of cosmetics are bought with a currency you can earn in gameplay, so customization isn't off the table.

I am a 49 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

After hacking at rats for a while this game quickly loses its appeal. It's a dumb, boring repetitive grind of a game.

The loot system is terrible, gain a loot box after every mission containing 3 new pieces of equipment with a slightly higher gear score, play another mission to get another loot box containing 3 new pieces of gear with a slightly higher gear score level. Repeat until you gradually become strong enough to do the higher difficulty.

Difficulty, there is no difference between the easiest difficulty and the toughest difficulty the mobs of rats just hit harder. It's a forced artificial difficulty that revolves around the badly designed loot system and leveling system.

Leveling, you gain the same amount of experience playing on the easiest difficulty as you do on the toughest difficulty, it's a boring grind to lvl to the maximum level of 35 where your characters "power level" increases along with his "gear score"

Beautiful, cathartic game that satisfies the teamwork-oriented co-op craving I've had for so long after playing hundreds of hours of Left 4 Dead. Normally I'd write a more detailed review, but I'm not far into the game enough to give my opinion on everything. So first impressions, it's awesome. I can see myself sinking hundreds of hours into this trying to master the characters and challenge myself with the harder difficulties. I really want to see this game succeed.

EDIT: After 140 hours, yeah, I love this game. The characters and banter are amazing, which for me is a huge deal in these co-op horde games. The combat is visceral, satisfying, and varied not just with different weapons but also with how to use them most effectively. The environments are gorgeous and Fatshark is the first to make me legitimately interested in the Warhammer universe.

If I had one complaint it would be that the leveling takes way too long. The weapon progression is fine, but the character progression is a detriment to the game in my opinion. Classes really don't start to get interesting until about level 20, which takes quite a while. I still don't know if I'll like 3 of the 5 characters because I don't want to go through the slog of leveling them when I've already found a character that I know I like.

[h1]My Rating: 5/5[/h1]

A few things to note: most of the games I play (and enjoy) are strictly solo, and I rarely make time for myself to play games anymore. At the time of this review 90% of my hours have been in the past week.

I bought this game a few years ago, I went into this game with no expectations, and at a first glance I felt like it was a more melee focused Left 4 Dead copy with a Warhammer: Age of Sigmar theme. Now I enjoy both AoS and 40K on tabletop, with more of an appreciation for 40K than AoS, so I went in with some bias. Stopped playing after an hour or so and completely forgot about the game. Came back to it a few months before all the Darktide hype and figured "eh, why not give it a shot?" Best choice I've made in a while. It's been hard to put the game down.

Pros:
- Each character has a lot of variety to choose from
- 3 classes each character (With the exception of the fire mage, each character has access to an additional class as paid DLC at this time)
- A decent selection of options for weapons
- Very satisfying combat
- Soundtrack fits the game very well
- Sound design is very satisfying 
- Good amount of content in the base game
- Crafting is fun, but not reqired
- Lootbox system that's fair and fun
- The game looks nice, even on the lowest setting
- The banter between characters feels natural, tension and arguing being organic at times.
- Being called a Lumberfoot
- The only explanation you have for the dwarf's language is in tool tips, which makes loading screens a bit more fun.
- The Chaos Wastes are a really fun way to play the game
- The Solo option is nice

Cons:
- Lots of paid DLC
- Cosmetics that have any effort put into them cost money
- The level design can be confusing at times
- The game will sometimes expect you to know the way to proceed with no explanation. I'm looking at you Trail of Treachery finale
- It takes quite a few matches to level up your characters
- The game can feel like a slog at times
- The dodge mechanic feels a bit clunky
- The prologue
- Load screens can take a while. Not a huge issue but if you don't like waiting it can get annoying
- Quickplay seems to be a mess? Never tried it but I've seen a lot of complaints

Overall, this game has a lot going for it. Don't go into it expecting a beautiful game where everyone looks like a supermodel, it takes place in a time where baths are a luxury, everything is filthy and it shows. If you can get the game on sale it's a steal, grab a few friends and you'll have a good time.

The game deepens the already excellent Warhammer atmosphere. You won't know the exact year of the events, so it's not clear whether Altdorf is already burning and Archaon has reached Middenheim, but the mood of the end of the world is omnipresent and heavy. Dust falls on the ruins, doom hangs in the air, and Nurgle's gardens of loathing and decay thrive among the broken houses. The occasional cheerful song from the dwarf or the wizard Sienna teasing remark to the devoted sigmarite Victor is like a spark of hope in the darkness and, with its contrast, deepens the hopeless distress. The Warhammer lover will be delighted.
An exception would be found, however, in the form of the elf Kerillian. Yes, Warhammer elves tend to be dismissive and condescending towards other races, but there's a difference between the good-natured bickering of others and a constant stream of annoying insults that the heroine spews wherever she goes. You can put up with it for a while, but when he doesn't close his mouth even after two hundred hours and utters a hundred venomous rants during a mission, it gets on your nerves. In the end, one finds oneself actually quite glad when the elf is finally cut down by the hardened assassin.

Vermintide 2 is a sequel as it should be. The successful action core of the first one remains preserved, only a little more dynamism and rawness has been added to it, resulting from a larger number of enemies and therefore even more headless carnage. The creators have reworked the item acquisition system to some extent, eliminating much of the annoying role of randomness through simple but purposeful crafting. There were also light RPG elements, a more diverse environment that is no longer bound by a single city, and more types of enemies, as the original rats (Skaven) were joined by hordes of Norse barbarians in the service of Nurgle, and hideous armies of Beastmen. Fatshark's Vermintide 2 excels at conveying warrior euphoria.

Nineteen character options.
The ensemble of five heroes looks to have remained the same from last time, but that's only true at first glance. The latter will already reveal the welcome changes. Everyone now has a choice of 4 careers, which open up completely new possibilities and game styles.
If you want a dwarf Bardin, an indestructible ironbreaker or a possessed slayer with vision worthy of death. Depending on your own taste and mood, you can play the sorceress Sienna as a deadly fire-throwing machine or a melee fighter dressed in flame armor. Human mercenary Markus Kruber reveals the campaign as a Bretonnian warrior or a hunter with a death-sowing bow. Templar Viktor Saltzpyre also has a decent selection of characters available. My favorite character remains elf Kerillian, even though everyone hates him, especially his campaign as Shade, the servant of Malekith.

You literally have to build each character according to your imagination and choose the best combinations of skills, equipment and weapons and their respective properties.
Personally, after hundreds of hours I have mastered the legendary campaigns of all characters (which was my main goal) and I enjoyed each one.

I've read many Warhammer Fantasy books, so I have to criticize the game for one thing - it's not bloody enough. It would definitely need more second animation of death, real carnage as described in the books, just don't mess with heroes in gloves. Being torn apart by skaven, having a skull crushed by a beast, being eaten alive by a chaos monster... maybe I sound weird now, but this just belongs to Warhammer.

I may have beaten the game and have nothing to gain from it, but unless I find a successor, I'll still enjoy the carnage of Warhammer. I choose from 19 campaigns based on a random number generator.
Bigger, more predatory, rawer, more dynamic, more sophisticated, richer. In short, better. [b] 90% [/b]

Better than Darktide.

I DON'T HATE THE GAME!

I'll say that again: I don't hate the game! It's actually really fun! 

So WHY am I not recommending it? Good question.

People don't seem to understand recommendations on steam. I don't *hate* Vermintide 2. I just wouldn't recommend it to other players. With that said...

Pros:

Graphics and atmosphere. Amazing realization of the Warhammer Fantasy setting. Fantastic job, Fatshark. 

Combat is... amazing. Best melee combat in a first person game ever, in my personal opinion. 

Extensive build diversity. Lots of careers and talents to pick from, that's great.

Cons:

GRINDY. AS. HELL. Seriously. So many of you are willing to tolerate the grind because the combat is great. For those who haven't played the game yet, this is how loot and progression works:

You get a loot box at the end of every mission. The "level" of the lootbox depends on difficulty, whether or not you're in quickplay, how many collectibles you got in the level, loot dice from (random) bosses and drops, and total RNG. This is the only way to get new weapons and items. There is NO way to get a specific weapon you want aside from crafting, and you can only get crafting materials by smelting down whatever you don't want. 

This means the most efficient way of gettting high-quality gear is if you play one specific mission on a high difficulty OVER and OVER and OVER again. This isn't like Deep Rock Galactic where the maps are randomly generated. You play the same mission on the same map over and over, grabbing all the collectibles. It's tedious as hell, and EVEN then it's still up to chance whether you get a Tier 6 chest or not. 

Even then, all loot in the game has an "item power" (like Gear Score in Tom Clancy's Division).

How do you get items with high power? Play on higher difficulties? Complete specific challenges? Nope. You just mindlessly open chests. Just keep opening em, and the item power for each item in each chest has a CHANCE of increasing anywhere from 1-5 or DECREASING from 1-2 according to the highest item power you've previously acquired. I'm 45 hours into the game and I've maybe opened 150-200 chests of various types, and I'm roughly at Item Power 250. The max is *300*. Y'know what that means? At LEAST another week of grinding. 

This is not a satisfying way of getting items. This has absolutely nothing to do with merit or skill and everything to do with grinding and patience. The actual skill and tryharding doesn't start until you've maxed out your item power. Until then: gotta open that next chest, baby.

Also, Winds of Magic is a terrible DLC, fight me. It costs the most despite adding the least (ONE new map). The new weapons are cool, but the new enemies have cheap, low-quality looking animations, and the new difficulty (cataclysm). No additional XP, no better loot. I find this especially bizarre because the Chaos Wastes roguelike mode easily adds twice as much content as Winds of Magic and it's FREE for everybody. 

I like the game and I'm going to keep playing it, but I'm concerned for the future of Vermintide 2. The grindy, tedious progression system combined with the fact that Tencent is a major Fatshark shareholder are not good signs. Fatshark's 40k title, Darktide, is an objectively unfinished buggy mess with the same progression tedium as Vermintide 2. 

If you want a truly great 4-player coop game, play Deep Rock Galactic.

This game is fun! I would give it my conditional recommendation if you:

- have friends that play this game (especially if they're experienced) or are willing to go in on it with you to give it a shot
- are interested in the Warhammer IP already or are willing to try getting invested through this game (which probably isn't the best place to start but everyone starts somewhere!)
- enjoy L4D-style gameplay loops or are coming from a similar game like Darktide, except it's generally melee-focused with medieval weapons/magic
- like action RPGs like Marvel's Avengers, but want something with much slower progression and more grinding
- find this game on sale

If more than one of the above apply to you, you'll have a good time. I've had the best time playing with friends and not a ton of success playing with randos because I prefer to use a mic and that's generally not the experience I've had - oh well.

There's not a ton of customization in terms of your character's cosmetics, which is fine I suppose but it does leave something to be desired) and the amount of grind that's needed to fully level a character's gear levels is off-putting to me as a beginner, especially when everyone else you play with has been playing longer and on higher difficulties. So, if you're in a position where you'd be the odd person out and you'd feel like you'd have to grind to keep up or feel awkward and don't have the time (I don't usually care - they can pick me up or choose a lower difficulty lol I got better things to do than grind levels man), then that might be a sticking point.

Other than that, it's still a lot of fun. I just don't have the energy to grind as much as this game seems to want me to.

Lose in a running race to an elf, lose a dwarf in the crowd, be set on fire by a wizard, receive a hug from a mercenary, be a subject of religious prejudice, hack rats, slash rats, decapitate rats, block rats, dodge rats, weave around rats, saute rats, dismember rats, have your skull crushed in by rats, rat blood is everywhere, my blood is everywhere, get shot in the back by your teammates, limp to the finish with one thousand rats nibbling at your ankles and blood pouring out of every orifice, receive three common items as a reward.

Man I love this game and it's at its best more than 4 years after launch with tons of extra base game content. This thing is so fun to play. Its first person melee combat is the best and most satisfying there is. It's absolutely dripping with character. Boatloads of progression. I see rats when I close my eyes now. Great looter game that takes the Left 4 Dead formula and adds in class-based abilities, looting, and a long-term progression system. Can be played both co-op or solo with bots. Bots are actually alright and often offer a better experience than playing with players. Bots are especially perfect for picking up tomes and grimoires: hidden collectable items you can collect each time you play a mission for more challenge and more reward (players aren't so consistent at picking those up, often not knowing where they are, or not caring). The playable classes and sub-classes are quite unique and (for the most part) greatly change up the gameplay experience. It's fun to level them all up individually. The loot system feels fair and has nice mechanics for consistent progression. 

The game consists of many long, replayable campaign missions, that can be completed and repeated on various difficulties. Boss fights are fun due to interesting mechanics rather than just being enemies with lots of health and damage. The level design is great, big and open with many nooks and crannies, allowing for many ways to deal with combat scenarios, as well as interesting hiding spots and platforming sections for the collectable tomes and grimoires mentioned earlier. This game is an absolute recommendation if you love co-op play, looter games, or liked L4D back in the day.

Not my cup of tea.

If they implement at least half what they have in Vermintide than Darktide will be an excellent game. So for now we'll just have Vermintide as an accomplishment for FatShark. Definitely a good game. Fun, easy to grasp, and best of all with complete features. A Bot system that isn't hot garbage. Full crafting system so no hunting random store fronts. Lots of little side quests/achievements to change up your game without being completely broken or un-intuitive or punishing. Easy character switch. Fast, responsive, easy to use and balanced match maker. So yeah. Play this while Fatshark fixes Darktide. I know i am.

EDIT: Updated for 2023.

Darktide's launch was so bad. I now recommend the superior Vermintide 2 game.   

Back in 2018, Fatshark announced dedicated servers (or at least community servers).

It is currently 2022 and there are no dedicated servers. There are no community servers. Everything is peer 2 peer and your experience is dependent on the Host's computer and internet connection. If you lose connection to the host (d/c, crash, rage quit) it is game over. Host Migration does not save progress, unless it is in Chaos Wastes, and only work some of the time. 

Other than that, it's a pretty good game. It will ruin other games that aren't titled Vermintide, so I don't recommend this game.

Back to the characters - you can play as 5 characters and each has 3 classes and 4 of them have a dlc class... I personaly hate it. First and my favourite is Kruber - human. Sounds nice, is nice to everyone and loves to drink. Best guy i could ask for in this game. Next is a dwarf named Bardin - again he is nice to everyone and sounds like a dwarf and also loves to drink. Next is Victor (human again) who believes in Sigmar - he sounds ok and interesting when he talks about Sigmar, but he can get annoying and he sometimes sounds so proud that it makes me feel sick. Next is a  Brightwizard called Sienna (human) - yes it is she not he - should be called brightwitch if ya ask me. But whatever - she is old and sometimes sounds annoying as all hell - interestaing aint it? Since she can summon a cyrcle of fire. And now the worst character of all Kerrilian the elf - yes... SHE HAS NO GOOD LINE! AND I MEAN IT! Listening to the worst tone of a guitar would still be better then listening to her. She is nothing but annoying b*tch. Always talking about how she is the best and nothing else. She deserves to be deleted, but she is still a bit better then Pavlovna from Call of duty: Vanguard... Now our friend in the main lobby in the keep, from where you go to missions. His shop is nothing but useless. Litteraly. You either have to complete his quests to get silver to buy cosmetics or buy them for real money... Litteraly nothing but useless. Difficulties of the missions - i played up to champion difficulty and i reccomend to play ONLY UP TO THIS DIFFICUTLY, because then its like expert in l4d2 - unplayable... And one difficulty is only playable if you pay a dlc... And that dlc only gives you a one more mission and a boring gamemode... This game is amazing. It is similar to Left for Dead and Killing Floor, but melee focused. I've only played with bots (they are viable until the hardest difficulty), so my review will not cover trying to play with other people.

Pros:
- The combat system. There are different weapons with their own strengths and weaknesses. Some weapons are great for killing hordes of weak enemies, while others are great at killing armored elites. Some weapons are even adequate at dealing with both. Once you learn a weapons strengths, you then learn the intricacy of the weapon's rotation of attacks, and when to interrupt that rotation with a block to better deal with a situation. Unfortunately, many weapon guides are outdated since there have been a couple of weapon updates.
- Characters have their own play styles, and each character has 3 character classes that play differently.
- The game looks great, and the weapon skins (illusions as the game calls them) also look great.
- Talents add some more variety to how each class is played, though some talents are obviously better than others.
- 13 maps, lasting about 20-30min each. No run is the same (there are a few scripted mini-boss fights), some runs will be easier and others more difficult. It is amazing to snatch victory from the jaws of defeat (also known as a Chaos Spawn). Each map stands out from the others.
- The daily quests and achievement rewards give better loot than one will encounter when just starting out (until you start playing on the hardest difficulty).
- The bots pick up potions and grenades. While they don't use them, they will give them to players that have an empty slot.
- Bots can be very effective at tanking bosses and mini-bosses (given favorable factors with terrain).
- Sanctioned mods that can be played on the official realm.
- You can pick what class (and what characters), talents, and weapons bots use. Since the bots use your characters, it is important to level up all characters that you use as bots and equip them with better weapons and accessories.
- As of patch 1.2.1 there is greater control over bots.

Meh:
- There aren't any stats for weapons, so some weapons are viewed as being useless when their benefits are hard to see (example: Kruber's two-handed sword seems worse than his executioners sword, but it does better stagger on heavy/charged attacks which is useful on preventing high-damaging elite enemies from attacking). (EDIT: There have been significant changes to certain weapons in version 2.0)
- The beginning can be very hard until you get better equipment. Crafting weapons becomes necessary to more quickly raise the power level of the equipment you get. This can be discouraging at first, but bearing through it rewards you with a fun game.
- The developers do not communicate very well.

Cons:
- A lot of old bugs keep returning when a major patch is released (hits on enemies not registering, enemies spawning on top of you, talents not working, bots getting stuck).
- It takes around 270 hours to level up all characters to the max level of 30. Now you have to level up to 35.
- Bots have had their range attack distances greatly reduced. Bots will not attack beastmen archers that are firing on them.
- Character classes are locked behind level unlocks, as are weapon blueprints to craft weapons.
- Very grindy.
- RNG (also known as Ranald) can be very cruel and unkind when getting loot. It seems like I mostly get trinkets, charms, and necklaces rather than weapons, and uncommonly get weapons with illusions (it does get better with better loot chests).
- Ranald, again, is not kind when re-rolling for traits and properties on weapons and accessories.
- Cosmetic hats can be very rare, and the different armor cosmetics are just re-colors of the default armors. These re-colored armors look bad with all the hats, because the hats are colored to match the default armors.
- Not all new player friendly weapons are available in the beginning. You have to level up to get access to blueprints to craft weapons and accessories, or hope Ranauld (RNGesus) gives you a variety of weapons.
- Losing connection to steam will end a run, and a run ending or being defeated results in no rewards (you do get a small amount of experience for being defeated though).

I am a 54 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 15. My son downloaded Vermintides and in less than a week, he had already played for over 11 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

At the time of writing? I love Vermintide 2!!! There's never been a better time to get into this game.
It's a melee-oriented Left4Dead spiritual successor with the best feeling first-person melee combat in the business where you have 15 (4 more as DLC) unique classes, a bunch of cool melee and ranged weapons that all feel amazing, a loveable and iconic cast to rival both L4Ds, a variety of locales to visit and fight FUCKED UP RAT PEOPLE in (also regular dudes but rotten), not one but TWO alternative game modes, and all of it feels, sounds and looks amazing! If that's not enough, we have absolutely twisted difficulties in the modded section for the madlads and the psychopaths. And it all goes on sale so often, it's more expensive NOT to buy it!
Don't worry, all the daily login and MTX crap the game got as it grew is EXTREMELY safe to just ignore, you're not losing out on any progress. Get the DLCs if you like what you see in the base game, it's all more worth it than not!

Mindless hack and slash horde shooter with grindy rpg elements tacked on. Very low skill ceiling. Game is just a mess, no idea why people like this but I could barely stomach the 7 hours I played. I guess people like to see hordes of things go boom. Buy if you like that. If you like tactical fights, using your brain, and leveraging your skill, play something else.

I love the idea of this type of Gameplay. The idea of getting overwhelmed and cutting through hordes and few games nail that. Vermintide almost gets it. The way the AI director works is really clever, and I think one of the best examples we have seen of such a system in action.

However my enjoyment of the game has always been stumped by crashes in multiplayer and ultimately even if I like all of the pieces they don't quite come together as a whole that I find myself coming back to, and I think that has a lot to do with experimentation and variety. The incentive of better loot is not quite enough for me to keep playing. I feel as if I had my fun, and moved on. I hope they will keep refining the game. I feel it deserves to be good. As it is now, I did not feel compelled enough to make it memorable.

Strawberry Cheesecake French Toast

Ingredients:

4 Slices Bread
4 Eggs
1 Tablespoon Vanilla
1 Cup Milk
1 Tablespoon Cinnamon
4 oz. Warm Cream Cheese
2 Tablespoons Vanilla Extract
2 Tablespoons Lemon Juice
¾ Cup Heavy Cream
1 ½ Cups Strawberry, Diced, Divided
⅓ Cup Sugar
Confectioners Sugar
Maple Syrup

Preparation:

1.Whisk eggs, cinnamon, vanilla and milk together in medium-large bowl to create egg wash.

2. In medium bowl mix cream cheese, vanilla, sugar, lemon juice and heavy cream (optional).

3. Take 2 slices of bread and spread mixture on both.

4. Press sliced strawberries on both slices & press together.

5. Dunk in egg wash.

6. Melt butter in a skillet on medium-low heat and cook bread for 2-3 minutes or until crumbs are crispy and bread is more solid.

7. Stack and garnish with strawberries and confectioners sugar. Add maple syrup to preference.

Hey look, another edit. 

After the most recent patch (which introduced the wolf-fathers gifts) any time I play the game, all I get is a black screen with UI elements. Presumably this is Easy AntiCheat thinking that the game files are modified and trying to prevent me from playing. I have attempted to verify my files and have uninstalled and reinstalled the game, to no avail. Nothing I do makes any difference. I can't speak for anyone else but for me personally the game is literally unplayable and I don't know why.



So I've played this game a lot more since my original review/rant, and feel more/less like I can make a 180 with the current state of the game.

FS has made a lot of very player friendly changes in the time since WoM came out, and have maybe not "reverted" but well.....reverted... a lot of the class nerfs, allowing specialization again while doing a fair job keeping balance. They have expressed a desire to make any future "DLC" (Maps.) free to all players in favor of some amount of micro being added (It was originally only cosmetic, but now includes very unique takes on hero careers; but its not super expensive and keeps the rest of the game free going forward so I consider it.....Acceptable

Over all without explaining every single thing that has been changed since my original review I'll just say that in its current state I would 100% recommend the game regardless of it being on sale or not





** Old Review Begin

I love this game, I want to keep loving this game, but I feel like the devs are too responsive with how quickly they're willing to buff/nerf things, and are too focused on making recruit/veteran as playable as possible, while leaving Legend as that near impossibly feat since just after launch.

7.5/10

Editing my already negative review of how FS handles game balance during the WoM "beta" 2 days before its release-

Assuming FS doesn't just pull some elaborate "April Fools!" and revert many of the changes made in 2.0, this game will remain in a sorry state of combat for months, and this is coming from someone who doesn't even mind how bad it actually is right now. I can't, and won't suggest you buy WoM at this moment, and I can't really suggest buying the base game either, as you cant just avoid the horrid 180 they've made unless you stick to Recruit/Veteran difficulties. Many talents that allowed careers with blatant downsides to improve survivability have been fully removed, I.E. slayer lost most of his damage reduction seemingly due to his main downside- the lack of ranged weapons no longer being a thing due to throwing axes, Unchained lost her health increase, mind you she gains overheat for taking damage meaning she needs HP far more than many other careers, and just overall your ability to use one career as a class specialist is gone. Regenerating arrows using the Waystalker passive? (You know, the range focused elf?) Gone. Free shooting with BH? Gone. They more/less threw everyone in 1 bucket and gave minimal new traits to compensate for the fact that they're all mostly mediocre at the one thing they're meant to be good at, bringing the good careers down to the level of the bad ones, so now they're all bad, and even then, careers almost no one played had nieche useful talents removed due to single instance use of them making them almost good.

rant end

3/10

Seriously don't buy this game right now.

tl dr;
This game could have been great. Like this it's just good.

Itemization is very boring, talents (skills) are mostly bland (+damage, + health, only about half has some little utility), end game is just farming or starting from scratch in another game mode. Bots are basically potatoes. Combat is fun, but everything else around it is half-baked, unpolished.
Worst though is that there is no real end-game, the rarest items don't really offer anything substantial and their drop rate is ridiculous therefore grinding is tedious and unrewarding.

Graphics is mind blowing tho.

This is among the very best of games your friends will never play with you. 

It's a really interesting take on the Left 4 Dead/survival horror format. It really does well making you feel like you're fighting overwhelming odds, and the gameplay really makes you feel like a fantasy super hero. It also has a more traditional RPG gear system that can make this game with only a few playable characters/classes feel much more diverse. The only thing I think they didn't nail when it comes to gameplay is map design. The maps are really interesting and immersive but there are times where you feel totally lost. It doesn't hold your hand at all when it comes to directions. 

Unfortunately, it can get pretty repetitive. Not all the levels are going to feel completely unique, and the character progression system can feel really slow for new players. There are a surprisingly high amount of concurrent players, but the slow and repetitious gameplay loop hasn't appealed to a lot of my friends. Maybe you'll have more luck, but be prepared to play with randoms just in case. 

Overall, its really fun. Especially if you're a fan of the genre, franchise, or feeling like a bloodthirsty badass.

This is a great hack and slash game with unique characters and characters that feel very different from each other which keeps the game fresh. However, it has a lot of problems. The main one for me personally is the latency issue of taking damage even though you blocked/dodged way before the attack hit you. On Legend and Cat this will result in dying and takes away all my motivation to play when I'm not the host. Even with a stable ping of over 100 (I normally have 120) the game just feels unplayable. You'll constantly be taking chip damage which on anything but a full tank character will result in you going down multiple times a game when I rarely go down a single time in legend as the host. 

The game is also full of BS that punishes players for things outside of their control. Blightstormers are a great example, on legend a blightstormer can cast through a wall and cause an entire party to wipe. This is frustrating because there is nothing the player can do to prevent the situation. 

The dumbest issue I have with this game is so simple and yet it will never get fixed. WHY DON'T ENEMIES HAVE FOOTSTEPS?! an enemy can just run up behind you a stab you with you being non-the-wiser. In a game where getting hit a single time as a non-tank character can be extremely detrimental it so stupid enemies can silently sneak up behind you causing you to constantly spin around like an idiot the entire match to make sure nothings behind you.

Spouse told me it was like Dragon Age:  Inquisition but instead of demons, you are a rat exterminator. And how awesome is that?! 

Seriously though, awesome game and really fun for those of us who love the more medieval/steampunk setting as opposed to the spacey-wacey side of Warhammer. I'm a fairly new inductee, so it's been a bit touch-and-go with learning the lore. This game helps me put pieces together slower, like in the Chaos Wastes when you fight against certain Chaos Gods, I have a better understanding of what Slaanesh does versus Khorne, and so on. 

Only real downside in my eyes are the bots. They are *SHIT* when it's just you, thus I strongly recommend making at least three friends and getting them hooked on this game too. Really makes it all much more enjoyable! :)

Warhammer Vermintide 2 is a really great game where you can massacre rats and other enemies for hours. I would classify the story mode as average. Some missions are really good that you enjoy their entire passage and processing, some are more boring. There are 5 branches for which characters to play as, which are then divided into even more sub-branches, where each character then has different abilities. The difficulty of cataclysm can be nerve wracking, but it's nothing that isn't doable. Your stacking of weapons and their perks + amulets also play a big role in your successful passage. After completing the basic missions, I enjoyed the Chaos Wastes mod the most, where, on the other hand, at the beginning of the game you only have basic weapon colors and no perks. As you go through several missions in a row to reach the end, you find coins with which you can buy better equipment, weapons and perks for your survival. Some may find the missions repetitive, but I really enjoy the game.

So basicaly, I've played more than 30 weaves so far, yet only finished 6 of them since you can't start hosting game yourself. Instead you rely on matchmaking that connects you to unstable host rather than starting your (stable) hosted game. I admit  few runs were failed (one of them was minotaur instantly pushing whole group off the edge right at the start of second stage, and most of these include minotaurs which seem pretty OP to a newbie, even tho I had few successful Cataclysm runs on first Vermintide). I still have to say that 75 %  of weave runs end up with you disconnecting because of weird "Backend error" or "Broken connection" (that happens regularly even at the end of achiev and grim runs), or host leaving etc.

Also high ping renders you unable to block attacks in time!!!

TL;DR This is disguised SINGLEPLAYER game. Nonhosted multiplayer will fuck with you HARDLY. You better stick to localy hosted games. Matchmaking will make you wanna commit suicide.

Also Vermintide 1 seemed way better balanced and optimalized.

I almost forgot bots freezing randomly. So even singleplayer is big nerve-wrecker.

UPDATE: Weaves seem to be good as long as you play them during hours, when there's only few players playing. It will likely make you a game host, so you can simply kick low skilled players ruining your runs. This is necessary as weaves are way harder than either a story mission or Chaos Wastes expedition. Pickups are very rare.

After Darktide's abysmal launch, I realized I've waiting over a year for Sienna's 4th career because Fatshark stopped caring. The roadmap was abandoned, major bugs still exist, and people still crash for various reasons. This is a joke. 

Weaves died with zero effort made to fix the content. This was a paid expansion btw that also let you play the highest difficulty in the game. Unless you buy Winds of Magic you are stuck on Legend difficulty. Cataclysm in vermintide 1 was free. 

Blatantly overpowered paid weapons. Spear and Shield, Sword and Mace, Masterwork Pistol, Trollhammer Torpedo, Dual Hammers, Bilhook, Griffonfoot Pistols, Coruscation Staff, etc all outperform almost every other weapon in the base game by miles. Why did I skip over elf's dlc weapons? Well...

Releasing a blatantly overpowered class with overpowered weapons then waiting months to nerf it to the ground. What Fatshark did with Sister of Thorns release was disgusting. +50% crit, attack speed, and crit damage self buff on a "support" class, with a "ranged" weapon that melee stabbed monsters to death in seconds. With moonfire bow being released as well (pay for that skin btw), why would you NOT buy her? It took them weeks to slightly nerf her, then months to hard gut her. SOT was a scam career. You got scammed if you purchased her. 

Let's be real here, the only reason Fatshark didn't get enough criticism is because of the free content. Say goodbye to that, because Tencent owns a majority share in the company. Enjoy your daily login shillings, testing the waters to see if it affects daily player count so they can roll out predatory systems in future releases. 

Fatshark and Tencent can suck a dick while they continue to release mediocre products that lack genuine player retention.

Edit: Well thanks to Darktides current issues (predatory MXTs and lack of content in my case), I refunded that and came back to this. I'm happy to see it's been fixed. Would recommend this game again. Still has a healthy player base, lots of content since it's been out for a while. Also a great alternative if you want co op, tried Darktide and were unsatisfied with what you got.

This game was great. A real underrated gem when it released. As someone who loves both L4D and Warhammer, this game was a match made in heaven. To this day, even with all the developers mistakes (radio silence for extended periods, promised content never delivered, new content breaking the game ie weaves of magic etc) I would still recommend it if not for one thing: the game has become unplayable. No matter what solution I try, I can't get the stuttering and sudden frame drops to go away after this latest patch. This isn't the first time but it appears it's the last time. FS, I love you guys, flaws and all. But when I'm running this on an i7 8700k, RTX 3090, 32gb DDR4, and a 970 evo, and I go from 100 ish frames on high to suddenly 40s, something is wrong. When I drop everything to the lowest settings and it barely makes a difference, something is wrong. When the game is saying I'm getting 120+ fps but it feels like 24fps every few seconds, something is wrong. I've dug up every solution I could find online, and nothing works. Every other game on my PC runs without a hitch, so I know this isn't on my end.

So no, even after 650hrs I don't recommend this game to anyone interested because this isn't the first time a patch has been introduced that breaks the game. This trend dates back to launch. Ran great at first, and with every patch something broke and performance just got worse. Thanks to this it's killed my hype for Darktide. I won't be picking it up. I don't want to be burned again after investing so much time, energy, and money into something. If this ever gets fixed, I will happily change this review and get on Darktide. But I just don't see that happening. Shame, because I think you guys have great vision FS. This is easily the best if not one of the best co op first person games out there. But the technical issues are just too much.

This game rocks. The copious microtransactions for a paid game are kind of lame, but they're mostly for cosmetics and the game does have free cosmetics. 

Basically giant rat exterminator the game. Pretty sweet.

Game is quite fun, but it's best played with a group of friends. It can sometimes be frustrating to play with bots or other players. At the lower difficulties there's plenty of people to play with during any time of day. Try to not stick to the lowest difficulties for too long as nobody in recruit or veteran knows where the tomes and grimoires are, and you're bound to reinforce bad habits and not learn the game properly. 

Don't stick to Kruber too much, compared to the others he's quite bland. Try leveling Saltzpyre, Kerilian or Sienna.(especially Sienna, most new players are put off by the overheat mechanics, but Battle Wizard Sienna is the strongest class in the game)

Progression feels smooth, leveling to max is quite fast but item level grind might take new players a bit. Getting the important items in red "veteran" quality is the last step to the power-curve. Afterwards, it's just class mechanics and personal skill to carry you through the game.

There are a few classes that didn't receive as much love as others, like huntsman or pyromancer, who perform worse than competing alternatives from other classes OR other classes of the same character, but they can be fun to play regardless.

Of the DLC's, get them when discounted, but the most important ones are the weapon bundle (for torpedo launcher on Bardin, griffinfeet pistols on Saltzpyre and Coruscation staff - best staff on Sienna) and the expansions for more content (more maps to play).

Do you like killing rats? Oh, but that's a simple question... Do you... LOVE killing rats. Do you want to be mired in the bloodbath, surrounded by the gore and viscera of countless rats that charge you and throw themselves upon your blade? Utterly swamped in a tide of blood and vermin?

Vermintide is very similar to the game "Left 4 Dead" except replace the zombies with rats and significantly restrict your ammo supplies so you have to focus heavily on melee combat. You'll go through missions having to complete specific objectives while the game throws commoner rats and "northlanders" (basically L4D common horde) at you, tossing in things like machine-gun toting rats, armored soldier rats, berserker northlanders, gas-rats, flamethrower rats, minotaurs, and even super-armored hulking chaos warriors at you, and even random bosses, often several of the former at the same time depending on how much the AI director wants to screw you over. It's not easy, either... well, unless you're playing on recruit difficulty but that's more of a "learning the controls" gamemode than anything else.
That paragraph alone makes for an okay game, BUT the real meat of this game comes from the characters, and is what really sets it apart from other games in its genre of sorts. The Ubersreik Five are quite an interesting little quintet with a long history and very colorful dialogue with each other all throughout the missions, in the hub, and in the background story stuff, making for a very memorable cast in a genre that is typically lacking in such. It's this character flavoring in particular that enriches the experience of VT2 so much, the constant quips... the jabs at each other when you friendly fire, the thinly-veiled threats and clear tension yet existing comraderie between these five is something to behold and truly makes the experience what it is.
Each of the five characters has a ton of weapons to unlock as well, and has a sort of XP bar progression and an overall loot progression shared across all five characters (the more gear you get the higher the score goes until it caps at 300). These varying weapons as well as the 3-4 sub-classes each character has adds a lot of replayability and build variety to things and does a really good job at preventing the experience from growing dull, while also not serving as so much of a grind that it makes things tedious, managing to almost perfectly strike that happy medium of progress without excess grind that few games can strike... and that Fatshark has failed to strike with other ventures of theirs.
I will say this, though, if you are going to get this game, wait for sale as usual (duh!), but also I'd say to get all the gameplay-focused DLC save for character DLCs... and then consider getting the character DLC if you end up liking the character or the game as a whole enough to try such.

*As my main language is not English, translate was used while writing this article.
While reading this article, keep in mind that the game has been "in service" for 7 years.
- Crashes occur due to random error in the game. (Imagine playing the game for 20 minutes and closing just as you were about to finish the level).
- This game has more lag (ping) than other online games.
- The game uses a P2P system and you have no choice but to return to the main screen when the host of the current game quits the game due to an error or gets angry. (There should be a checkpoint system; when the host of the game leaves, one of the existing players should be replaced and he should be able to continue from that checkpoint).
- The game's player base is cancerous. Majority of the players have no respect for other players. For example, I witnessed that a player wanted the buff potion on the other player and that other player didn't want to give it, then killed that player and got the potion.
- Most of the players don't know how to play and are not inclined to learn. (It must be related to what I wrote above).
- Again, according to what I wrote above, there is another common occurrence while playing the game; The person who hosts the game (not directly related to being the host) goes somewhere without telling his teammates where he is going. Usually, this person dies ahead of the team because he is separate from the team and leaves the game. If it is the host who leaves the game, your time is wasted again and imagine that you enter the next game with this psychology.
- Most of the cosmetic upgrades of the game career DLCs do not unlock the skins in the game. It unlocks the challenges required to unlock those skins. And most of them are not challenges that require talent, they are challenges that you can accomplish with random events during the match. Therefore, you have to wait for a random event to get what you pay for. As a result, you have no choice but to watch the skins on the challenge page saying, "I wonder if I can have this skin one day?"
- The patches brought to the game are very few and progress slowly. (And it often brings other problems with it).
- Many mods were made to the game for the reason I wrote before. As I wrote at the beginning of this article, this game has been operating for 7 years, although the developers of the game have also half-assed some of these modes. So I don't have any hope for improvement anymore.
- There is no balance regarding the characters and weapons in the game. It is possible to see the same character careers and builds in the game.
- Doing the challenges in the game and developing your characters quickly become boring. There is no improvement in these. Therefore, you find yourself entering a random match by ignoring the challenges and simply saying "meh".

From the creators that played Played Left 4 Dead 1 and 2. Who were kicked out of Disneyland for kicking Mickey Mouse in the balls. They drew from their haterade of the mouse to create an exterminators dream, comes Vermintide 2. 

The player is able to slaughter as many rats throughout the magical kingdom until the job is done. The Ubersreik four or five it doesn't matter. 

Come back to the haunted lands to reclaim what they can after Disney has acquired as much territory. Three different careers per player. Choose between range, close quarter combat and tank role of your favorite character. 

Bardin, your uncle that you thought was over the hill, but is just getting started.
Kruber a down for anything solider that likes emo women.
Saltzpyre a priest that is all about blessing the rats on the head as hard as possible.
Kerillian a wood elf so deep in her emo phase she is slowly turning into a dark elf.
Sienna your fiery Latina aunt that is ready to go scorched earth. 

Now that the patches are out you can fight the Plague ridden (iPhone users), the Beast Men (your steroid jacked meat heads )and the Rat Men (Disney). 

Gather your friends and topple an empire for the Emperor.

This is not Left for Dead. I don't know why people claim it is. The only similarity is that it's 4 players co-op.

But while L4D2 had very tight design and perfect gameplay loop, this wants to be soo much bigger that it hurts that gameplay, in my opinion.

Specifically:

- there are different "classes" or characters with different special abilities and tons of various bonuses
- weapons you have depend on the class and what you selected before the battle. This alone makes such a huge difference to L4D interesting design where you had to use what you found, and you had to use various weapons in general.
- there is this weird pseudo-RPG level up system, where basically you get to improve the damage you deal.

I'm not saying it's a bad game, but I got fooled thinking I would get some of the L4D2 magic here, and for me it's not there.

Also I only played a few hours and with strangers (but that's also how I usually played L4D2). But I already got tired of the game in this time, not sure if I'll play more.

If you enjoy games like L4D, you'll love this game. While sitting in the similar general genre of a 4-Player Horde Slasher/Shooter, it's more than unique enough to stand on it's own. 5 players each with 3 vanilla classes to choose from, equipment to grab, craft, and upgrade and weapons to unlock and learn. Cosmetics, both free and premium (and entirely separated from each other!) And some pretty strong standalone DLC (If a bit on the short end sometimes). Fatshark even will sanction some mods that you can play on official servers with (they're small and more along the lines of QoL than anything else, but there's one that improves the bots a bit, great if you're playing Solo with them.) They're still working on content for the games, (grudge marks for the Chaos Wastes recently dropped) and they're still working on the DLC character classes (still waiting on Victor and Sienna, with Kerillian being the most recent dlc class dropped) I always find myself coming back to this game, and for once, I rather enjoy the grind. Tons of challenges, plenty of unlocks, and the events are nice, too. I finished the Halloween event and got some weapon cosmetics, and a couple cool new frames. Great for some extra challenge, too.
EDIT: Still enjoying the game, still waiting on Sienna DLC class, LOL. Victor's DLC class is too much fun, waiting to see where the "Kruber is missing" diary entries go.

Good game, in the same vein of older games like Left 4 Dead or Left 4 Dead 2. It copies a lot of mechanics of that kind of game - hordes of enemies spawning at intervals to attack you, special enemies that can disable you and that teammates can save you from if you get caught, bosses - plus adds a lot of new stuff on top of having much improved combat.

You go through missions primarily fighting Skaven (rat people), but also fighting human followers of the Chaos Gods. There are five characters you can choose from, each with different weapons, special activated ultimate abilities, and three (four with DLC) variants you can choose from. You can customize your character with gear - new weapons and such - as you play the game and unlock new weapons. You gain talent points every 5 levels up to about level 30 which lets you customize your character somewhat, so you can focus specifically on a build that gains temporary health with multiple enemies hit and wield greatswords that cleave through foes, or focus on weapons with armor-piercing abilities and fast attacks then focus on single target kills. Characters have both ranged and melee weapons, with ranged and melee sub-classes existing. There is a crafting system that lets you customize your weapons and such, such as re-forging their special traits (like 10% bonus vs infantry or extra stamina shields for blocking), or upgrading them to the next rarity tier (which might give them additional bonuses, or something like "when you use a potion the nearest ally gets its effect as well").

All in all it's a fun game to go through. It does require four players to get the most out of it, but I do quite well with two-player co-op (bots fill the other two slots, and while they aren't very competent they aren't completely useless most of the time). On sale it 100% is worth it, and I'm probably going to pick up some of the DLC before the current sale ends.

Edit: After playing a couple dozen more hours since this review, I have played through all of the missions except the Return to Ubersreik ones (which I played in Vermintide 1 years ago anyway somewhat), and have gotten through a handful of missions on Legendary difficult with a single friend in co-op. It is definitely worth playing, though I would grab it on sale if you aren't sure or don't have enough friends to play it with (as playing solo or with random players isn't for everyone).

This game is alot of fun. Haven't played many melee focused first person games like it. If you're a chivalry fan looking for something a bit more PvE, an old L4D Fan, someone who can't stand the melee nerfs in Back4Blood, or just and RPG enthusiast looking for some character customization and looting in a co-op setting; there is plenty of fun to be had. 

Excellent character dialogue and depth through sparse interactions through your long playtime.  Multiple classes to pick from (a bit of character locking for classes but having played Darktide I'm actually viewing that as a plus now if the alternative is boring stagnant create a character stiff board nonsense). 

Engaging story with a few missions from the first game (narrator character won't SHUT UP DURING, which takes the place of the old character dialogue unfortunately). An amazing experience that anyone can enjoy and a class for any type of playstyle. 

This game is STILL BEING UPDATED DESPITE IT LIKELY HAVING SOME OVERLAP IN PLAYERBASE WITH NEWLY RELEASED DARKTIDE. The devs have a vision for updating it and they're not through yet with no signs of slowing down. Unlike Darktide it also features a unique cast of multiple races instead of all samey and equally ugly humans (likely lore accurate for 40k but still painful to the eyes).  

Can't wait to see the as of yet unreleased fourth class for Sienna (she's effectively a pyromancer for those uninitiated in Warhammer lore), and the direction this newest set of unreleased stages are going to go.

If you're still reading up to this point than quit wasting time and GET THIS GEM NOW you will not regret it.

It's Left 4 Dead with RPG elements.  It also has some of the best melee combat I've ever played.   Enemy damage directly relates to where your weapon impacts, and those hits matter.  Cracking someone in the side of the knee will knock them to the ground.  The shields actually protect only the shielded area, and don't give the enemies a magical barrier that protects against damage.  If you aim carefully, you can bypass the shields with skill.  It's very satisfying. 

Also, the weapon actually all play differently.  Each weapon type has its own style of gameplay, and not just the same weapon animations with slightly different stats.   And their different styles of play work better against certain enemy types than others, so make it interest to try out different combos and different "builds."  

If you want a hack and slash, this game will give you all you can handle!

Great game that's still being updated, albeit very slowly. It has great mechanics and depth, while still being fun and easily accessible. It's basically a Left 4 Dead-like game, with a focus on melee, magic and fantasy style combat, with added RPG elements such as levelling, talents, abilities, and a variety of gear rarities, stats and traits that you can create and modify yourself using a basic crafting system. It's not super in-depth compared to most RPG games, but it's enough and It works tremendously well with this style of gameplay, in my opinion it's taken the basic essence of Left4Dead and expanded on it for a much more comprehensive experience.

Like L4D it is a co-op game, so the experience is definitely better with friends, but it's a really fun game to play and to waste a few hours. The only thing it's really lacking gameplay-wise is more variety in the levels, enemies and bosses, and sadly it has no versus mode, despite this being promised by the developers for years. 

Another positive thing to note is that It also has great characters, with brilliant voice acting, some of the best I've probably heard in a video game, and even though i'm not particularly knowledgeable on Warhammer lore, I find it fun and engaging.

So yeah, it's a solid game in my opinion and one i'd definitely recommend. It's regularly on offer and unless you're completely against this style of gameplay, then i'd say it's a must play.
